description: Correlations in momentum space between hadrons created by ultrarelativistic proton–proton collisions at the CERN Large Hadron Collider provide insights into the strong interaction, particularly the short-range dynamics of hyperons—baryons that contain strange quarks.

heading: Detection of large-scale X-ray bubbles in the Milky Way halo
description: Observations from the eROSITA telescope reveal soft-X-ray-emitting bubbles extending above and below the Galactic plane, which arose from energy injected into the Galactic halo from past activity in the Galactic centre.

heading: Structure of mycobacterial ATP synthase bound to the tuberculosis drug bedaquiline
authors: Hui GuoGautier M. CourbonJohn L. Rubinstein
description: Structures of Mycobacterium smegmatis ATP synthase provide insights into how the enzyme conserves energy by autoinhibition of ATP hydrolysis and the mechanism of action of bedaquiline, a drug used in treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis.

heading: H1 histones control the epigenetic landscape by local chromatin compaction
authors: Michael A. WillcocksonSean E. HealtonArthur I. Skoultchi
description: Experiments using a conditional triple-knockout mouse strain show that histone H1 regulates the activity of chromatin domains by controlling chromatin compaction, genome architecture and  histone methylation.

heading: Enigmatic dinosaur precursors bridge the gap to the origin of Pterosauria
authors: Martín D. EzcurraSterling J. NesbittMax C. Langer
description: Lagerpetids, bipedal archosaurs that are thought to be related to dinosaurs, are instead a sister group to pterosaurs, and although they have no obvious flight adaptations they share numerous synapomorphies with pterosaurs across the entire skeleton.

heading: Lymphoangiocrine signals promote cardiac growth and repair
authors: Xiaolei LiuEster De la CruzGuillermo Oliver
description: Lymphatic endothelium secretes factors needed for heart growth and repair such as RELN, which helps with heart regeneration and cardioprotection after myocardial infarction.

heading: Operation of an optical atomic clock with a Brillouin laser subsystem
description: By using a stimulated Brillouin scattering laser in a strontium-ion optical clock instead of the usual bulk-cavity-stabilized laser, the need for vacuum is removed and resonator volume is substantially reduced.

heading: An SHR–SCR module specifies legume cortical cell fate to enable nodulation
description: Repurposing of an SHR–SCR stem cell program in the legume root cortex enables rhizobial symbiosis.

heading: The functional proteome landscape of Escherichia coli
description: Thermal proteome profiling combined with a reverse genetics approach provides insights into the abundance and thermal stability of the global proteome of Escherichia coli.

heading: A hydrophobic ratchet entrenches molecular complexes
authors: Georg K. A. HochbergYang LiuJoseph W. Thornton
description: Accumulation of hydrophobic residues at the interface between monomers may favour the maintenance of multimeric protein states during evolution, even if multimerization confers no functional advantage.

heading: Correlates of protection against SARS-CoV-2 in rhesus macaques
description: Adoptive transfer of purified IgG from convalescent macaques protects naive macaques against SARS-CoV-2 infection, and cellular immune responses contribute to protection against rechallenge with SARS-CoV-2.

heading: Enhanced triple-α reaction reduces proton-rich nucleosynthesis in supernovae
description: The triple-α reaction rate in proton-rich core-collapse supernovae is found to be enhanced at high nucleon densities, suppressing the formation of proton-rich nuclei from gallium to cadmium.

heading: Structure of the class D GPCR Ste2 dimer coupled to two G proteins
description: A cryo-electron microscopy structure of the yeast pheromone receptor Ste2, a class D G-protein-coupled receptor, in its active state reveals that Ste2 is a homodimer that couples to two G proteins.

heading: Ultrafast structural changes within a photosynthetic reaction centre
description: Time-resolved serial femtosecond crystallography is used to reveal the structural changes that stabilize the charge-separation steps of electron-transfer reactions in the photosynthetic reaction centre of Blastochloris viridis on a timescale of picoseconds.

heading: Availability of food determines the need for sleep in memory consolidation
authors: Nitin S. ChouhanLeslie C. GriffithAmita Sehgal
description: Hunger status in a fly is shown to drive either sleep-dependent or sleep-independent memory formation through different mushroom body circuits.

heading: Thermochemical lithosphere differentiation and the origin of cratonic mantle
authors: Fabio A. CapitanioOliver NebelPeter A. Cawood
description: A model is proposed for the origin of cratonic lithospheric mantle in which rifting and melting in the hot, early Earth mantle leave behind large volumes of stiffer, depleted mantle.

heading: Distinct hypothalamic control of same- and opposite-sex mounting behaviour in mice
description: Ultrasonic vocalizations of male mice distinguish aggressive, male-directed mounting from reproductive, female-directed mounting behaviours, which are represented by distinct ESR1-expressing populations of neurons in the ventromedial hypothalamus and medial preoptic area, respectively.

heading: Determination of the fine-structure constant with an accuracy of 81 parts per trillion
description: The fine-structure constant is determined with an accuracy of 81 parts per trillion using matter-wave interferometry to measure the rubidium atom recoil velocity.

heading: Highly multiplexed spatial mapping of microbial communities
description: High-phylogenetic-resolution microbiome mapping by fluorescence in situ hybridization (HiPR-FISH) enables the spatial mapping of hundreds of species of microorganisms and shows how microbial networks in the mouse gut are affected by antibiotic treatment.

heading: The neuropeptide Pth2 dynamically senses others via mechanosensation
authors: Lukas AnneserIvan C. AlcantaraErin M. Schuman
description: In zebrafish, the expression levels of the neuropeptide Pth2 change as exposure to conspecifics is limited or increased, and these changes track the presence of individuals and group density through mechanical stimulations induced by the movements of other fish.

heading: Structure of the shutdown state of myosin-2
description: The structure of myosin-2 in the shutdown state reveals how the shutdown state is stabilized and how phosphorylation of light chains allows myosin to be activated.

heading: ALDH4A1 is an atherosclerosis auto-antigen targeted by protective antibodies
description: An autoantibody found in a mouse model of atherosclerosis recognizses ALDH4A1, and infusion of the antibody delays plaque formation in mice.

heading: Cryo-EM structure of the inhibited (10S) form of myosin II
description: High-resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of smooth muscle myosin II in the inhibited state enables increased understanding of the functions of the head and tail regions in regulation of myosin activity and the pathological mechanisms of disease mutations.

heading: Autonomous navigation of stratospheric balloons using reinforcement learning
description: Data augmentation and a self-correcting design are used to develop a reinforcement-learning algorithm for the autonomous navigation of Loon superpressure balloons in challenging stratospheric weather conditions.

heading: A brainstem peptide system activated at birth protects postnatal breathing
authors: Yingtang ShiDaniel S. StornettaDouglas A. Bayliss
description: A peptidergic brainstem circuit is identified that supports the initiation and establishment of breathing by providing a supplementary respiratory drive immediately after birth.

heading: Galactosaminogalactan activates the inflammasome to provide host protection
description: Galactosaminogalactan of Aspergillus fumigatus acts as a pathogen-associated molecular pattern that activates the NLRP3 inflammasome, which is crucial for anti-fungal host defence.

heading: Reprogramming to recover youthful epigenetic information and restore vision
description: Expression of three Yamanaka transcription factors in mouse retinal ganglion cells restores youthful DNA methylation patterns, promotes axon regeneration after injury, and reverses vision loss in a mouse model of glaucoma and in aged mice, suggesting that mammalian tissues retain a record of youthful epigenetic information that can be accessed to improve tissue function.

heading: A single-dose live-attenuated YF17D-vectored SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate
description: A candidate vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 that uses the yellow fever 17D live-virus vector is highly efficacious and displays a favourable safety profile in Syrian hamster, mouse and cynomolgus macaque models.

heading: Metallaphotoredox aryl and alkyl radiomethylation for PET ligand discovery
authors: Robert W. PipalKenneth T. StoutDavid W. C. MacMillan
description: A versatile and rapid metallaphotoredox catalytic method of making 3H- and 11C-labelled tracer compounds for use in positron emission tomography (PET) is reported.

heading: TRF2-mediated telomere protection is dispensable in pluripotent stem cells
description: Depletion of TRF2—an essential mediator of telomere protection in most mammalian cells—in mouse embryonic stem cells activates a compensatory transcriptional program that renders TRF2 dispensable for their survival and proliferation.

heading: The barley pan-genome reveals the hidden legacy of mutation breeding
description: Chromosome-scale sequence assemblies of 20 diverse varieties of barley are used to construct a first-generation pan-genome, revealing previously hidden genetic variation that can be used by studies aimed at crop improvement

heading: TRF2-independent chromosome end protection during pluripotency
authors: Phil RuisDavid Van LySimon J. Boulton
description: Experiments in mouse pluripotent embryonic and epiblast stem cells show that TRF2 is dispensable for telomere protection specifically specifically in the pluripotent cells that form during early embryonic development, when cells form T-loops independently of this protein.

heading: A network of grassroots reserves protects tropical river fish diversity
authors: Aaron A. KoningK. Martin PeralesPeter B. McIntyre
description: A network of small, community-run river reserves in Thailand increases local fish biomass, diversity and richness.

heading: The gut microbiota is associated with immune cell dynamics in humans
authors: Jonas SchluterJonathan U. PeledJoao B. Xavier
description: Influence of the gut microbiome on the human immune system is revealed by systems analysis of vast clinical data from decades of electronic health records paired with massive longitudinal microbiome sequencing.

heading: Functional adaptive landscapes predict terrestrial capacity at the origin of limbs
authors: Blake V. DicksonJennifer A. ClackStephanie E. Pierce
description: Analysis of humeri from fossils that span the fin-to-limb transition reveal that the change in the humerus shape is driven by both ecology and phylogeny, and is associated with functional trade-offs related to locomotor performance.

heading: A map of cis-regulatory elements and 3D genome structures in zebrafish
description: A comprehensive map of transcriptomes, cis-regulatory elements, heterochromatin structure, the methylome and 3D genome organization in the zebrafish (Danio rerio) enables identification of species-specific and evolutionarily conserved regulatory features, and provides a foundation for modelling studies on human disease and development.

heading: Multiple wheat genomes reveal global variation in modern breeding
description: Comparison of multiple genome assemblies from wheat reveals extensive diversity that results from the complex breeding history of wheat and provides a basis for further potential improvements to this important food crop.

heading: Commensal-driven immune zonation of the liver promotes host defence
authors: Anita GolaMichael G. DorringtonRonald N. Germain
description: The authors show that zonation extends to hepatic immune cells and that this spatial patterning is mediated by microbiome sensing by liver sinusoidal endothelial cells, and provide evidence that immune zonation is required to protect the host from the dissemination of blood-borne pathogens.

heading: Progenitor identification and SARS-CoV-2 infection in human distal lung organoids
authors: Ameen A. SalahudeenShannon S. ChoiCalvin J. Kuo
description: A long-term culture method for organoids derived from single adult human lung cells is used to identify progenitor cells and study SARS-CoV-2 infection.

heading: Late Cretaceous bird from Madagascar reveals unique development of beaks
authors: Patrick M. O’ConnorAlan H. TurnerLydia J. Rahantarisoa
description: A crow-sized stem bird, Falcatakely forsterae, possesses a long and deep rostrum—a beak morphology that was previously unknown among Mesozoic birds and is similar to that of some crown-group birds, such as toucans.

heading: Neural circuit mechanisms of sexual receptivity in Drosophila females
description: In Drosophila melanogaster, female mating decisions are governed by female-specific descending neurons that integrate input from auditory neurons that respond to features of the song of a conspecific male and central neurons that encode the mating status of the female.

heading: Splicing factor YBX1 mediates persistence of JAK2-mutated neoplasms
authors: Ashok Kumar JayaveluTina M. SchnöderFlorian H. Heidel
description: Inhibition of YBX1, a downstream target of the Janus kinase JAK2, sensitizes myeloproliferative neoplasm cells to JAK and could provide a means to eradicate such cells in human haematopoietic cancers.

heading: Experimental evidence of neutrinos produced in the CNO fusion cycle in the Sun
description: Direct experimental evidence of the carbon–nitrogen–oxygen fusion cycle in the Sun is provided by the detection of neutrinos emitted during this process.

heading: Lanthanide-doped inorganic nanoparticles turn molecular triplet excitons bright
description: Optically dark (non-emitting) triplet excitons on organic molecules may be rendered bright by coupling the molecules to lanthanide-doped nanoparticles, providing a way to control such excitons in optoelectronic systems.

heading: Antarctic ice dynamics amplified by Northern Hemisphere sea-level forcing
authors: Natalya GomezMichael E. WeberHolly K. Han
description: Changes in Northern Hemisphere ice-sheet size during ice-age cycles enhance the advance and retreat of the grounding line of the Antarctic Ice Sheet, owing to interhemispheric sea-level forcing.

heading: Spin-enhanced nanodiamond biosensing for ultrasensitive diagnostics
authors: Benjamin S. MillerLéonard BezingeRachel A. McKendry
description: Lateral-flow in vitro diagnostic assays based on fluorescent nanodiamonds, in which microwave-based spin manipulation is used to increase sensitivity, are demonstrated using the biotin–avidin model and by the single-copy detection of HIV-1 RNA.

heading: Observing the emergence of a quantum phase transition shell by shell
description: An atomic simulator formed of a few ultracold fermionic atoms trapped in a two-dimensional harmonic potential exhibits precursors of a quantum phase transition, revealing the onset of collective quantum many-body phenomena in a few-body system.

heading: Electrical switching of magnetic order in an orbital Chern insulator
description: Non-volatile electrical switching of magnetic order in an orbital Chern insulator is experimentally demonstrated using a moiré heterostructure and analysis shows that the effect is driven by topological edge states.

heading: Unconventional ferroelectricity in moiré heterostructures
description: Electronic ferroelectricity is observed in a graphene-based moiré heterostructure, which is explained using a spontaneous interlayer charge-transfer model driven by layer-specific on-site Coulomb repulsion.

heading: Key role of chemistry versus bias in electrocatalytic oxygen evolution
authors: Hong Nhan NongLorenz J. FallingTravis E. Jones
description: Spectroscopic studies and theoretical calculations of the electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction establish that reaction rates depend on the amount of charge stored in the electrocatalyst, and not on the applied potential.

heading: LDLRAD3 is a receptor for Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus
authors: Hongming MaArthur S. KimMichael S. Diamond
description: LDLRAD3 is a receptor for infection with Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus, and in mouse models deletion of Ldlrad3 or treatment with a soluble LDLRAD3 decoy molecule abrogates infection and disease caused by this virus.

heading: Small-molecule-induced polymerization triggers degradation of BCL6
description: Binding of the small molecule BI-3802 to the oncogenic transcription factor B cell lymphoma 6 (BCL6) induces polymerization of BCL6, leading to its ubiquitination by SIAH1 and proteasomal degradation.

heading: MFSD12 mediates the import of cysteine into melanosomes and lysosomes
authors: Charles H. AdelmannAnna K. TraunbauerDavid M. Sabatini
description: A rapid labelling and immunopurification-based method is used to isolate melanosomes and profile their labile metabolites, revealing that MFSD12 has a key role in cysteine import into melanosomes and lysosomes.

heading: Clustered versus catastrophic global vertebrate declines
description: In the geographically and taxonomically divided systems of vertebrates in the Living Planet Index, a small percentage of clusters showed extreme declines or increases, whereas most vertebrate populations across all systems showed no mean global trend.

heading: Assembly of synaptic active zones requires phase separation of scaffold molecules
authors: Nathan A. McDonaldRichard D. FetterKang Shen
description: The components of active zones at neuronal synapses are well known, but the processes underlying the assembly of these structures are less so; here, a role for liquid–liquid phase separation of scaffold proteins is identified.

heading: Drivers and dynamics of a massive adaptive radiation in cichlid fishes
description: Analyses of molecular, anatomical, pigmentation and ecological characteristics of nearly all of the approximately 240 species of cichlid fishes in Lake Tanganyika show that the massive adaptive radiation occurred within the confines of the lake through trait-specific pulses of accelerated evolution.

heading: RNA nucleation by MSL2 induces selective X chromosome compartmentalization
authors: Claudia Isabelle Keller ValsecchiM. Felicia BasilicataAsifa Akhtar
description: Dosage compensation in Drosophila involves nucleation of the dosage compensation complex at the X chromosome by MSL2 and the non-coding RNA roX.

heading: Coupling of hippocampal theta and ripples with pontogeniculooccipital waves
authors: Juan F. Ramirez-VillegasMichel BesserveNikos K. Logothetis
description: Studies using multi-structure recordings in macaque monkeys show that distinct phasic pontogeniculooccipital waves modulate hippocampal network events similar to those that underlie the learning and formation of memories during sleep.

heading: Structure and function of virion RNA polymerase of a crAss-like phage
authors: Arina V. DrobyshevaSofia A. PanafidinaMaria L. Sokolova
description: The RNA polymerase from the crAss-like bacteriophage phi14:2, which is translocated into the host cell with phage DNA and transcribes early phage genes, is structurally most similar to eukaryotic RNA interference polymerases, suggesting that the latter have a phage origin.

heading: A network of transcriptional repressors modulates auxin responses
description: Genes encoding the class A auxin-response factor group of plant transcriptional activators reside in constitutively open chromatin, enabling their continual regulation by transcriptional repressors to modulate auxin signalling throughout development.

heading: Tension heterogeneity directs form and fate to pattern the myocardial wall
authors: Rashmi PriyaSrinivas AllankiDidier Y. R. Stainier
description: Differences in the mechanical properties of individual cardiomyocytes drive their segregation into compact versus trabecular layer, thereby transforming the myocardium in a developing heart from a simple epithelium into an intricately patterned tissue with distinct cell fates.

heading: Widespread endogenization of giant viruses shapes genomes of green algae
authors: Mohammad MoniruzzamanAlaina R. WeinheimerFrank O. Aylward
description: The authors show that large endogenous viral elements derived from giant viruses are prominent components of green algal genomes.

heading: Defining HPV-specific B cell responses in patients with head and neck cancer
description: Detailed analyses of B cells in the tumour microenvironment of human papilloma virus (HPV)-linked head and neck cancers reveal strong humoral immune responses to HPV antigens and the secretion of HPV-specific antibodies in situ.

heading: A molecular cell atlas of the human lung from single-cell RNA sequencing
authors: Kyle J. TravagliniAhmad N. NabhanMark A. Krasnow
description: Expression profiling on 75,000 single cells creates a comprehensive cell atlas of the human lung that includes 41 out of 45 previously known cell types and 14 new ones.

heading: Host ANP32A mediates the assembly of the influenza virus replicase
description: Structural and biochemical studies of influenza virus RNA polymerase in complex with host acidic nuclear phosphoprotein 32 (ANP32) show how ANP32-mediated polymerase dimerization enables the replication of influenza viral RNA in a host-dependent manner.

heading: Observation of gauge invariance in a 71-site Bose–Hubbard quantum simulator
description: Quantum simulation in a 71-site optical lattice certifies gauge invariance, showing how this essential property of lattice gauge theories can be maintained across a quantum phase transition.

heading: A blue ring nebula from a stellar merger several thousand years ago
authors: Keri HoadleyD. Christopher MartinBradley E. Schaefer
description: Observations and stellar evolution models of a blue ring nebula and its central star (TYC 2597-735-1) suggest that the remnant star merged with a lower-mass companion several thousand years ago.

heading: The scales of human mobility
description: A model shows that human mobility is organized within hierarchical containers that coincide with familiar scales and that a power-law distribution emerges when movements between different containers are combined.

heading: The growth equation of cities
description: A theoretical model in the form of a stochastic differential equation is proposed that describes, more accurately than previous models, the population evolution of cities, revealing that rare but very large interurban migration is a dominant factor.

heading: Sources of particulate-matter air pollution and its oxidative potential in Europe
authors: Kaspar R. DaellenbachGaëlle UzuAndré S. H. Prévôt
description: Observations and air-quality modelling reveal that the sources of particulate matter and oxidative potential in Europe are different, implying that reducing mass concentrations of particulate matter alone may not reduce oxidative potential.

heading: Structural basis for the final steps of human 40S ribosome maturation
description: Studies of five cryo-electron microscopy structures reveal the composition and conformational progression in the final maturation events of human 40S ribosomal subunit assembly.

heading: Phenotypic variation of transcriptomic cell types in mouse motor cortex
description: Single-cell transcriptomic, morphological and electrophysiological characteristics are combined to classify more than 1,300 neurons from mouse motor cortex.

heading: Decoding myofibroblast origins in human kidney fibrosis
description: A range of techniques are used to investigate the molecular landscape of chronic kidney disease, and the results suggest that distinct populations of pericytes and fibroblasts are the main source of myofibroblasts in kidney fibrosis.

heading: Slower decay of landfalling hurricanes in a warming world
description: North Atlantic landfalling hurricanes are weakening more slowly than in the past because warming oceans are increasing the moisture carried by the storm until it hits land, and this storm moisture acts as an ongoing heat source post-landfall.

heading: A reference map of potential determinants for the human serum metabolome
description: The levels of 1,251 metabolites are measured in 475 phenotyped individuals, and machine-learning algorithms reveal that diet and the microbiome are the determinants with the strongest predictive power for the levels of these metabolites.

heading: A measure of smell enables the creation of olfactory metamers
description: By collecting nearly 50,000 perceptual estimates of smell, a reliable physicochemical measure that links odorant structure to odorant perception at a resolution that enables the creation of olfactory metamers was derived.

heading: Feeding induces cholesterol biosynthesis via the mTORC1–USP20–HMGCR axis
description: mTORC1 stabilizes HMG-CoA reductase, a rate-limiting enzyme in the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway, via the deubiquitylase USP20 in response to feeding.

heading: Inhibition of PCSK9 potentiates immune checkpoint therapy for cancer
description: Inhibiting the PCSK9 protein, a regulator of cholesterol metabolism, enhances immune checkpoint therapy in mouse models of cancer, in a manner that depends on the regulation of antigen-presenting MHC I molecules.

heading: Chemico-genetic discovery of astrocytic control of inhibition in vivo
authors: Tetsuya TakanoJohn T. WallaceScott H. Soderling
description: A cell-surface fragment complementation strategy is used to identify the proteome at the junction of astrocytes and synapses in vivo, and shows that NRCAM expressed in astrocytes has a key role in regulating inhibitory synapse function.

heading: Spatial connectivity matches direction selectivity in visual cortex
authors: L. Federico RossiKenneth D. HarrisMatteo Carandini
description: In the mouse visual cortex, the excitatory and inhibitory presynaptic neurons of individual layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons are spatially offset to generate direction-selective responses.

heading: Transcriptome and translatome co-evolution in mammals
description: An analysis using ribosome-profiling and matched RNA-sequencing data for three organs across five mammalian species and a bird enables the comparison of translatomes and transcriptomes, revealing patterns of co-evolution of these two expression layers.

heading: Dense sampling of bird diversity increases power of comparative genomics
description: A dataset of the genomes of 363 species from the Bird 10,000 Genomes Project shows increased power to detect shared and lineage-specific variation, demonstrating the importance of phylogenetically diverse taxon sampling in whole-genome sequencing.

heading: Sensory pollutants alter bird phenology and fitness across a continent
authors: Masayuki SenzakiJesse R. BarberClinton D. Francis
description: Human-generated noise and night lighting affect breeding habits and fitness in birds, implying that sensory pollutants must be considered alongside other environmental factors in assessing biodiversity conservation.

heading: HSP40 proteins use class-specific regulation to drive HSP70 functional diversity
description: The binding and activation of HSP70 by class B J-domain proteins is subject to an autoinhibitory regulatory mechanism that controls substrate targeting to HSP70 and is required for the disaggregation of amyloid fibres.

heading: A yeast living ancestor reveals the origin of genomic introgressions
description: A yeast clonal descendant of an ancient hybridization event is identified and sheds light on the early evolution of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Alpechin lineage and its abundant Saccharomyces paradoxus introgressions.

heading: Molecular dissection of amyloid disaggregation by human HSP70
authors: Anne S. WentinkNadinath B. NillegodaBernd Bukau
description: The molecular steps that lead to the disaggregation of amyloid fibrils are shown to involve the synergistic action of HSP70 and its co-chaperones DNAJB1 and HSP110.

heading: Progressive Cactus is a multiple-genome aligner for the thousand-genome era
description: The Progressive Cactus program can create reference-free alignments of hundreds of large vertebrate genomes efficiently, and is used for the alignment of more than 600 amniote genomes.

heading: Correlated insulating states at fractional fillings of moiré superlattices
description: An optical sensing technique reveals an abundance of correlated insulating states at fractional fillings of moiré superlattices that are proposed to arise from a series of charge-ordered states.

heading: The baryon density of the Universe from an improved rate of deuterium burning
description: High-precision cross-sections of the nuclear reaction that burns deuterium to create helium-3 are used to produce theoretical estimates of the primordial baryon density that are in agreement with recent astronomical observations.

heading: Persistent transcriptional programmes are associated with remote memory
authors: Michelle B. ChenXian JiangThomas C. Südhof
description: The authors identify long-lasting transcriptional programmes in neurons and glia that are associated with the storage of a remote memory.

heading: Ultra-sensitive and resilient compliant strain gauges for soft machines
authors: Oluwaseun A. AraromiMoritz A. GrauleRobert J. Wood
description: Strain gauges with both high sensitivity and high mechanical resilience, based on strain-mediated contact in anisotropically resistive structures, are demonstrated within a sensor-integrated, textile-based sleeve that can recognize human hand motions via muscle deformations.

heading: Anatomy of cage formation in a two-dimensional glass-forming liquid
description: The onset of rigidity in a two-dimensional colloidal glass-forming system is identified by the formation and merging of locally rigid domains in which particles move in a cooperative manner.

heading: A comparative genomics multitool for scientific discovery and conservation
authors: Diane P. GenereuxAitor SerresElinor K. Karlsson
description: A whole-genome alignment of 240 phylogenetically diverse species of eutherian mammal—including 131 previously uncharacterized species—from the Zoonomia Project provides data that support biological discovery, medical research and conservation.

heading: Mobility network models of COVID-19 explain inequities and inform reopening
description: An epidemiological model that integrates fine-grained mobility networks illuminates mobility-related mechanisms that contribute to higher infection rates among disadvantaged socioeconomic and racial groups, and finds that restricting maximum occupancy at locations is especially effective for curbing infections.

heading: COVID-19 treatments and pathogenesis including anosmia in K18-hACE2 mice
description: Transgenic K18-hACE2 mice are a useful model of COVID-19 including anosmia; infection of these mice resulted in severe pneumonia and, in some cases, infection in the brain, which was prevented by convalescent plasma.

heading: An early Cambrian euarthropod with radiodont-like raptorial appendages
description: Kylinxia zhangi is a transitional fossil that is an evolutionary ‘missing link’ between radiodonts (also known as anomalocaridids) and true arthropods, providing insights into the origin and early evolution of Arthropoda.

heading: Neuronal diversity and convergence in a visual system developmental atlas
description: The neuronal diversity of the Drosophila optic lobe is described throughout pupal development by single-cell sequencing, leading to the discovery of transient extrinsic neurons and a dorsoventral asymmetry of the visual circuits.

heading: IFITM3 functions as a PIP3 scaffold to amplify PI3K signalling in B cells
description: IFITM3 shifts upon phosphorylation from acting as an antiviral effector to being a scaffold for PIP3 and thereby amplifies PI3K signalling, which can be co-opted for malignant transformation in B cell leukaemia and lymphoma.

heading: Structures and pH-sensing mechanism of the proton-activated chloride channel
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the human proton-activated chloride channel (PAC) shed light on its pH-dependent gating mechanism and anion selectivity.

heading: Inhibition of LTβR signalling activates WNT-induced regeneration in lung
authors: Thomas M. ConlonGerrit John-SchusterAli Önder Yildirim
description: Blockade of lymphotoxin β-receptor (LTβR) signalling restores WNT signalling and epithelial repair in a model of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

heading: Combinatorial expression of GPCR isoforms affects signalling and drug responses
authors: Maria Marti-SolanoStephanie E. CrillyM. Madan Babu
description: Transcriptomics, proteomics, single-cell RNA sequencing, population-wide genetic association studies and structure–function analyses provide a picture of how the differential expression of G-protein-coupled receptor isoforms can diversify signalling in different tissues.

heading: A bright millisecond-duration radio burst from a Galactic magnetar
authors: B. C. AndersenK. M. BanduraA. V. Zwaniga
description: Measurements of an intense radio burst from a Galactic magnetar provide evidence that magnetars are the probable source of some fast radio bursts.

heading: Paracrine signalling by cardiac calcitonin controls atrial fibrogenesis and arrhythmia
description: Heart atria produce a large pool of calcitonin (previously well-recognized as a thyroid-secreted hormone with roles in calcium and bone metabolism) that in the heart acts as a paracrine signal controlling atrial fibrosis and fibrillation.

heading: Logic-in-memory based on an atomically thin semiconductor
description: Logic operations and reconfigurable circuits are demonstrated that can be directly implemented using memory elements based on floating-gate field-effect transistors with monolayer MoS2 as the active channel material.

heading: Gut-educated IgA plasma cells defend the meningeal venous sinuses
description: IgA-secreting plasma cells that originate in the intestine are found in the meninges, where they protect the brain against pathogens.

heading: Host variables confound gut microbiota studies of human disease
description: The authors use a machine-learning approach to uncover confounding variables in studies that seek to establish an association between the gut microbiota and human disease.

heading: The impact of nuclear shape on the emergence of the neutron dripline
description: A mechanistic explanation for the origin of the neutron dripline shows that nuclei accommodate the addition of neutrons by becoming increasingly ellipsoidal, up to a maximum number of neutrons, reconciling theory and experiments.

heading: No pulsed radio emission during a bursting phase of a Galactic magnetar
description: An 8-hour radio observational campaign of the Galactic magnetar SGR 1935+2154, assisted by multi-wavelength data, indicates that associations between fast radio bursts and soft γ-ray bursts are rare.

heading: A fast radio burst associated with a Galactic magnetar
authors: C. D. BochenekV. RaviD. L. McKenna
description: Observations of the fast radio burst FRB 200428 coinciding with X-rays from the Galactic magnetar SGR 1935+2154 indicate that active magnetars can produce fast radio bursts at extragalactic distances.

heading: Catalytic asymmetric addition of an amine N–H bond across internal alkenes
description: Hydroamination with high enantio- and regioselectivity is achieved across a wide range of internal alkenes by using a cationic iridium complex that adds an ammonia surrogate containing a pyridine group.

heading: Repeated cross-sectional sero-monitoring of SARS-CoV-2 in New York City
description: Seropositive samples of SARS-CoV-2 were detected as early as mid-February in patients at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, and antibody positivity increased during the first wave of the pandemic and remained stable afterwards.

heading: Age-specific mortality and immunity patterns of SARS-CoV-2
authors: Megan O’DriscollGabriel Ribeiro Dos SantosHenrik Salje
description: The relative risk of COVID-19-associated death for younger individuals (under 65) is consistent across countries and can be used to robustly compare the underlying number of infections in each country.

heading: Values encoded in orbitofrontal cortex are causally related to economic choices
description: Direct electrical stimulation of the brain in rhesus monkeys (Macaca mulatta) predictably varied subjective valuation and choices, linking valuation and economic decision making to the orbitofrontal cortex.

heading: 150 million years of sustained increase in pterosaur flight efficiency
description: Phylogenetic statistical analyses, biophysical models and information from the fossil record show that an evolutionary signal of natural selection acted to increase the flight efficiency of pterosaurs over millions of years.

heading: Metal-free photoinduced C(sp3)–H borylation of alkanes
description: Metal-free borylation of C(sp3)–H bonds by violet-light-induced hydrogen atom transfer is reported, demonstrating high selectivity for the substitution of methyl C–H bonds over other weaker C–H bonds.

heading: Contrasting signatures of genomic divergence during sympatric speciation
authors: Andreas F. KauttClaudius F. KratochwilAxel Meyer
description: Population genomic analyses of Midas cichlid fishes in young Nicaraguan crater lakes suggest that sympatric speciation is promoted by polygenic architectures.

heading: Identification of SARS-CoV-2 inhibitors using lung and colonic organoids
description: The use of lung and colonic organoid systems to assess the susceptibility of lung and gut cells to SARS-CoV-2 and to screen FDA-approved drugs that have antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2 is demonstrated.

heading: Tunable dynamics of B cell selection in gut germinal centres
authors: Carla R. NowosadLuka MesinGabriel D. Victora
description: Antibody selection and maturation within B cells found in gut-associated germinal centres is stimulated by the gut microbiota, to a degree that depends on the presence and composition of the microbes.

heading: Large Chinese land carbon sink estimated from atmospheric carbon dioxide data
description: Newly available atmospheric carbon dioxide measurements from six sites across China during 2009 to 2016 indicate a larger land carbon sink than previously thought, reflecting increased afforestation.

heading: High-depth African genomes inform human migration and health
description: Whole-genome sequencing analyses of African populations provide insights into continental migration, gene flow and the response to human disease, highlighting the importance of including diverse populations in genomic analyses to understand human ancestry and improve health.

heading: Enteric neurons increase maternal food intake during reproduction
description: A multi-organ circuit is activated in female flies after mating, leading to changes in enteric neurons that increase food intake.

heading: Memory failure predicted by attention lapsing and media multitasking
authors: Kevin P. MadoreAnna M. KhazenzonAnthony D. Wagner
description: Lapses in attention before remembering partially account for why we remember or forget in the moment, why some individuals remember better than others, and why heavier media multitasking is related to worse memory.

heading: The landscape of RNA Pol II binding reveals a stepwise transition during ZGA
description: Binding of RNA polymerase II during zygotic genome activation in mouse embryos is determined using the newly developed method Stacc–seq.

heading: Efficient epoxidation over dinuclear sites in titanium silicalite-1
description: A combination of spectroscopy, microscopy and theoretical calculations shows that the reactivity of titanium silicalite-1 as an epoxidation catalyst is due to the presence of dinuclear titanium sites.

heading: Site-specific RNA methylation by a methyltransferase ribozyme
authors: Carolin P. M. ScheitlMohammad Ghaem MaghamiClaudia Höbartner
description: A methyltransferase ribozyme, along with the small-molecule cofactor O6-methylguanine, is shown to catalyse the site-specific installation of 1-methyladenosine in various RNAs, providing insights into the catalytic abilities of RNA.

heading: Exuberant fibroblast activity compromises lung function via ADAMTS4
authors: David F. BoydE. Kaitlynn AllenPaul G. Thomas
description: Viral infection of the respiratory system induces exuberant fibroblast activity, resulting in extensive remodelling of the extracellular matrix and cytokine release, which promote immune cell infiltration of the affected area at the expense of respiratory function.

heading: Single-cell mutation analysis of clonal evolution in myeloid malignancies
authors: Linde A. MilesRobert L. BowmanRoss L. Levine
description: The evolution of myeloid malignancies is investigated using combined single-cell sequencing and immunophenotypic analysis.

heading: Diverse polarization angle swings from a repeating fast radio burst source
description: Polarization observations of the fast radio burst FRB 180301 with the FAST radio telescope show diverse polarization angle swings, consistent with a magnetospheric origin of the emission.

heading: The Philae lander reveals low-strength primitive ice inside cometary boulders
description: When the Philae lander bounced on the surface of comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko, it exposed primitive icy-dust material within cometary boulders; the intrinsic strength and porosity of this material is reported.

heading: Parallel ascending spinal pathways for affective touch and pain
description: Two populations of neurons with distinct anatomy and receptor expression that convey information from the spinal cord to the brain have different functional properties with respect to touch and pain.

heading: High-throughput calculations of magnetic topological materials
description: High-throughput calculations are performed to predict approximately 130 magnetic topological materials, with complete electronic structure calculations and topological phase diagrams.

heading: Macrophage-derived glutamine boosts satellite cells and muscle regeneration
description: Mouse models of muscle injuries and ageing characterized by low levels of intra-tissue glutamine are ameliorated by macrophage-specific deletion or systemic pharmacological inhibition of glutamate dehydrogenase 1, which results in constitutively high activity of glutamine synthetase.

heading: snRNA-seq reveals a subpopulation of adipocytes that regulates thermogenesis
description: Single-nucleus RNA sequencing in mouse and human adipose tissue identifies a subpopulation of adipocytes that regulates thermogenesis in neighbouring adipocytes in a paracrine manner by modulating acetate signalling.

heading: Spike mutation D614G alters SARS-CoV-2 fitness
description: The SARS-CoV-2 variant expressing spike(D641G) shows increased infectivity in human lung epithelial cells and in hamster and primary human upper airway tissues, but is more susceptible to neutralization by antibodies raised against SARS-CoV-2.

heading: High sensitivity of tropical precipitation to local sea surface temperature
description: The response of tropical precipitation to variation in sea surface temperature is stronger than in most climate models, with cool and warm ocean regions linked by strong shallow atmospheric circulations.

heading: Bennu’s near-Earth lifetime of 1.75 million years inferred from craters on its boulders
authors: R.-L. BallouzK. J. WalshD. S. Lauretta
description: Analysis of the size and depth of craters on boulders on the asteroid (101955) Bennu indicates that Bennu has been in near-Earth space for 1.75 ± 0.75 million years.

heading: Reply to: Methods matter in repeating ocean acidification studies
authors: Timothy D. ClarkGraham D. RabyJosefin Sundin

heading: Methods matter in repeating ocean acidification studies
authors: Philip L. MundayDanielle L. DixsonSue-Ann Watson

heading: A pooled testing strategy for identifying SARS-CoV-2 at low prevalence
description: A mathematical algorithm for population-wide screening of SARS-CoV-2 infections using pooled parallel RT–PCR tests requires considerably fewer tests than individual testing procedures and has minimal delays in the identification of individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2.

heading: Epigenetic therapy induces transcription of inverted SINEs and ADAR1 dependency
authors: Parinaz MehdipourSajid A. MarhonDaniel D. De Carvalho
description: Inverted-repeat Alu elements are the main source of drug-induced immunogenic double-stranded RNAs, which are destabilized by the RNA deaminase ADAR1, thereby limiting activation of the immune response.

heading: Cas9 gene therapy for Angelman syndrome traps Ube3a-ATS long non-coding RNA
authors: Justin M. WolterHanqian MaoMark J. Zylka
description: Genomic integration of an adeno-associated virus vector in a mouse model of Angelman syndrome unsilences paternal Ube3a and rescues anatomical and behavioural phenotypes, suggesting a pathway towards the treatment of this neurodevelopmental disorder.

heading: Integrated optical multi-ion quantum logic
authors: Karan K. MehtaChi ZhangJonathan P. Home
description: Scalable optics co-fabricated with a cryogenic surface-electrode ion trap are used to drive high-fidelity multi-ion quantum logic gates, demonstrating a route to simultaneously scale and reduce errors in quantum processors.

heading: Equilibrium between nascent and parental MCM proteins protects replicating genomes
description: Mother cells recycle parental MCMs and simultaneously synthesize nascent MCMs, both of which are inherited by daughter cells, in which the former are preferentially used to form active replisomes and the latter adjust the pace of replisome movement to minimize errors during DNA replication.

heading: Atomic-resolution protein structure determination by cryo-EM
description: Advances in electron cryo-microscopy allow the structure of apoferritin to be determined at a resolution that enables the visualization of individual atoms.

heading: Single-particle cryo-EM at atomic resolution
authors: Takanori NakaneAbhay KotechaSjors H. W. Scheres
description: Advances in electron cryo-microscopy hardware allow proteins to be studied at atomic resolution.

heading: TGF-β suppresses type 2 immunity to cancer
description: Depletion of transforming growth factor-β receptor 2 (TGFBR2) in CD4+ T cells results in IL-4-dependent vascular remodelling, stopping tumour growth in a transgenic mouse model of breast cancer, suggesting that type 2 immunity could be targeted for cancer treatments.

heading: DNA mismatches reveal conformational penalties in protein–DNA recognition
description: A high-throughput assay that introduces mismatched base pairs into the DNA sequence shows that mismatches can increase transcription factor binding affinity by prepaying some of the energetic cost of distorting the DNA.

heading: Integrated multi-wavelength control of an ion qubit
description: A surface-electrode ion-trap chip is demonstrated, which delivers all the wavelengths of light required for the preparation and operation of ion qubits.

heading: Cancer immunotherapy via targeted TGF-β signalling blockade in TH cells
description: 4T-Trap, a bispecific molecule designed to recognize CD4 and bind TGF-β, blocks TGF-β signalling in T helper cells, causing interleukin-4-dependent vascular reorganization and cancer cell death in a mouse model of breast cancer.

heading: Exome sequencing and characterization of 49,960 individuals in the UK Biobank
authors: Cristopher V. Van HoutIoanna TachmazidouAris Baras
description: Exome sequences from the first 49,960 participants in the UK Biobank highlight the promise of genome sequencing in large population-based studies and are now accessible to the scientific community.

heading: Stellar clustering shapes the architecture of planetary systems
authors: Andrew J. WinterJ. M. Diederik KruijssenMélanie Chevance
description: The architecture of planetary systems is shown to be strongly affected by stellar clustering in position-velocity phase space; hot Jupiters occur preferentially at high density, suggesting that their extreme orbits originate from environmental perturbations.

heading: Toughening mechanisms of the elytra of the diabolical ironclad beetle
description: A jigsaw-style configuration of interlocking structures identified in the elytra of the remarkably tough diabolical ironclad beetle, Phloeodes diabolicus, is used to inspire crush-resistant multilayer composites for engineering joints.

heading: Immune receptor inhibition through enforced phosphatase recruitment
authors: Ricardo A. FernandesLeon SuK. Christopher Garcia
description: A approach termed ‘receptor inhibition by phosphatase recruitment’ is described for attenuating both tonic and ligand-activated cell-surface receptor signalling.

heading: Seismic evidence for partial melt below tectonic plates
description: Analysis of global three-dimensional shear attenuation and velocity models implies that partial melting in the seismic low-velocity zone enables motion of oceanic plates by reducing the viscosity of the asthenosphere.

heading: Reply to: Transparency and reproducibility in artificial intelligence
Transparency and reproducibility in artificial intelligence
authors: Benjamin Haibe-KainsGeorge Alexandru AdamHugo J. W. L. Aerts

heading: Global priority areas for ecosystem restoration
authors: Bernardo B. N. StrassburgAlvaro IribarremPiero Visconti
description: Multicriteria optimization identifies global priority areas for ecosystem restoration and estimates their benefits for biodiversity and climate, providing cost–benefit analyses that highlight the importance of optimizing spatial planning and incorporating several biomes in restoration strategies.

heading: PIEZO2 in sensory neurons and urothelial cells coordinates urination
description: PIEZO2 is expressed in the bladder urothelium and sensory neurons innervating the lower urinary tract and is a key mechanosensor for the control of urination.

heading: H i 21-centimetre emission from an ensemble of galaxies at an average redshift of one
description: Emission from atomic hydrogen at a wavelength of 21 centimetres had been observed from galaxies at a maximum redshift of 0.4, but is now reported at a redshift of about 1.

heading: RETRACTED ARTICLE: Room-temperature superconductivity in a carbonaceous sulfur hydride
description:
Room-temperature superconductivity is observed in a photochemically
                synthesized ternary carbonaceous sulfur hydride system at 15 °C and 267 GPa.

heading: The cellular basis of distinct thirst modalities
description: The authors uncover the diverse transcriptomic cell types of thirst-driving neurons in the lamina terminalis and show that unique combinations of neuron types respond to and mediate distinct thirst states.

heading: The NAD+-mediated self-inhibition mechanism of pro-neurodegenerative SARM1
description: NAD+ is shown to be a ligand of the armadillo/heat repeat motifs (ARM) domain of SARM1, and it is suggested that this binding of NAD+ mediates self-inhibition of SARM1.

heading: Dense and pleiotropic regulatory information in a developmental enhancer
description: A robotic pipeline is used to survey a library of mutations in a Drosphila gene enhancer, showing that most mutations altered gene expression and had widespread pleiotropic effects that are likely to constrain regulatory evolution.

heading: Surface coordination layer passivates oxidation of copper
description: High oxidation resistance, without degradation of thermal or electrical conductivity, is achieved in copper using surface modification by a solvothermal or electrochemical treatment with sodium formate and formation of a thin surface coordination layer.

heading: Inherited causes of clonal haematopoiesis in 97,691 whole genomes
authors: Alexander G. BickJoshua S. WeinstockPradeep Natarajan
description: Analysis of 97,691 high-coverage human blood DNA-derived whole-genome sequences enabled simultaneous identification of germline and somatic mutations that predispose individuals to clonal expansion of haematopoietic stem cells, indicating that both inherited and acquired mutations are linked to age-related cancers and coronary heart disease.

heading: An unexpectedly large count of trees in the West African Sahara and Sahel
description: Deep learning was used to map the crown sizes of each tree in the West African Sahara, Sahel and sub-humid zone using submetre-resolution satellite imagery, revealing a relatively high density of trees in arid areas.

heading: Efficient and stable blue quantum dot light-emitting diode
description: Cadmium-free blue quantum dot light-emitting diodes are constructed with a quantum yield of unity, an efficiency at the theoretical limit, high brightness and long operational lifetime.

heading: RAD51-dependent recruitment of TERRA lncRNA to telomeres through R-loops
description: Telomeric-repeat-containing RNA is recruited to telomeres by a mechanism that involves the DNA recombinase RAD51 and the formation of DNA–RNA hybrids, or R-loops—a process similar to that involved in homology-directed DNA repair.

heading: A system hierarchy for brain-inspired computing
description: The concept of neuromorphic completeness and a system hierarchy for neuromorphic computing are presented, which could improve programming-language portability, hardware completeness and compilation feasibility of brain-inspired computing systems

heading: Capillary cell-type specialization in the alveolus
description: Single-cell analysis of blood vessels in the alveolus, the site of chronic disease and virus-induced lung injury, reveals two intermingled endothelial cell types with specialized gas exchange and stem cell functions.

heading: Inherited myeloproliferative neoplasm risk affects haematopoietic stem cells
authors: Erik L. BaoSatish K. NandakumarVijay G. Sankaran
description: A genome-wide association study identifies 17 genetic loci that are associated with the risk of myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), and shows that the modulation of haematopoietic stem cell function drives MPN risk.

heading: Building cratonic keels in Precambrian plate tectonics
authors: A. L. PerchukT. V. GeryaW. L. Griffin
description: Modelling reveals how thick diamondiferous continental mantle ‘keels’ were formed only at increased mantle temperatures when the melt-depleted, hot, ductile mantle located under subducting oceanic plates flowed backwards, underplating the continents.

heading: Cell-type-specific 3D epigenomes in the developing human cortex
description: Analysis of cis-regulatory chromatin interactions, open chromatin and transcriptomes for different cell types isolated from mid-gestational human cortex samples provides insights into gene regulation during development.

heading: Evidence for 28 genetic disorders discovered by combining healthcare and research data
description: By integrating healthcare and exome-sequencing data from parent–offspring trios of patients with developmental disorders, 28 genes that had not previously been associated with developmental disorders were identified.

heading: Mechanism of strand exchange from RecA–DNA synaptic and D-loop structures
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the bacterial recombination protein RecA with DNA, and of RecA–D-loop complexes, provide insights into the double-stranded DNA opening, homology search and strand-exchange processes of homologous recombination.

heading: Computational planning of the synthesis of complex natural products
description: A synthetic route-planning algorithm, augmented with causal relationships that allow it to strategize over multiple steps, can design complex natural-product syntheses that are indistinguishable from those designed by human experts.

heading: SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibody structures inform therapeutic strategies
authors: Christopher O. BarnesClaudia A. JettePamela J. Bjorkman
description: Eight structures of human neutralizing antibodies that target the SARS-CoV-2 spike receptor-binding domain are reported and classified into four categories, suggesting combinations for clinical use.

heading: Fc-optimized antibodies elicit CD8 immunity to viral respiratory infection
description: An antibody Fc domain variant with enhanced binding to an activating Fc receptor on dendritic cells promotes the induction of a protective CD8 T cell response.

heading: Innate and plastic mechanisms for maternal behaviour in auditory cortex
authors: Jennifer K. SchiavoSilvana ValtchevaRobert C. Froemke
description: The onset of maternal behaviour in mice involves an interaction between intrinsic tuning of auditory cortical neurons and experience-dependent plasticity.

heading: Relatives of rubella virus in diverse mammals
authors: Andrew J. BennettAdrian C. PaskeyTony L. Goldberg
description: Ruhugu virus and rustrela virus are the first close relatives of rubella virus, providing insights into the zoonotic origin of rubella virus and the epidemiology and evolution of all three viruses.

heading: A STAT3 palmitoylation cycle promotes TH17 differentiation and colitis
description: The dynamic and reversible S-palmitoylation of the transcription factor STAT3 enhances its activation and promotes the differentiation of TH17 cells.

heading: Environmental drivers of megafauna and hominin extinction in Southeast Asia
description: Stable isotope data for Southeast Asian mammals across the Quaternary period shed light on environmental change from the Early Pleistocene to the Holocene epoch, contextualizing hominin evolution and megafauna extinction in the region.

heading: The genomic landscapes of individual melanocytes from human skin
description: A combination of clonal expansion and DNA amplification is used to sequence genetic material from individual melanocytes, shedding light on the mutational landscape of these cells and the development of melanomas.

heading: eIF2α controls memory consolidation via excitatory and somatostatin neurons
description: Stimulation of de novo protein synthesis in both excitatory and inhibitory, somatostatin-expressing neurons in the mouse hippocampus enhances memory consolidation.

heading: Phenotypic landscape of intestinal organoid regeneration
description: An organoid-based screening platform maps the genetic interactions underlying intestinal development and regeneration, showing that retinoic acid metabolism maintains the balance between regeneration and homeostasis, and that an antagonist of the retinoid X receptor promotes regeneration in vivo.

heading: Emergent electromagnetic induction in a helical-spin magnet
description: Microscale magnetic devices containing nanoscale spin helices produce an inductance comparable in magnitude to that of a commercial inductor, in a volume about a million times smaller.

heading: Microglia-organized scar-free spinal cord repair in neonatal mice
description: In neonatal mice, scar-free healing after spinal cord injury is organized by microglia, and transplantation of neonatal microglia or peptidase-inhibitor-treated adult microglia into adult mice after injury improves healing and axon regrowth.

heading: Spontaneous travelling cortical waves gate perception in behaving primates
authors: Zachary W. DavisLyle MullerJohn H. Reynolds
description: Timing and position of spontaneously arising waves of activity in the visual cortex predict the sensitivity of visual perception in awake, behaving marmosets (Callithrix jacchus).

heading: Four annular structures in a protostellar disk less than 500,000 years old
authors: Dominique M. Segura-CoxAnika SchmiedekeRobert J. Harris
description: Dust-emission observations of the young (<500,000 years old) protostar IRS 63 show evidence of rings and gaps in its disk, a prerequisite of planet formation.

heading: A comprehensive quantification of global nitrous oxide sources and sinks
description: Bottom-up and top-down approaches are used to quantify global nitrous oxide sources and sinks resulting from both natural and anthropogenic sources, revealing a 30% increase in global human-induced emissions between 1980 and 2016.

heading: Amygdala inhibitory neurons as loci for translation in emotional memories
description: Protein synthesis is required in distinct populations of inhibitory neurons in the mouse amygdala to store memories of danger and safety.

heading: The major genetic risk factor for severe COVID-19 is inherited from Neanderthals
description: Risk of severe COVID-19 is conferred by a genomic segment that is inherited from Neanderthals and is carried by around 50% and 16% of people in south Asia and Europe, respectively.

heading: Reevaluating bipedalism in Danuvius
authors: Scott A. WilliamsThomas C. PrangLiza J. Shapiro

heading: Reply to: Reevaluating bipedalism in Danuvius
Innovations present in the primate interneuron repertoire
authors: Fenna M. KrienenMelissa GoldmanSteven A. McCarroll
description: Single-nucleus RNA-sequencing analyses of brain from humans, macaques, marmosets, mice and ferrets reveal diverse ways that interneuron populations have changed during evolution.

heading: An enzymatic Alder-ene reaction
description: Analysis of two homologous groups of fungal pericyclases demonstrates how they can catalyse either an Alder-ene reaction—which has not previously been found in nature—or a hetero-Diels–Alder reaction.

heading: Concentric liquid reactors for chemical synthesis and separation
description: In a rotating reactor, immiscible or pairwise-immiscible liquids organize into stable but internally agitated concentric layers, enabling multistep syntheses and separations of reaction mixtures.

heading: Active particles induce large shape deformations in giant lipid vesicles
description: Experiments and simulations show that local non-equilibrium forces exerted by self-propelled particles trapped inside a giant unilamellar lipid vesicle induce dramatic shape changes in the vesicle.

heading: Tumoural activation of TLR3–SLIT2 axis in endothelium drives metastasis
description: Expression of the axon-guidance gene Slit2 in endothelium, induced by endothelial sensing of tumour-derived double-stranded RNA, promotes metastatic dissemination in mouse models of breast and lung cancer.

heading: COVID-19 vaccine BNT162b1 elicits human antibody and TH1 T cell responses
description: In a phase I/II dose-escalation clinical trial, the mRNA COVID-19 vaccine BNT162b1 elicits specific T cell and antibody responses that suggest it has protective potential.

heading: Bolometer operating at the threshold for circuit quantum electrodynamics
description: A thermal detector based on a graphene monolayer operates at the threshold for circuit quantum electrodynamics applications, achieving a minimum time constant of 200 ns.

heading: A single bacterial genus maintains root growth in a complex microbiome
authors: Omri M. FinkelIsai Salas-GonzálezJeffery L. Dangl
description: Experiments using an ecologically realistic 185-member bacterial synthetic community in the root system of Arabidopsis reveal that Variovorax bacteria can influence plant hormone levels to reverse the inhibitory effect of the community on root growth.

heading: Repeat expansions confer WRN dependence in microsatellite-unstable cancers
description: In cells with microsatellite instability, expanded TA-dinucleotide repeats form cruciform structures that stall replication forks and cause chromosome shattering in the absence of the WRN helicase.

heading: Structural basis for pH gating of the two-pore domain K+ channel TASK2
authors: Baobin LiRobert A. RietmeijerStephen G. Brohawn
description: The authors report on the structure of the K+ channel TASK2 and how this channel opens in response to pH changes on either side of the cell membrane.

heading: Rate of mass loss from the Greenland Ice Sheet will exceed Holocene values this century
authors: Jason P. BrinerJoshua K. CuzzoneSophie Nowicki
description: Rates of ice-mass loss from southwestern Greenland this century will exceed the maximum rate over the past 12,000 years, and would not be the result of natural variation.

heading: Graphene-based Josephson junction microwave bolometer
authors: Gil-Ho LeeDmitri K. EfetovKin Chung Fong
description: An ultimately thin microwave bolometric sensor based on a superconductor–graphene–superconductor Josephson junction with monolayer graphene has a sensitivity approaching the fundamental limit imposed by intrinsic thermal fluctuations.

heading: A hypothalamic novelty signal modulates hippocampal memory
description: The supramammillary nucleus in the hypothalamus acts as a novelty hub that selectively directs different types of novelty signals to different subregions of the hippocampus and flexibly modulates the encoding of memory.

heading: Negative feedback control of neuronal activity by microglia
description: Microglia, the brain’s immune cells, suppress neuronal activity in response to synaptic ATP release and alter behavioural responses in mice.

heading: Cells of the adult human heart
description: Single-cell and single-nucleus RNA sequencing are used to construct a cellular atlas of the human heart that will aid further research into cardiac physiology and disease.

heading: Integration of innate immune signalling by caspase-8 cleavage of N4BP1
authors: Alexander D. GitlinKlaus HegerVishva M. Dixit
description: NEDD4-binding protein 1 (N4BP1) is identified as a suppressor of cytokine production that is inactivated by caspase-8, which provides insight into the mechanisms underlying the immunodeficiency caused by mutations in FADD and caspase-8.

heading: Third-order nanocircuit elements for neuromorphic engineering
description: Electrophysical processes are used to create third-order nanoscale circuit elements, and these are used to realize a transistorless network that can perform Boolean operations and find solutions to a computationally hard graph-partitioning problem.

heading: Reply to: Zebrafish prrx1a mutants have normal hearts
authors: Noemi CastroviejoOscar H. OcañaM. Angela Nieto

heading: Zebrafish prrx1a mutants have normal hearts
authors: Federico TessadoriDennis E. M. de BakkerJeroen Bakkers

heading: Conformation of sister chromatids in the replicated human genome
description: Modified chromosome conformation capture (Hi-C) technology is used to characterize the interactions between sister chromatids, despite their identical DNA sequences.

heading: Light-driven post-translational installation of reactive protein side chains
description: A wide range of side chains are installed into proteins by addition of photogenerated alkyl or difluroalkyl radicals, providing access to new functionality and reactivity in proteins.

heading: The hysteresis of the Antarctic Ice Sheet
description: Modelling shows that the Antarctic Ice Sheet exhibits multiple temperature thresholds beyond which ice loss would become irreversible, and once melted, the ice sheet can regain its previous mass only if the climate cools well below pre-industrial temperatures.

heading: Functional genomic landscape of cancer-intrinsic evasion of killing by T cells
authors: Keith A. LawsonCristovão M. SousaJason Moffat
description: Genome-wide CRISPR screens in mouse cancer cell lines are used to identify a core, conserved set of genes and pathways that govern how cancer cells evade killing by cytotoxic T lymphocytes.

heading: Hippocampal CA2 sharp-wave ripples reactivate and promote social memory
description: Social memory is consolidated in the brain through the reactivation of neuronal firing by sharp-wave ripples in the CA2 region of the hippocampus, in a similar way to the consolidation of spatial memory.

heading: Colloidal diamond
authors: Mingxin HeJohnathon P. GalesDavid J. Pine
description: Self-assembly of cubic diamond crystals is demonstrated, by using precursor clusters of particles with carefully placed ‘sticky’ patches that attract and bind adjacent clusters in specific geometries.

heading: Local exposure to inequality raises support of people of low wealth for taxing the wealthy
description: Local exposure to inequality in low-income areas is positively associated with support for a tax on wealthier individuals to address economic disparities.

heading: Structure of nucleosome-bound DNA methyltransferases DNMT3A and DNMT3B
description: Catalytically inactive DNMT3B3 is crucial in de novo CpG methylation of DNA, interacting with the nucleosome core to orient catalytically active DNMT3A2 so that it can bind to nearby linker DNA.

heading: Fractional antiferromagnetic skyrmion lattice induced by anisotropic couplings
description: Theoretically predicted fractional antiferromagnetic skyrmions are experimentally realized in MnSc2S4 and are found to originate from anisotropic couplings over nearest neighbours in the crystal lattice.

heading: Initiation of a conserved trophectoderm program in human, cow and mouse embryos
description: Comparative analysis of human, cow and mouse embryos shows that a mechanism involving atypical protein kinase C initiates the trophectoderm program during the morula stage in these three species.

heading: Synthetic group A streptogramin antibiotics that overcome Vat resistance
description: Modular synthesis and structural biology are used to design and characterize group A streptogramin antibiotics, one of which has activity against streptogramin-resistant strains and demonstrates efficacy in a mouse model of bacterial infection.

heading: Mapping carbon accumulation potential from global natural forest regrowth
authors: Susan C. Cook-PattonSara M. LeavittBronson W. Griscom
description: A one-kilometre-resolution map of aboveground carbon accumulation rates of forest regrowth shows 100-fold variation across the globe, with rates 32% higher on average than IPCC estimates.

heading: The maternal microbiome modulates fetal neurodevelopment in mice
authors: Helen E. VuongGeoffrey N. PronovostElaine Y. Hsiao
description: Small molecules that arise from the maternal gut microbiome in pregnant dams promote fetal thalamocortical axonogenesis in their offspring.

heading: Modulating TRADD to restore cellular homeostasis and inhibit apoptosis
description: The adaptor protein TRADD is a regulator of both cellular homeostasis and apoptosis, and represents a potential therapeutic target for human diseases.

heading: Shared yet dissociable neural codes across eye gaze, valence and expectation
description: The primate amygdala contains a shared neural circuitry for eye gaze and for valence; however, this circuitry implements two different neural codes—one for the outcome and another for the expectation of the outcome.

heading: Near-perfect photon utilization in an air-bridge thermophotovoltaic cell
description: An air gap embedded within the structure of a thermophotovoltaic device acts as a near-perfect reflector of low-energy photons, resulting in their recovery and recycling by the thermal source, enabling excellent power-conversion efficiency.

heading: Receptor binding and priming of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 for membrane fusion
authors: Donald J. BentonAntoni G. WrobelSteven J. Gamblin
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of consecutive binding events of ACE2 in complex with the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 reveal the mechanisms of receptor binding by the spike protein and activation for membrane fusion by the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2.

heading: Slow compression of crystalline ice at low temperature
Plasmonic enhancement of stability and brightness in organic light-emitting devices
authors: Michael A. FusellaRenata SaramakJulia J. Brown
description: Plasmonic effects in organic light-emitting devices, which are normally considered a source of energy loss, are harnessed to enhance the stability of these devices while maintaining operational efficiency.

heading: Prokaryotic viperins produce diverse antiviral molecules
description: Eukaryotic viperins originated from a clade of bacterial and archaeal proteins that catalyse the production of antiviral molecules.

heading: Reprogramming roadmap reveals route to human induced trophoblast stem cells
authors: Xiaodong LiuJohn F. OuyangJose M. Polo
description: Single-cell transcriptomics roadmap of human dermal fibroblasts reprogrammed to primed and naive pluripotency reveals a route for the direct reprogramming of somatic cells into induced trophoblast stem cells.

heading: Homeostatic mini-intestines through scaffold-guided organoid morphogenesis
description: Miniature gut tubes grown in vitro from mouse intestinal stem cells are perfusable, can be colonized with microorganisms and exhibit a similar arrangement and diversity of specialized cell types to intestines in vivo.

heading: Deep posteromedial cortical rhythm in dissociation
description: Dissociative states in mouse and human brains are traced to low-frequency rhythmic neural activity—with distinct molecular, cellular and physiological properties—in the deep retrosplenial cortex and the posteromedial cortex.

heading: Population genomics of the Viking world
description: Ancient DNA analyses reveal that Viking Age migrations from Scandinavia resulted in differential influxes of ancestry to different parts of Europe, and the increased presence of non-local ancestry within Scandinavia.

heading: Metabolic trait diversity shapes marine biogeography
description: A tight coupling between metabolic rate, efficacy of oxygen supply and the temperature sensitivities of marine animals predicts a variety of geographical niches that better aligns with the distributions of species than models of either temperature or oxygen alone.

heading: A submicrometre silicon-on-insulator resonator for ultrasound detection
description: The widely available silicon-on-insulator technology is used to develop a miniaturized ultrasound detector, which is 200 times smaller than the wavelengths of sound that it can detect.

heading: Bridging of DNA breaks activates PARP2–HPF1 to modify chromatin
description: The PARP2–HPF1 histone-modifying complex bridges two nucleosomes to align broken DNA ends for ligation, initiating conformational changes that activate PARP2 and enable DNA damage repair.

heading: Plasticity of ether lipids promotes ferroptosis susceptibility and evasion
authors: Yilong ZouWhitney S. HenryStuart L. Schreiber
description: The cellular organelles peroxisomes contribute to the sensitivity of cells to ferroptosis by synthesizing polyunsaturated ether phospholipids, and changes in the abundances of these lipids are associated with altered sensitivity to ferroptosis during cell-state transitions.

heading: Stimulus-specific hypothalamic encoding of a persistent defensive state
authors: Ann KennedyPrabhat S. KunwarDavid J. Anderson
description: Persistent neural activity in the mouse hypothalamus encodes aversive emotional states related to specific threatening stimuli.

heading: The superconducting quasicharge qubit
authors: Ivan V. PechenezhskiyRaymond A. MenciaVladimir E. Manucharyan
description: A fundamental superconducting qubit is introduced: ‘blochnium’ is dual to the transmon, relies on a circuit element called hyperinductance, and its fundamental physical variable is the quasicharge of the Josephson junction.

heading: Reverse and forward engineering of Drosophila corneal nanocoatings
description: The building blocks of the nanostructures observed on Drosophila corneas are determined, and then used to create artificial nanostructures with anti-reflective and anti-adhesive properties.

heading: Red blood cell tension protects against severe malaria in the Dantu blood group
authors: Silvia N. KariukiAlejandro Marin-MenendezJulian C. Rayner
description: The rare blood group Dantu is known to protect against severe malaria, and a mechanism is proposed here: Dantu red blood cells have a high membrane tension that prevents invasion by malaria parasites.

heading: A giant planet candidate transiting a white dwarf
description: A giant planet candidate roughly the size of Jupiter but more than 14 times as massive is observed by TESS and other instruments to be transiting the white dwarf star WD 1856+534.

heading: Evolution of the endothelin pathway drove neural crest cell diversification
authors: Tyler A. SquareDavid JandzikDaniel M. Medeiros
description: CRISPR–Cas9-mediated disruption of the endothelin-signalling pathway in the sea lamprey Petromyzon marinus and the frog Xenopus laevis were used to delineate ancient and lineage-specific roles of endothelin signalling and provide insights into vertebrate evolution.

heading: Structural basis for the action of the drug trametinib at KSR-bound MEK
authors: Zaigham M. KhanAlexander M. RealArvin C. Dar
description: Crystal structures of the MEK kinase bound to the scaffold protein KSR and various MEK inhibitors, including the anti-cancer drug trametinib, reveal the molecular and functional mechanisms behind MEK inhibition.

heading: Structural mechanism of cGAS inhibition by the nucleosome
description: Using cryo-electron microscopy, the authors determine the structure of cGAS bound to nucleosomes and present evidence for the mechanism by which nucleosome binding to cGAS prevents cGAS dimerization and its binding to free double-stranded DNA.

heading: Bending the curve of terrestrial biodiversity needs an integrated strategy
description: To promote the recovery of the currently declining global trends in terrestrial biodiversity, increases in both the extent of land under conservation management and the sustainability of the global food system from farm to fork are required.

heading: The molecular basis of tight nuclear tethering and inactivation of cGAS
description: Structural studies show that cyclic GMP–AMP synthase binds to nucleosomes through its DNA-binding site, which maintains it in an inactive conformation and prevents self-DNA binding.

heading: Structural basis for sequestration and autoinhibition of cGAS by chromatin
authors: Sebastian MichalskiCarina C. de Oliveira MannKarl-Peter Hopfner
description: Biochemical and structural analyses show how tethering of the nucleotidyltransferase cGAS to chromatin prevents autoimmune recognition of nuclear DNA.

heading: Evidence for supercritical behaviour of high-pressure liquid hydrogen
description: Simulations using machine-learning-based interatomic potentials in dense hydrogen overcome system size and timescale limitations, providing evidence of a supercritical behaviour of high-pressure liquid hydrogen and reconciling theoretical and experimental discrepancies.

heading: Experimental deterministic correction of qubit loss
description: A deterministic correction of errors caused by qubit loss or leakage outside the computational space is demonstrated in a trapped-ion experiment by using a minimal instance of the topological surface code.

heading: The coding capacity of SARS-CoV-2
