description: Excitation to the second excited state of 229Th is used to populate the metastable state 229mTh, enabling accurate determination of the isomer’s energy, half-life and excitation linewidth.

heading: The fundamental role of chromatin loop extrusion in physiological V(D)J recombination
description: V(D)J recombination in B cells involves cohesin-mediated extrusion of chromatin loops to present DNA targets for cleavage and joining.

heading: Energy of the 229Th nuclear clock transition
authors: Benedict SeiferleLars von der WensePeter G. Thirolf
description: The transition energy of the first excited state of 229Th to the ground state is determined through the measurement of internal conversion electrons to correspond to a wavelength of 149.7 ± 3.1 nanometres.

heading: Electrochemically reconfigurable architected materials
description: Architected silicon-based lattices are reported that reversibly transform their structure on electrochemical lithiation and delithiation, through cooperatively coupled buckling instabilities that are sensitive to random  and  pre-designed defects.

heading: Anthropogenic biases in chemical reaction data hinder exploratory inorganic synthesis
description: Human scientists make unrepresentative chemical reagent and reaction condition choices, and machine-learning algorithms trained on human-selected experiments are less capable of successfully predicting reaction outcomes than those trained on randomly generated experiments.

heading: Genome architecture and stability in the Saccharomyces cerevisiae knockout collection
description: Whole-genome sequencing of the strains of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae gene-knockout collection reveals the effects of the deletion of non-essential genes on genome stability.

heading: Cleavage of RIPK1 by caspase-8 is crucial for limiting apoptosis and necroptosis
authors: Kim NewtonKatherine E. WickliffeVishva M. Dixit
description: Caspase-8 suppresses apoptosis and necroptosis in embryonic mice by cleaving RIPK1.

heading: Early Pleistocene enamel proteome from Dmanisi resolves Stephanorhinus phylogeny
description: Palaeoproteomic analysis of dental enamel from an Early Pleistocene Stephanorhinus resolves the phylogeny of Eurasian Rhinocerotidae, by enabling the reconstruction of molecular evolution beyond the limits of ancient DNA preservation.

heading: SLC19A1 transports immunoreactive cyclic dinucleotides
authors: Rutger D. LuteijnShivam A. ZaverDavid H. Raulet
description: A genome-wide CRISPR-interference screen is used to identify the reduced folate carrier SLC19A1 as the major transporter of cyclic dinucleotides in human cells, with potential roles in immunotherapeutic treatment of cancer, immune responses to pathogens and inflammatory diseases.

heading: Targeting cardiac fibrosis with engineered T cells
description: Adoptive transfer of CAR T cells against the fibroblast marker FAP reduces cardiac fibrosis and restores function after cardiac injury in mice, providing proof-of-principle for the development of immunotherapeutic treatments for cardiac disease.

heading: Hindered dialkyl ether synthesis with electrogenerated carbocations
description: A route to the synthesis of hindered ethers is developed, in which electrochemical oxidation is used to liberate high-energy carbocations that are then captured by an alcohol.

heading: The low-energy Goldstone mode in a trapped dipolar supersolid
description: Observation of the collective mode responding to the superfluid stiffness—the low-energy Goldstone mode—provides direct evidence for phase rigidity, which is a key signature of supersolidity in an ultracold quantum gas.

heading: Supersolid symmetry breaking from compressional oscillations in a dipolar quantum gas
description: Two distinct compressional oscillation modes are characterized in a dipolar Bose–Einstein condensate; this demonstrates the breaking of two symmetries owing to the coexisting superfluid and crystal properties of a supersolid.

heading: Intrinsically stable organic solar cells under high-intensity illumination
description: Organic photovoltaic cells containing an intrinsically stable organic absorber layer that are likely to be stable for many decades under illumination are demonstrated.

heading: Information gerrymandering and undemocratic decisions
authors: Alexander J. StewartMohsen MoslehJoshua B. Plotkin
description: In a voter game, information gerrymandering can sway the outcome of the vote towards one party, even when both parties have equal sizes and each player has the same influence; and this effect can be exaggerated by strategically placed zealots or automated bots.

heading: Frequent observations of identical onsets of large and small earthquakes
description: Analysis of a dataset of high-sensitivity Tohoku–Hokkaido seismograph records shows that pairs of subduction-type earthquakes of different sizes have very similar initial characteristics, implying that the final size of an earthquake cannot be reliably predicted from these.

heading: Quantum critical behaviour at the many-body localization transition
description: Quantum critical behaviour at the many-body localization transition in a disordered Bose–Hubbard system of bosonic rubidium atoms in an optical lattice is observed, connecting the macroscopic phenomenology of the transition to the system’s microscopic quantum correlations.

heading: Death march of a segmented and trilobate bilaterian elucidates early animal evolution
description: Yilingia spiciformis, a bilaterian dating to the Ediacaran period, is described from body fossils associated with trails produced by the animal, shedding light on the origins of segmentation and motility in bilaterian animals.

heading: Straightforward access to N-trifluoromethyl amides, carbamates, thiocarbamates and ureas
description: N-trifluoromethyl analogues of amides and related carbonyl compounds are prepared via bench-stable carbamoyl fluoride building blocks.

heading: Structural basis of nucleosome recognition and modification by MLL methyltransferases
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of mixed-lineage leukaemia methyltransferases 1 and 3 associated with unmodified or mono-ubiquitinated nucleosome reveal the structural basis for the activity specificity and regulation of these enzymes.

heading: A unified mechanism for intron and exon definition and back-splicing
description: The cryo-electron microscopy structures of an early spliceosome complex in yeast reveal a unified mechanism for defining introns and exons and also for back-splicing to generate circular RNA.

heading: Fast inflows as the adjacent fuel of supermassive black hole accretion disks in quasars
description: Observations of highly redshifted broad absorption lines of helium and hydrogen atoms provide unambiguous evidence of fast infalling gas that is merging into an accretion disk around a black hole.

heading: Structures of influenza A virus RNA polymerase offer insight into viral genome replication
description: Structures of RNA polymerase of human and avian influenza A viruses reveal that the interface of the RNA polymerase dimer is required to initiate viral RNA synthesis in viral genome replication.

heading: E-cadherin is required for metastasis in multiple models of breast cancer
description: Although E-cadherin loss promotes tumour-cell invasion in mouse and human models of invasive ductal carcinoma, E-cadherin expression prevents oxidative-stress-mediated apoptosis during detachment and is essential for metastasis.

heading: Salmonella persisters promote the spread of antibiotic resistance plasmids in the gut
description: The re-seeding of antibiotic-resistant persister subpopulations of Salmonella enterica into the gut lumen favours the transfer of resistance plasmids to gut-resident enterobacteria, showing that even small reservoirs of persister bacteria facilitate the spread of antibiotic resistance.

heading: Maternal vitamin C regulates reprogramming of DNA methylation and germline development
description: The effect of vitamin C deprivation on mouse germline development is analysed, revealing that maternal vitamin C is required for proper DNA demethylation and the development of fetal oocytes, whereas the lack of vitamin C during pregnancy leads to reduced female fecundity in the offspring.

heading: Magnitude of urban heat islands largely explained by climate and population
description: The effect of cities on urban climate (often warmer but sometimes cooler than their surroundings) is largely explained by local hydroclimate and patterns of city development.

heading: Asymmetric lysosome inheritance predicts activation of haematopoietic stem cells
description: The cellular degradative machinery can be asymmetrically inherited upon haematopoietic-stem-cell division, which predicts the future metabolic and translational activation of their daughter cells.

heading: The histone mark H3K36me2 recruits DNMT3A and shapes the intergenic DNA methylation landscape
description: H3K36me2 targets DNMT3A to intergenic regions and this process, together with H3K36me3-mediated recruitment of DNMT3B, has a key role in establishing and maintaining genomic DNA methylation landscapes.

heading: Mediterranean winter rainfall in phase with African monsoons during the past 1.36 million years
description: Comparisons between past regional drivers of precipitation extremes found time series data from Lake Ohrid and modern climate models of the Mediterranean may help to reduce simulation uncertainties in predictions of the Mediterranean climate.

heading: Constraints on global mean sea level during Pliocene warmth
authors: Oana A. DumitruJacqueline AustermannBogdan P. Onac
description: Using phreatic overgrowths on speleothems, sea level during the mid-Piacenzian Warm Period, which was about two to three degrees Celsius warmer than the pre-industrial period, is shown to have been about 16 metres higher than today.

heading: Superconductivity in an infinite-layer nickelate
description: Superconductivity is demonstrated in an infinite-layer nickelate similar to infinite-layer copper oxides, which is synthesized using soft- chemistry topotactic reduction of the perovskite precursor phase.

heading: A 3.8-million-year-old hominin cranium from Woranso-Mille, Ethiopia
authors: Yohannes Haile-SelassieStephanie M. MelilloTimothy M. Ryan
description: Two related studies describe a newly discovered cranium of Australopithecus anamensis, the environment in which this hominin would have lived approximately 3.8 million years ago and how it is related to Australopithecus afarensis.

heading: An actin-based viscoplastic lock ensures progressive body-axis elongation
description: Molecular analysis and mathematical modelling are combined to identify a network of factors that account for viscoplastic deformation in elongation of Caenorhabditis elegans during embryonic development.

heading: Natural selection on the Arabidopsis thaliana genome in present and future climates
description: The predicted increase in frequency of droughts and rising temperatures in Europe will lead core populations of a temperate plant to an evolutionary dead-end unless they acquire genetic alleles that are present only in extreme edge Mediterranean, Scandinavian, or Siberian populations.

heading: Emergence of tissue-like mechanics from fibrous networks confined by close-packed cells
authors: Anne S. G. van OostenXingyu ChenPaul A. Janmey
description: Tissue rheology emerges from the interplay between fibrous networks and cell inclusions, and the mechanical properties of tissues are modulated by restricting the relaxation modes of fibres close to volume-conserving cells.

heading: Efficient molecular doping of polymeric semiconductors driven by anion exchange
description: The limitations of conventional chemical doping of polymeric semiconductors can be overcome by adding a second ionic species into the system, leading to enhanced doping, electrical conductivity and stability.

heading: Structure and mechanism of mitochondrial proton-translocating transhydrogenase
description: The structure of a mammalian proton-translocating transhydrogenase in various conformations is solved by cryo-electron microscopy, and a mechanism for the coupling process within the enzyme is proposed.

heading: Metastatic-niche labelling reveals parenchymal cells with stem features
description: A cell-penetrating fluorescent marker is used to label cells in the metastatic tumour microenvironment, revealing a variety of cell types including parenchymal cells with lung stem-cell characteristics.

heading: Age and context of mid-Pliocene hominin cranium from Woranso-Mille, Ethiopia
description: Two related studies describe a newly discovered cranium of Australopithecus anamensis, the environment in which this hominin would have lived approximately 3.8 million years ago and how it is related to Australopithecus afarensis.

heading: The flight response impairs cytoprotective mechanisms by activating the insulin pathway
authors: María José De RosaTania VeutheyMark J. Alkema
description: The release of tyramine during the flight response in nematodes activates the DAF-2/insulin–IGF pathway to downregulate cytoprotective mechanisms and shorten lifespan.

heading: Fatty acids and cancer-amplified ZDHHC19 promote STAT3 activation through S-palmitoylation
description: The palmitoylation of STAT3 is mediated by fatty acids and/or the palmitoyl acyltransferase ZDHHC19, and deregulation of this palmitoylation has a role in inflammation and tumorigenesis.

heading: Changing climate both increases and decreases European river floods
description: Analysis of a comprehensive European flood dataset reveals regional changes in river flood discharges in the past five decades that are consistent with models suggesting that climate-driven changes are already happening.

heading: Temporal plasticity of apical progenitors in the developing mouse neocortex
description: In the brains of embryonic mice, some types of progenitor (apical progenitors) can revert to earlier molecular, electrophysiological and neurogenic states when transplanted into younger hosts, whereas others cannot, highlighting progenitor-type-specific differences in fate plasticity.

heading: Structural basis of assembly of the human T cell receptor–CD3 complex
description: A high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human octameric T cell receptor–CD3 complex, including the complete extracellular and transmembrane domains, reveals the structural basis for TCR–CD3 assembly and provides insights into T cell receptor activation.

heading: Modern microprocessor built from complementary carbon nanotube transistors
description: A 16-bit microprocessor built from over 14,000 carbon nanotube transistors may enable energy efficiency advances in electronics technologies beyond silicon.

heading: Hidden resilience and adaptive dynamics of the global online hate ecology
description: The dynamics of interactions between hate-orientated networks on different online platforms is characterized, and a mathematical model predicts that policing on one online platform can make matters worse and generate ‘darker’ parts of the Internet.

heading: BCAA catabolism in brown fat controls energy homeostasis through SLC25A44
description: The solute carrier transporter protein SLC25A44 regulates uptake of branched-chain amino acids in mitochondria of brown adipose tissue in which they are utilized for thermogenesis.

heading: Force-induced conformational changes in PIEZO1
description: Cryo-electron microscopy and high-speed atomic force microscopy reveal that PIEZO1 can reversibly deform its shape towards a planar structure, which may explain how the PIEZO1 channel is gated in response to mechanical stimulation.

heading: Increasing wildfires threaten historic carbon sink of boreal forest soils
authors: Xanthe J. WalkerJennifer L. BaltzerMichelle C. Mack
description: Soil radiocarbon dating reveals that combusted ‘legacy carbon’—soil carbon that escaped burning during previous fires—could shift the carbon balance of boreal ecosystems, resulting in a positive climate feedback.

heading: Quantifying inactive lithium in lithium metal batteries
description: Titration gas chromatography is developed as an analytical method of distinguishing between lithium metal and lithium compounds within a cycled battery and assessing the amount of unreacted metallic lithium available.

heading: Microbiota-derived lantibiotic restores resistance against vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus
authors: Sohn G. KimSimone BecattiniEric G. Pamer
description: The gut commensal Blautia producta secretes a lantibiotic that reduces colonization of the gut by the major pathogen vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium, and transplantation of microbiota with high abundance of the lantibiotic gene enhances resistance to colonization in mice.

heading: Mechanosensation of cyclical force by PIEZO1 is essential for innate immunity
authors: Angel G. SolisPiotr BieleckiRichard A. Flavell
description: PIEZO1 signalling mediates activation of a proinflammatory response to cyclical pressure fluctuations in immune cells.

heading: Structure and mechanogating of the mammalian tactile channel PIEZO2
description: The cryo-electron microscopy structure of mouse PIEZO2 is determined and compared to that of PIEZO1, providing insights into the potential gating mechanisms of these mechanosensitive ion channels.

heading: Ionic-surfactant-mediated electro-dewetting for digital microfluidics
description: A method of droplet manipulation is described that uses electrical signals to induce the liquid to dewet, rather than wet, a hydrophilic conductive surface.

heading: DEAD-box ATPases are global regulators of phase-separated organelles
description: RNA-dependent DEAD-box ATPases (DDXs) regulate the dynamics of phase-separated organelles, with ATP-bound DDXs promoting phase separation, and ATP hydrolysis inducing compartment disassembly and RNA release.

heading: Identification of an ATP-sensitive potassium channel in mitochondria
description: The pore-forming and ATP-binding subunits of a mitochondrial protein complex that mediates ATP-dependent potassium currents are identified and characterized, revealing the role of this channel in mitochondrial physiology and pathologies.

heading: Reconstituting the transcriptome and DNA methylome landscapes of human implantation
description: Transcriptomics and DNA methylomics are used to study the implantation process of human embryos at single-cell resolution.

heading: Electron pairing in the pseudogap state revealed by shot noise in copper oxide junctions
description: Shot-noise measurements in copper oxides reveal paired charge carriers existing in the pseudogap above the superconducting critical temperature, shedding light on the properties of high-temperature superconductivity in these materials.

heading: Conserved cell types with divergent features in human versus mouse cortex
authors: Rebecca D. HodgeTrygve E. BakkenEd S. Lein
description: RNA-sequencing analysis of cells in the human cortex enabled identification of diverse cell types, revealing well-conserved architecture and homologous cell types as well as extensive differences when compared with datasets covering the analogous region of the mouse brain.

heading: Absence of a thick atmosphere on the terrestrial exoplanet LHS 3844b
authors: Laura KreidbergDaniel D. B. KollRoland Vanderspek
description: Phase curve measurements for the small (1.3 Earth radii) terrestrial exoplanet LHS 3844b show absence of a thick atmosphere, in agreement with theoretical predictions.

heading: Niche stiffness underlies the ageing of central nervous system progenitor cells
description: Aged progenitor cells in the rat central nervous system can be made to behave as young cells by reducing the stiffness of the tissue microenvironment, or by inhibiting the mechanosensitive protein PIEZO1.

heading: Seismic velocities of CaSiO3 perovskite can explain LLSVPs in Earth’s lower mantle
authors: A. R. ThomsonW. A. CrichtonS. A. Hunt
description: Unexpectedly low seismic velocities of CaSiO3 perovskite in deeply subducted oceanic crust can explain the properties of anomalous continent-sized regions in Earth’s lower mantle.

heading: Wnt and TGFβ coordinate growth and patterning to regulate size-dependent behaviour
authors: Christopher P. ArnoldBlair W. Benham-PyleAlejandro Sánchez Alvarado
description: A planarian fission protocol shows that the number of progeny and the frequency of fission initiation correlate with parent size, and TGFβ and Wnt signalling components are identified as regulators of fission behaviour.

heading: Genetic induction and mechanochemical propagation of a morphogenetic wave
description: Tissue shape changes in the posterior endoderm of the early Drosophila embryo are driven by actomyosin contractions emerging from a transcriptional induction followed by a mechanically-driven propagation of RhoI–myosin II activation.

heading: Social dilemmas among unequals
authors: Oliver P. HauserChristian HilbeMartin A. Nowak
description: A framework that includes inequality shows that extreme inequality prevents cooperation, but overall welfare is maximized when endowments and productivities are aligned such that more-productive individuals receive higher endowments.

heading: The decoupled nature of basal metabolic rate and body temperature in endotherm evolution
description: Evolutionary change in basal metabolic rate was not coupled with body temperature across endothermic species, although the mechanism by which birds and mammals adapted to colder environments differed.

heading: Insights into ubiquitin chain architecture using Ub-clipping
authors: Kirby N. SwatekJoanne L. UsherDavid Komander
description: Enzymatic cleavage within ubiquitin molecules followed by quantitative mass-spectrometry simplifies complex ubiquitin chains and enables mapping of polyubiquitin architectures.

heading: Stretchable pumps for soft machines
description: A stretchable polymer pump that uses electric fields to accelerate ions in dielectric liquids can generate flow even when bent into different conformations, offering applications in soft robotics.

heading: Fossil insect eyes shed light on trilobite optics and the arthropod pigment screen
description: Comparing the eyes of crane-fly fossils with those of extant species demonstrates that they contain eumelanic screening pigments and that the lenses are calcified during fossilization, with implications for interpreting optical systems in other extinct arthropods such as trilobites.

heading: Imaging magnetic polarons in the doped Fermi–Hubbard model
description: Magnetic polarons are imaged with single-site spin and density resolution in the low-doping regime of the atomic Fermi–Hubbard model, showing that mobile delocalized doublons are necessary for polaron formation.

heading: The formation of Jupiter’s diluted core by a giant impact
description: An energetic head-on collision between a large impactor and the proto-Jupiter with a primordial compact core could have mixed the heavy elements within the deep interior, leading to a ‘diluted’ core for Jupiter.

heading: Position and momentum mapping of vibrations in graphene nanostructures
description: Investigation of a free-standing graphene monolayer using a technique based on transmission electron microscopy allows identification of atomic vibrations characteristic of the bulk or the edge of the sample.

heading: Metamorphism and the evolution of plate tectonics
authors: Robert M. HolderDaniel R. VieteTim E. Johnson
description: Variability in Earth’s thermal gradients, recorded by metamorphic rocks through time, shows that Earth’s modern plate tectonics developed gradually since the Neoarchaean era, three billion years ago.

heading: Increased shear in the North Atlantic upper-level jet stream over the past four decades
authors: Simon H. LeePaul D. WilliamsThomas H. A. Frame
description: The North Atlantic jet stream has become 15 per cent more sheared in the upper atmosphere since 1979, an expected consequence of climate change, and consistent with increased aircraft turbulence.

heading: Controlling organization and forces in active matter through optically defined boundaries
authors: Tyler D. RossHeun Jin LeeMatt Thomson
description: Light is used to guide the behaviour of an engineered active-matter system, producing structures and properties that can be dynamically manipulated and controlled.

heading: A dominant population of optically invisible massive galaxies in the early Universe
description: Submillimetre-wavelength observations reveal a sample of galaxies that have no detectable emission in the ultraviolet-to-near-infrared region, and are probably the progenitors of the largest present-day galaxies in clusters.

heading: Locally renewing resident synovial macrophages provide a protective barrier for the joint
description: Analysis of macrophage subsets within joints reveals a population of CX3CR1+ tissue-resident macrophages that form a tight-junction-mediated barrier at the synovial lining, protecting the joint from the invasion of inflammatory cells.

heading: Deep roots for mid-ocean-ridge volcanoes revealed by plagioclase-hosted melt inclusions
authors: Emma N. BennettFrances E. JennerC. Johan Lissenberg
description: Volatile contents of plagioclase-hosted melt inclusions from volcanoes at the Gakkel mid-ocean ridge suggest that magmatic crystallization extends to depths of 16 kilometres, much deeper than suggested by olivine-hosted melt inclusions.

heading: Climate change and overfishing increase neurotoxicant in marine predators
authors: Amina T. SchartupColin P. ThackrayElsie M. Sunderland
description: Overfishing and warming ocean temperature have caused an increase in methylmercury concentrations in some Atlantic predatory fish, and this trend is predicted to continue unless stronger mercury and carbon emissions standards are imposed.

heading: Opposing T cell responses in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
description: Activated clonally expanded CD4+ T cells display specificity to the myelin peptide MOG, whereas clonally expanded CD8+ T cells depend on T cell receptor recognition of unrelated surrogate peptides and have a regulatory function.

heading: Collisions between cold molecules in a superconducting magnetic trap
description: Collisions between cold trapped molecules are directly observed by magnetically capturing molecular oxygen in a superconducting trap, without the need for laser cooling.

heading: BORIS promotes chromatin regulatory interactions in treatment-resistant cancer cells
authors: David N. DebruyneRuben DriesRani E. George
description: The CTCF paralogue BORIS is upregulated in transcriptionally reprogrammed neuroblastoma cells rendered resistant to targeted therapy, in which it promotes regulatory chromatin interactions that maintain the resistance phenotype.

heading: Observed controls on resilience of groundwater to climate variability in sub-Saharan Africa
authors: Mark O. CuthbertRichard G. TaylorNeno Kukuric
description: Analysis of multidecadal hydrograph and precipitation data for sub-Saharan Africa shows a complex relationship between groundwater recharge and precipitation, and that a drier climate does not necessarily mean less recharge.

heading: Molecular architecture of lineage allocation and tissue organization in early mouse embryo
description: Spatially resolved transcriptomes of cell populations at defined positions in the early mouse embryo reveal molecular bases of lineage specification and tissue patterning.

heading: A national experiment reveals where a growth mindset improves achievement
authors: David S. YeagerPaul HanselmanCarol S. Dweck
description: A US national experiment showed that a short, online, self-administered growth mindset intervention can increase adolescents’ grades and advanced course-taking, and identified the types of school that were poised to benefit the most.

heading: Pol II phosphorylation regulates a switch between transcriptional and splicing condensates
authors: Yang Eric GuoJohn C. ManteigaRichard A. Young
description: RNA polymerase II with a hypophosphorylated C-terminal domain preferentially incorporates into mediator condensates, and with a hyperphosphorylated C-terminal domain into splicing-factor condensates, revealing phosphorylation as a regulatory mechanism in condensate preference.

heading:
Non-line-of-sight imaging using phasor-field virtual wave
            optics
description:
Algorithms based on diffractive wave propagation of light offer
                effective imaging of complex scenes hidden from direct view.

heading: Reply to: Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
Do not discard Staphylococcus aureus WTA as a vaccine antigen
authors: Rob van DalenMichèle M. MolendijkNina M. van Sorge

heading: Exome sequencing of Finnish isolates enhances rare-variant association power
authors: Adam E. LockeKaryn Meltz SteinbergNelson B. Freimer
description: Exome-wide sequencing studies of populations in Finland identified 26 deleterious alleles associated with 64 quantitative traits that are clinically relevant to cardiovascular and metabolic diseases.

heading: Towards artificial general intelligence with hybrid Tianjic chip architecture
description: The ‘Tianjic’ hybrid electronic chip combines neuroscience-oriented and computer-science-oriented approaches to artificial general intelligence, demonstrated by controlling an unmanned bicycle.

heading: Maximized electron interactions at the magic angle in twisted bilayer graphene
authors: Alexander KerelskyLeo J. McGillyAbhay N. Pasupathy
description: Scanning tunnelling spectroscopy is used to map the atomic-scale electronic structure of magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene, finding multiple signatures of electron correlations and thus providing insight into the sought-after mechanism behind superconductivity in graphene.

heading: Loss of p53 triggers WNT-dependent systemic inflammation to drive breast cancer metastasis
authors: Max D. WellensteinSeth B. CoffeltKarin E. de Visser
description: Loss of p53 in mouse models of breast cancer leads to activation of WNT signalling, which promotes metastatic spread by inducing systemic neutrophilic inflammation.

heading: Cholera toxin promotes pathogen acquisition of host-derived nutrients
description: Cholera toxin selectively promotes the growth of Vibrio cholerae through the acquisition of nutrients, including haem and fatty acids, from the host gut.

heading: Charge order and broken rotational symmetry in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene
description: When scanning tunnelling spectroscopy is used to map the electronic structure of magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene, a pseudogap phase is found, accompanied by a global charge-ordered stripe phase.

heading: Dietary methionine influences therapy in mouse cancer models and alters human metabolism
authors: Xia GaoSydney M. SandersonJason W. Locasale
description: In two patient-derived xenograft models of colorectal cancer and a mouse model of autochthonous soft-tissue sarcoma, dietary restriction of methionine influences the outcome of cancer and interacts with antimetabolite and radiation therapies, through effects on one-carbon metabolism.

heading: CD24 signalling through macrophage Siglec-10 is a target for cancer immunotherapy
authors: Amira A. BarkalRachel E. BrewerIrving L. Weissman
description: CD24 interacts with the tumour-associated-macrophage receptor Siglec-10 to inhibit the macrophage-mediated clearance of cancer cells, revealing a new ‘don’t eat me’ signal as a potential target for cancer immunotherapy.

heading: Plant cell-surface GIPC sphingolipids sense salt to trigger Ca2+ influx
description: The sphingolipid GIPC in the plant cell plasma membrane binds to sodium and triggers calcium influx, thereby triggering responses to excess salt such as efflux of sodium ions from cells.

heading: Human placenta has no microbiome but can contain potential pathogens
authors: Marcus C. de GoffauSusanne LagerGordon C. S. Smith
description: The human placenta does not have a microbiota, suggesting that bacterial infection of the placenta is not a common cause of adverse pregnancy outcome, but group B Streptococcus is found in approximately 5% of placental samples.

heading: A clinically applicable approach to continuous prediction of future acute kidney injury
description: A deep learning approach that predicts the risk of acute kidney injury may help to identify patients at risk of health deterioration within a time window that enables early treatment.

heading: Weak average liquid-cloud-water response to anthropogenic aerosols
description: Satellite data for cloud tracks downwind of major pollution sources show a relatively small global average decrease in cloud water caused by anthropogenic aerosols, invalidating claims that aerosol-induced effects contribute substantially to climate cooling.

heading: Spectroscopic signatures of many-body correlations in magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene
description: Scanning tunnelling spectroscopy and extended-Hubbard-model cluster calculations reveal that magic-angle twisted bilayer graphene is a strongly correlated electron system, similar to other unconventional superconductors.

heading: Lysine harvesting is an antioxidant strategy and triggers underground polyamine metabolism
authors: Viridiana Olin-SandovalJason Shu Lim YuMarkus Ralser
description: The harvest of large quantities of lysine by yeast and other microbes triggers a reprogramming of redox metabolism, in which NADPH is channelled into glutathione metabolism to reduce levels of reactive oxygen species and increase tolerance to oxidative stress.

heading: Structure and mechanism of the cation–chloride cotransporter NKCC1
authors: Thomas A. ChewBenjamin J. OrlandoLiang Feng
description: The cryo-EM structure of the zebrafish cation–chloride cotransporter NKCC1 reveals the domain organization, ion translocation pathway, ion-binding sites and key residues for binding activity, providing insights into the activity of this family of transporter proteins with key roles in physiology.

heading: Giant nonreciprocal second-harmonic generation from antiferromagnetic bilayer CrI3
description: Large second-harmonic generation is observed in antiferromagnetic bilayers of CrI3, providing information about the microscopic origin of layered antiferromagnetism and motivating the use of two-dimensional magnets in nonlinear optical devices.

heading: High performance from extraordinarily thick organic light-emitting diodes
description: Extraordinarily thick organic light-emitting diodes can be fabricated using hybrid organic–inorganic perovskites as the transport layers, thus relaxing fabrication constraints without affecting their efficiency, voltage requirement or durability.

heading: Global entangling gates on arbitrary ion qubits
description: Multi-qubit entangling gates are realized by simultaneously driving multiple motional modes of a linear chain of trapped ions with modulated external fields, achieving a fidelity of about 93 per cent with four qubits.

heading: Flower isoforms promote competitive growth in cancer
description: A cell competition mechanism based on the differential expression of isoforms of Flower proteins is found in humans as well as Drosophila, and promotes tumorigenesis.

heading: A mutation-independent approach for muscular dystrophy via upregulation of a modifier gene
authors: Dwi U. KemaladewiPrabhpreet S. BassiRonald D. Cohn
description: When Lama1 was upregulated using CRISPR and a catalytically inactive Cas9 in a mouse model of congenital muscular dystrophy type 1A, apparent hindlimb paralysis, muscle fibrosis and nerve myelination defects were ameliorated in symptomatic mice.

heading: A strongly inhomogeneous superfluid in an iron-based superconductor
authors: D. ChoK. M. BastiaansM. P. Allan
description: Atomic-resolution imaging of a strongly inhomogeneous superfluid in an iron-based superconductor shows spatial correlation between superfluid density variations and the strength of quasiparticle character.

heading: Parallel entangling operations on a universal ion-trap quantum computer
description: Parallel two-qubit entangling gates are realized in an array of fully connected trapped-ion qubits, achieving a full-adder operation on a quantum processor with an average fidelity of 83.3 per cent.

heading: Single-cell analysis of cardiogenesis reveals basis for organ-level developmental defects
authors: T. Yvanka de SoysaSanjeev S. RanadeDeepak Srivastava
description: Single-cell RNA-sequencing analysis reveals functions of lineage-specifying transcription factors underlying congenital defects in heart development.

heading: Resolving medulloblastoma cellular architecture by single-cell genomics
authors: Volker HovestadtKyle S. SmithPaul A. Northcott
description: Characterization of medulloblastoma tissues using single-cell transcriptomics shows that the different molecular subtypes consist of distinct developmental phenotypes.

heading: Soil nematode abundance and functional group composition at a global scale
authors: Johan van den HoogenStefan GeisenThomas Ward Crowther
description: High-resolution spatial maps of the global abundance of soil nematodes and the composition of functional groups show that soil nematodes are found in higher abundances in sub-Arctic regions, than in temperate or tropical regions.

heading: H+ transport is an integral function of the mitochondrial ADP/ATP carrier
authors: Ambre M. BertholetEdward T. ChouchaniYuriy Kirichok
description: The mitochondrial ADP/ATP carrier mediates the proton leak in mitochondria from all tissues that lack UCP1, thereby linking coupled (ATP production) and uncoupled (thermogenesis) energy conversion.

heading: Modular and tunable biological feedback control using a de novo protein switch
authors: Andrew H. NgTaylor H. NguyenHana El-Samad
description: DegronLOCKR designer-protein technology is used to implement synthetic positive- and negative-feedback systems in the yeast mating pathway as well as feedback control of a synthetic gene circuit.

heading: Global spatial risk assessment of sharks under the footprint of fisheries
authors: Nuno QueirozNicolas E. HumphriesDavid W. Sims
description: A global dataset of the satellite-tracked movements of pelagic sharks and fishing fleets show that sharks—and, in particular, commercially important species—have limited spatial refuge from fishing effort.

heading: De novo design of bioactive protein switches
authors: Robert A. LanganScott E. BoykenDavid Baker
description: A technique for the de novo design of switchable protein systems controlled by induced conformational change is demonstrated for three functional motifs, in vitro and in yeast and mammalian cells.

heading: General relativistic orbital decay in a seven-minute-orbital-period eclipsing binary system
authors: Kevin B. BurdgeMichael W. CoughlinThomas A. Prince
description: Observations of an eclipsing double-white-dwarf binary with an orbital period of 6.91 minutes that is decaying as predicted by general relativity are reported; once launched, the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) should swiftly detect this binary.

heading: Meningeal lymphatic vessels at the skull base drain cerebrospinal fluid
authors: Ji Hoon AhnHyunsoo ChoGou Young Koh
description: Clearance of macromolecules from the cerebrospinal fluid in mice takes place via meningeal lymphatic vessels at the base of the skull; both drainage and the integrity of these vessels deteriorate with age.

heading: No evidence for globally coherent warm and cold periods over the preindustrial Common Era
description: Warm and cold periods over the past 2,000 years have not occurred at the same time in all geographical locations, with the exception of the twentieth century, during which warming has occurred almost everywhere.

heading: Resolving the energy levels of a nanomechanical oscillator
authors: Patricio Arrangoiz-ArriolaE. Alex WollackAmir H. Safavi-Naeini
description: A hybrid platform comprising a microwave superconducting qubit and a nanomechanical piezoelectric oscillator is used to resolve the phonon number states of the oscillator.

heading: Intercellular interaction dictates cancer cell ferroptosis via NF2–YAP signalling
description: Ferroptosis in cancer cells can be regulated by cadherin-mediated intercellular contacts, NF2–Hippo signalling, and activity of the YAP transcription co-activator.

heading: Inhibition of bacterial ubiquitin ligases by SidJ–calmodulin catalysed glutamylation
description: In cells infected with Legionella pneumophila, the pseudo kinase SidJ is activated upon forming a complex with human calmodulin and catalyses glutamylation of SidE ubiquitin ligases, which abolishes the activity of these enzymes.

heading: Potential roles of gut microbiome and metabolites in modulating ALS in mice
description: A study of the functional microbiome in a mouse model of ALS shows that several gut bacteria may modulate the severity of the disease.

heading: Regulation of phosphoribosyl ubiquitination by a calmodulin-dependent glutamylase
description: In Legionella pneumophila, the effector SidJ induces the covalent attachment of glutamate moieties to SdeA in a calmodulin-dependent manner, inhibiting SidE-mediated ubiquitination and regulating pathogenicity.

heading: Quantum-enhanced sensing of a single-ion mechanical oscillator
description: Number-state superpositions of the harmonic motion of a trapped beryllium ion are used to measure the oscillation frequency with quantum-enhanced sensitivity, achieving a mode-frequency uncertainty of about 10−6.

heading: Holistic prediction of enantioselectivity in asymmetric catalysis
description: A workflow for deriving statistical models of one set of reactions that can be used to predict related reactions is presented, facilitating catalyst and enantioselective reaction development.

heading: Signatures of tunable superconductivity in a trilayer graphene moiré superlattice
description: By varying the vertical displacement field in a trilayer graphene and hexagonal boron nitride moiré superlattice, transitions can be observed from the superconducting phase to Mott insulator and metallic phases.

heading: A calmodulin-gated calcium channel links pathogen patterns to plant immunity
description: The cyclic nucleotide-gated channel proteins CNGC2 and CNGC4 form a calcium channel in Arabidopsis; this channel is blocked by calmodulin in the resting state but is phosphorylated and activated upon pathogen attack, triggering an increase in cytosolic calcium levels.

heading: Conformation space of a heterodimeric ABC exporter under turnover conditions
description: Eight cryo-electron microscopy structures of the ATP-binding cassette exporter TmrAB under turnover conditions characterize the entire transport cycle in a lipid environment.

heading: Thermal conductance of single-molecule junctions
description: The thermal conductance of single-molecule junctions is measured using picowatt-resolution calorimetric scanning probes and is found to be nearly independent of the length of the alkanedithiol molecules studied.

heading: Correcting datasets leads to more homogeneous early-twentieth-century sea surface warming
description: Correction of oddities in the historical record of sea surface temperatures reveals that some basin-wide climate variations were an artefact of systematic biases that stem, in part, from Japanese records being truncated to whole numbers when the records were digitized.

heading: Rotation tracking of genome-processing enzymes using DNA origami rotors
description: ORBIT (origami-rotor-based imaging and tracking) is used to track the DNA rotation that results from DNA unwinding by RecBCD helicase and transcription by RNAP at a single-molecule scale and millisecond time resolution.

heading: Giant thermal Hall conductivity in the pseudogap phase of cuprate superconductors
description: The so-called pseudogap phase in hole-doped cuprate superconductors is associated with an unusually large thermal Hall effect that attains unprecedented levels as the parent Mott insulator is approached.

heading: Neuronal vulnerability and multilineage diversity in multiple sclerosis
description: Single-cell RNA sequencing was used to construct a map of gene expression in lesions from brains of patients with multiple sclerosis, revealing distinct lineage- and region-specific transcriptomic changes associated with selective cortical neuron damage and glial activation.

heading: Visualizing electrostatic gating effects in two-dimensional heterostructures
authors: Paul V. NguyenNatalie C. TeutschNeil R. Wilson
description: Changes in the electronic states of two-dimensional semiconductor devices resulting from electrical gating can be monitored directly using micrometre-scale angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy.

heading: Non-photosynthetic predators are sister to red algae
authors: Ryan M. R. GawrylukDenis V. TikhonenkovPatrick J. Keeling
description: Species of the eukaryotic phylum Rhodelphidia are non-photosynthetic, flagellate predators with gene-rich genomes, in contrast to their closely related sister lineage—the red algae—which are immotile, typically photoautotrophic and have relatively small intron-poor genomes and reduced metabolism.

heading: Intestinal infection triggers Parkinson’s disease-like symptoms in Pink1−/− mice
description: In mice lacking PINK1, bacterial infection in the intestine results in mitochondrial antigen presentation and generation of CD8+ T cells, and infected mice develop motor impairments, suggesting that PINK1 suppresses autoimmunity.

heading: Absence of NKG2D ligands defines leukaemia stem cells and mediates their immune evasion
description: Leukaemic stem cells in acute myeloid leukaemia are defined by a lack of expression of NKG2D ligands, which mediates their ability to evade surveillance by NK cells.

heading: A two-qubit gate between phosphorus donor electrons in silicon
authors: Y. HeS. K. GormanM. Y. Simmons
description: A fast, high-fidelity two-qubit exchange gate between phosphorus donor electron spin qubits in silicon is demonstrated by creating a tunable exchange interaction between two electrons bound to phosphorus atom qubits.

heading: Incompatible and sterile insect techniques combined eliminate mosquitoes
description: A field trial succeeded in eliminating populations of the mosquito Aedes albopictus through inundative mass release of incompatible Wolbachia-infected males, which were also irradiated to sterilize any accidentally-released females, and so prevent population replacement.

heading: Activation of PDGF pathway links LMNA mutation to dilated cardiomyopathy
description: A disease model using cardiomyocytes derived from induced pluripotent stem cells of patients with mutated LMNA-related dilated cardiomyopathy reveals that the abnormal activation of the PDGF pathway is associated with the arrhythmic phenotypes of patients.

heading: Elemental signatures of Australopithecus africanus teeth reveal seasonal dietary stress
description: Trace-element analysis of teeth from the hominin Australopithecus africanus, dated to 2.6–2.1 million years ago, sheds light on the weaning sequence of this species and its responses to seasonal food scarcity

heading: Deep hydrous mantle reservoir provides evidence for crustal recycling before 3.3 billion years ago
authors: Alexander V. SobolevEvgeny V. AsafovGary R. Byerly
description: Hydrogen isotopes and compositions of melt inclusions in olivine in komatiites indicate a hydrous source produced by recycling of seawater-altered crust into the deep mantle over 3.3 billion years ago.

heading: Structure and assembly of the mitochondrial membrane remodelling GTPase Mgm1
description: Crystal and electron cryo-tomography structures of Mgm1 from Chaetomium thermophilum reveal that Mgm1 forms bent tetramers, which further assemble into helical filaments on both positively and negatively curved membranes.

heading: Tumour lineage shapes BRCA-mediated phenotypes
description: Analysis of more than 17,000 tumours suggests that the contribution of germline and somatic mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes to oncogenesis depends on tumour lineage.

heading: Designing minimal and scalable insect-inspired multi-locomotion millirobots
description: A ten-gram insect-inspired robot capable of crawling, walking, jumping, somersaulting and performing collective tasks is built from low-cost, assembly-free components, demonstrating its scalability for collective applications with expanded mobility.

heading: Reconstructing the late-accretion history of the Moon
description: Lunar impact simulations find an impactor-retention ratio three times lower than previously thought and indicate that highly siderophile element retention began 4.35 billion years ago, resolving accretion mass discrepancies between Earth and the Moon.

heading: A human liver cell atlas reveals heterogeneity and epithelial progenitors
description: Single-cell RNA sequencing of cells from healthy human liver, hepatocellular carcinoma and chimaeric mouse liver identifies subtypes of liver cells, epithelial progenitors and differences between healthy and diseased cells.

heading: Controlling protein assembly on inorganic crystals through designed protein interfaces
description: The controlled design of arrays of carboxylates geometrically matched to a potassium ion sublattice leads to the formation of extended self-assembled protein structures on mica.

heading: Planar perovskite solar cells with long-term stability using ionic liquid additives
description: Addition of an ionic liquid, BMIMBF4, to metal halide perovskite solar cells improves their efficiency and long-term operation under accelerated aging conditions of high temperature and full-spectrum sunlight.

heading: Comprehensive single-cell transcriptome lineages of a proto-vertebrate
description: Comprehensive single-cell transcriptomes in the proto-vertebrate Ciona intestinalis identified provisional gene networks for 41 different neural subtypes, providing insights into the swimming circuit of tadpoles and the evolution of the vertebrate telencephalon.

heading: Notum produced by Paneth cells attenuates regeneration of aged intestinal epithelium
description: Ageing-associated decline in intestinal stem cell function is mediated by increased Notum, a protein inhibitor of stemness-maintaining Wnt signalling, which is secreted by Paneth cells.

heading: scSLAM-seq reveals core features of transcription dynamics in single cells
authors: Florian ErhardMarisa A. P. BaptistaLars Dölken
description: A technique known as scSLAM-seq that combines single-cell RNA sequencing with metabolic RNA labelling and nucleoside conversion is used to study the onset of cytomegalovirus infection in single mouse fibroblasts.

heading: Peptide ligation by chemoselective aminonitrile coupling in water
description: Prebiotic peptide formation is achieved through chemoselective, high-yielding ligation of α-aminonitriles in water, showing selectivity for α-peptide coupling and tolerance of all proteinogenic amino acid residues.

heading: Mechanisms of RALF peptide perception by a heterotypic receptor complex
description: Uncovering a mechanism of peptide perception by the receptor kinase FER and the LLG1 protein in Arabidopsis thaliana suggests a role for diverse RALF peptides in regulating multiple growth and reproductive processes in plants.

heading: Apidima Cave fossils provide earliest evidence of Homo sapiens in Eurasia
description: Detailed comparative analyses of two fossil crania from Apidima Cave, Greece, indicate that two late Middle Pleistocene human groups were present at this site; first an early Homo sapiens population followed by a Neanderthal population.

heading: Neural signatures of sleep in zebrafish
authors: Louis C. LeungGordon X. WangPhilippe Mourrain
description: Fluorescence-based polysomnography in zebrafish reveals two major sleep signatures that share features with those of amniotes, which suggests that common neural sleep signatures emerged in the vertebrate brain over 450 million years ago.

heading: m6A enhances the phase separation potential of mRNA
authors: Ryan J. RiesSara ZaccaraSamie R. Jaffrey
description: The cytosolic N6-methyladenosine (m6A)-binding proteins YTHDF1, YTHDF2 and YTHDF3 undergo liquid–liquid phase separation in vitro and in cells; this is enhanced by polymethylated mRNAs to form complexes that partition into different cellular phase-separated compartments.

heading: Collective intercellular communication through ultra-fast hydrodynamic trigger waves
authors: Arnold J. T. M. MathijssenJoshua CulverManu Prakash
description: Ultra-fast hydrodynamic communication between cells emerges in colonies of Spirostomum ambiguum through the generation of long-ranged vortex flows that are sensed by neighbouring cells, leading to propagating trigger waves that coordinate the release of toxins.

heading: Nonlinear optics in the fractional quantum Hall regime
description: Nonlinear optical measurements in a two-dimensional electron system embedded in an optical cavity show enhanced polariton–polariton interactions in the fractional quantum Hall regime.

heading: Modulation of cardiac ryanodine receptor 2 by calmodulin
description: The regulatory mechanism through which ryanodine receptor 2 is modulated by calmodulin is revealed through structural determination of ryanodine receptor 2 under eight conditions.

heading: Isomerization of BRCA1–BARD1 promotes replication fork protection
description: BRCA1–BARD1 has a role in replication fork protection that is mediated by a mechanism of phosphorylation-targeted isomerization of BRCA1 and is independent of the canonical interaction between BRCA1 and PALB2.

heading: Unsupervised word embeddings capture latent knowledge from materials science literature
description: Natural language processing algorithms applied to three million materials science abstracts uncover relationships between words, material compositions and properties, and predict potential new thermoelectric materials.

heading: Interacting Floquet polaritons
description: Frequency modulation is used to create ‘Floquet polaritons’—strongly interacting quasi-particles that exist in a customizable set of modes.

heading: Neogene cooling driven by land surface reactivity rather than increased weathering fluxes
authors: Jeremy K. Caves RugensteinDaniel E. IbarraFriedhelm von Blanckenburg
description: A carbon cycle model constrained by weathering-sensitive isotopic tracers reveals that long-term cooling in the Neogene period reflects a change in how surface denudation is partitioned into weathering and erosion.

heading: Whole-animal connectomes of both Caenorhabditis elegans sexes
authors: Steven J. CookTravis A. JarrellScott W. Emmons
description: Quantitative connectivity matrices (or connectomes) for both adult sexes of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans are presented that encompass all connections from sensory input to end-organ output across the entire animal.

heading: Hyperbolic lattices in circuit quantum electrodynamics
authors: Alicia J. KollárMattias FitzpatrickAndrew A. Houck
description: An interconnected network made of superconducting microwave resonators is created as a step towards quantum simulations of interacting particles in hyperbolic space.

heading: Somatic mutations and cell identity linked by Genotyping of Transcriptomes
authors: Anna S. NamKyu-Tae KimDan A. Landau
description: Profiling of over 38,000 CD34+ cells from patients with CALR-mutated myeloproliferative neoplasms, using the ‘Genotyping of Transcriptomes’ procedure, reveals that the transcriptional output of these mutations depends upon native cell identity.

heading: Single-cell analysis reveals T cell infiltration in old neurogenic niches
authors: Ben W. DulkenMatthew T. BuckleyAnne Brunet
description: Single-cell transcriptomic analysis of neurogenic niches in young and old mice reveals that T cells infiltrate the neurogenic niches of old mice and inhibit the proliferation of neural stem cells, in part through expression of interferon-γ.

heading: Insect egg size and shape evolve with ecology but not developmental rate
authors: Samuel H. ChurchSeth DonougheCassandra G. Extavour
description: Analyses of insect eggs as well as genetic and life-history traits of insects show that where eggs are laid, rather than universal allometric constants, developmental rate or adult body size, underlies size and shape evolution.

heading: Sensitization of silicon by singlet exciton fission in tetracene
description: A silicon and tetracene solar cell employing singlet fission uses an eight-angstrom-thick hafnium oxynitride interlayer to promote efficient triplet transfer, increasing the efficiency of the cell.

heading: Magnetic monopole noise
authors: Ritika DusadFranziska K. K. KirschnerJ. C. Séamus Davis
description: Magnetic-flux noise measurements with a SQUID-based spectrometer demonstrate the presence of a magnetic monopole plasma in Dy2Ti2O7.

heading: A fast radio burst localized to a massive galaxy
description: Use of a specially built radio interferometer shows that a non-repeating fast radio burst is localized to a few-arcsecond region containing a single massive galaxy, and is perhaps derived from an old stellar population.

heading: Committed emissions from existing energy infrastructure jeopardize 1.5 °C climate target
description: A comprehensive assessment of ‘committed’ carbon dioxide emissions—from existing and proposed fossil-fuel-based infrastructure—finds that these emissions may exceed the level required to keep global warming within 1.5 degrees Celsius.

heading: Smoothened stimulation by membrane sterols drives Hedgehog pathway activity
description: The crystal structure of active mouse SMO in complex with the SAG21k agonist and a stabilizing intracellular binding nanobody reveals the structural basis of SMO regulation by PTCH1.

heading: Can lasers really refrigerate CdS nanobelts?
Reinvestigation of a robotically revealed reaction
Reply to: Can lasers really refrigerate CdS nanobelts?
Light-wave dynamic control of magnetism
description: The magnetic properties of a ferromagnetic layer stack are controlled on attosecond timescales through optically induced spin and orbital momentum transfer, demonstrating a coherent regime of ultrafast magnetism.

heading: UDP-glucose accelerates SNAI1 mRNA decay and impairs lung cancer metastasis
description: UDP-glucose has a tumour-suppressive role by inhibiting the association between HuR and SNAI1 mRNA, whereas UGDH-mediated metabolism of UDP-glucose leads to increased SNAI1 mRNA stability and expression, thereby promoting tumour cell migration and lung cancer metastasis.

heading: FOXA1 mutations alter pioneering activity, differentiation and prostate cancer phenotypes
authors: Elizabeth J. AdamsWouter R. KarthausCharles L. Sawyers
description: Mutations in the transcription factor FOXA1 that are common in prostate cancer result in gain-of-function effects that promote changes in the differentiation of tumour cells.

heading: Observing crystal nucleation in four dimensions using atomic electron tomography
description: Atomic electron tomography captures crystal nucleation in four dimensions in FePt nanoparticles, with the observed early-stage nucleation not consistent with classical nucleation theory.

heading: Conformational transitions of a neurotensin receptor 1–Gi1 complex
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of human neurotensin receptor 1 in complex with Gi1 protein and the agonist JMV449 reveal a non-canonical state that may represent an intermediate form in G-protein activation.

heading: Structure and autoregulation of a P4-ATPase lipid flippase
description: Cryo-EM structures of the yeast P4-ATPase Drs2p–Cdc50p in three different states of activation provide insights into the function of this lipid flippase, including mechanisms of autoinhibition and PI4P-dependent activation.

heading: RETRACTED ARTICLE: Living annulative π-extension polymerization for graphene nanoribbon synthesis
description: A solution-based living annulative π-extension polymerization technique produces graphene nanoribbons with simultaneous control over their length, width and edges, resulting in the synthesis of graphene nanoribbon block copolymers.

heading: Untethered flight of an insect-sized flapping-wing microscale aerial vehicle
authors: Noah T. JafferisE. Farrell HelblingRobert J. Wood
description: Sustained flight of an insect-sized flapping-wing aerial vehicle weighing just 259 milligrams that does not need to fly tethered to an off-board power supply is demonstrated.

heading: Distinct structural classes of activating FOXA1 alterations in advanced prostate cancer
description: Comprehensive genomic analyses and mechanistic studies uncover three structural, functional and clinical classes of activating FOXA1 mutations and locus rearrangements in prostate cancer.

heading: Developmental dynamics of lncRNAs across mammalian organs and species
description: A transcriptome dataset from seven organs and seven mammalian species throughout development is used to analyse the expression of long noncoding RNAs in tissues within and between species, and at different stages of organ development.

heading: Gene expression across mammalian organ development
description: The transcriptomes of seven major organs across developmental stages from several mammalian species are used for comparative analyses of gene expression and evolution across organ development.

heading: Stationary entangled radiation from micromechanical motion
authors: S. BarzanjehE. S. RedchenkoJ. M. Fink
description: A parametrically driven 30-micrometre-long silicon nanostring oscillator emits stationary path-entangled microwave radiation, squeezing the joint field operators of two thermal modes by 3.4 decibels below the vacuum level.

heading: Foot callus thickness does not trade off protection for tactile sensitivity during walking
authors: Nicholas B. HolowkaBert WynandsDaniel E. Lieberman
description: People who frequently walk barefoot have thicker and harder calluses than those who typically use footwear; however, in contrast to shoes, callus thickness does not trade-off protection for the ability to perceive tactile stimuli during walking.

heading: Immune evasion before tumour invasion in early lung squamous carcinogenesis
description: The immune response is modulated at a early stage of carcinogenesis, such that both immune activation and evasion precede tumour invasion.

heading: High-dimensional geometry of population responses in visual cortex
description: Analysis of the encoding of natural images by very large populations of neurons in the visual cortex of awake mice characterizes the high dimensional geometry of the neural responses.

heading: Tracking the precession of single nuclear spins by weak measurements
authors: K. S. CujiaJ. M. BossC. L. Degen
description: Periodic weak measurements of just a few carbon-13 nuclear spins in diamond demonstrate sensitive, high-resolution nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy at the molecular level.

heading: Reply to: Egg pigmentation probably has an Archosaurian origin
Mitochondrial fission requires DRP1 but not dynamins
Egg pigmentation probably has an early Archosaurian origin
Perfect Andreev reflection due to the Klein paradox in a topological superconducting state
description: Perfect transmission of electrons through a finite potential barrier between a normal metal and a topological superconducting state is demonstrated, as evidenced by an exact doubling of conductance in point contact measurements.

heading: Location-level processes drive the establishment of alien bird populations worldwide
authors: David W. ReddingAlex L. PigotTim M. Blackburn
description: Bayesian hierarchical regression analysis of a global database of bird introduction events reveals the environmental, climatic and biotic factors that are the primary determinants of the successful establishment of populations of alien species.

heading: Noncoding deletions reveal a gene that is critical for intestinal function
description: An intestine-critical region on human chromosome 16, and its regulation of PERCC1, a newly identified gene, is shown to underlie the genetic basis of a severe, inherited form of diarrhoea.

heading: Enhanced intrinsic photovoltaic effect in tungsten disulfide nanotubes
description: A bulk photovoltaic effect is observed in devices based on tungsten disulfide, and is enhanced if the devices take the form of polar nanotubes, showing the importance of reducing crystal symmetry to a polar structure in achieving higher efficiencies.

heading: Helical van der Waals crystals with discretized Eshelby twist
description: Experiments demonstrate a class of van der Waals nanowires, made from layered crystals of the semiconductor germanium sulfide, in which a tunable interlayer twist evolves naturally during synthesis.

heading: Genetic analyses of diverse populations improves discovery for complex traits
authors: Genevieve L. WojcikMariaelisa GraffChristopher S. Carlson
description: Genetic analyses of ancestrally diverse populations show evidence of heterogeneity across ancestries and provide insights into clinical implications, highlighting the importance of including ancestrally diverse populations to maximize genetic discovery and reduce health disparities.

heading: Large-scale chemical–genetics yields new M. tuberculosis inhibitor classes
authors: Eachan O. JohnsonEmily LaVerriereDeborah T. Hung
description: A high-throughput chemical–genetic screening approach for the discovery of targets and chemicals to treat Mycobacterium tuberculosis yields tenfold more hit compounds than conventional whole-cell screening methods.

heading: Electrolytic vascular systems for energy-dense robots
authors: Cameron A. AubinSnehashis ChoudhuryRobert F. Shepherd
description: An energy-dense hydraulic fluid is used to construct a synthetic circulatory system in a lionfish-like soft robot, enabling untethered movement for up to 36 hours.

heading: Structural colour using organized microfibrillation in glassy polymer films
authors: Masateru M. ItoAndrew H. GibbonsEasan Sivaniah
description: Standing-wave optics can be used to control microfibril and cavity formation in polymer films and the resulting porous layered structures can produce tunable structural colour, enabling inkless ‘printing’ of images.

heading: Machine learning in electronic-quantum-matter imaging experiments
description: A machine-learning approach is used to train artificial neural networks to analyse experimental scanning tunnelling microscopy image arrays of quantum materials.

heading: Turbulent convective length scale in planetary cores
description: Numerical modelling of rotating turbulent convective flows shows that the length scale of convection in planetary cores is set by the flow speed and not by the fluid viscosity.

heading: Distinct modes of mitochondrial metabolism uncouple T cell differentiation and function
authors: Will BailisJustin A. ShyerRichard A. Flavell
description: Genetic, pharmacological and metabolomics experiments reveal that the malate–aspartate shuttle and mitochondrial citrate export support the differentiation of mouse T helper 1 cells, whereas succinate dehydrogenase enforces their terminal effector function.

heading: National food production stabilized by crop diversity
description: A greater diversity of crops at the national level increases the temporal stability of total national harvest, reflecting markedly lower frequencies of years with sharp harvest losses.

heading: A universal biomolecular integral feedback controller for robust perfect adaptation
description: A synthetic gene circuit implementing an integral feedback topology is shown to achieve robust perfect adaptation in living cells--mathematical analysis proves this topology is necessary for adaptation in networks with noisy dynamics.

heading: TOX is a critical regulator of tumour-specific T cell differentiation
description: The nuclear factor TOX is highly expressed in antigen-specific dysfunctional T cells in tumours and exhausted T cells during chronic viral infection and is a crucial regulator of the differentiation of tumour-specific T cells.

heading: RETRACTED ARTICLE: Global analysis of streamflow response to forest management
description: Analysis of forest-management studies finds that forest removal is more likely to increase streamflow in areas with greater water storage between the surface and bedrock, and that forest planting is more likely to decrease streamflow in drier climates.

heading: TOX reinforces the phenotype and longevity of exhausted T cells in chronic viral infection
description: TOX is a critical factor for the normal progression of T cell dysfunction and the maintenance of exhausted T cells during chronic infections.

heading: TOX transcriptionally and epigenetically programs CD8+ T cell exhaustion
authors: Omar KhanJosephine R. GilesE. John Wherry
description: The transcription factor TOX is a central regulator of the transcriptional and epigenetic development of exhausted T cells.

heading: Evidence for two blue (type IIb) diamond populations
45.5-tesla direct-current magnetic field generated with a high-temperature superconducting magnet
description: A copper oxide high-temperature superconductor magnet generates a direct-current magnetic field of 45.5 tesla—the highest value reported so far—using a design that enables operation at high current densities.

heading: Reply to: Evidence for two blue (type IIb) diamond populations
authors: Evan M. SmithSteven B. ShireyWuyi Wang

heading: Migrant memory B cells secrete luminal antibody in the vagina
description: In a mouse model of herpes simplex 2 virus infection, circulating memory B cells—rather than plasma cells—are shown to be the source of antibody secretion in the vaginal lumen following secondary infection.

heading: Mineral protection regulates long-term global preservation of natural organic carbon
authors: Jordon D. HemingwayDaniel H. RothmanValier V. Galy
description: Broadening activation energy distributions and increasing radiocarbon ages reveal the global importance of mineral protection in promoting organic carbon preservation.

heading: Climate as a risk factor for armed conflict
authors: Katharine J. MachCaroline M. KraanNina von Uexkull
description: Climate has affected organized armed conflict within countries, and intensifying climate change is estimated to increase future risks of conflict, although other drivers are substantially more influential and the mechanisms of climate–conflict linkages remain uncertain.

heading: Pluripotency and the origin of animal multicellularity
authors: Shunsuke SogabeWilliam L. HatlebergBernard M. Degnan
description: Comparison of transcriptomes, cell fates and behaviour of three primary cell types from the sponge Amphimedon queenslandica with choanoflagellates and other unicellular holozoans suggests that the first animal cells transitioned between multiple states.

heading: Structural mechanism for NEK7-licensed activation of NLRP3 inflammasome
description: A cryo-electron microscopy structure of human NLRP3 in complex with the mitotic kinase NEK7 provides insights into the interactions that mediate the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome.

heading: Isotopic constraint on the twentieth-century increase in tropospheric ozone
authors: Laurence Y. YeungLee. T. MurrayJérôme Chappellaz
description: Isotope data from polar firn and ice are used to constrain the increase in tropospheric ozone between 1850 and 2005 ad.

heading: Spin–orbit-driven band inversion in bilayer graphene by the van der Waals proximity effect
authors: J. O. IslandX. CuiA. F. Young
description: By enhancing the spin–orbit coupling in bilayer graphene using the proximity effect in a van der Waals heterostructure, band inversion occurs and an incompressible, gapped phase is produced.

heading: Hydraulic control of mammalian embryo size and cell fate
description: A mouse blastocyst model reveals how lumenal pressure, cell cortical tension and tissue stiffness act at the tissue scale to regulate embryo size, which in turn influences the division pattern of trophectoderm cells and their fate specification.

heading: Transposon-encoded CRISPR–Cas systems direct RNA-guided DNA integration
authors: Sanne E. KlompePhuc L. H. VoSamuel H. Sternberg
description: A programmable transposase integrates donor DNA at user-defined genomic target sites with high fidelity, revealing a new approach for genetic engineering that obviates the need for DNA double-strand breaks and homologous recombination.

heading: Atypical behaviour and connectivity in SHANK3-mutant macaques
description: The CRISPR–Cas9-mediated generation of germline-transmissible mutations of SHANK3 in cynomolgus macaques (Macaca fascicularis) forms the basis of a non-human-primate model of autism spectrum disorder and Phelan–McDermid syndrome.

heading: Structure and function of Vms1 and Arb1 in RQC and mitochondrial proteome homeostasis
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the yeast 60S ribosomal subunit in complex with Vms1 provides insights into the roles of proteins in the ribosome-associated quality control pathway.

heading: Antarctic offshore polynyas linked to Southern Hemisphere climate anomalies
authors: Ethan C. CampbellEarle A. WilsonLynne D. Talley
description: Measurements collected during recent polynya events in the Southern Ocean reveal that these sea ice openings formed as a result of weakened stratification and severe storms and were sustained by deep overturning.

heading: Off-target RNA mutation induced by DNA base editing and its elimination by mutagenesis
description: Cytosine and adenine base editors have undesired off-target effects on RNA, but this activity can be reduced in deaminase-engineered variants while preserving on-target DNA editing.

heading: Uncertainties in tropical-cyclone translation speed
Mating preferences of selfish sex chromosomes
description: Population genetic modelling shows that mate preferences encoded on sex chromosomes can drive the evolution of extremely male-costly traits.

heading: Measurability of pressure inside the proton
A cool accretion disk around the Galactic Centre black hole
authors: Elena M. MurchikovaE. Sterl PhinneyRoger D. Blandford
description: Emission from the 1.3-millimetre hydrogen recombination line reveals a rotating disk of cool gas 0.004 parsecs in radius around the supermassive black hole at the centre of our Galaxy.

heading: Reply to: Moon, I.-J. et al.; Lanzante, J. R.
Climate change and tropical cyclone trend
authors: Il-Ju MoonSung-Hun KimJohnny C. L. Chan

heading: Magnetism in cold subducting slabs at mantle transition zone depths
description: Synchrotron Mössbauer source spectroscopy is used to reveal that haematite remains magnetic in cold subducting slabs at the depth of the transition zone in the Earth’s mantle, with implications for the locations of magnetic poles during inversions of the Earth’s magnetic field.

heading: Hypersonic Bose–Einstein condensates in accelerator rings
description: Bose–Einstein condensates are transported at hypersonic speeds over a distance of 15 cm in a neutral-atom accelerator ring while preserving their internal coherence.

heading: Group 3 innate lymphoid cells mediate early protective immunity against tuberculosis
description: Group 3 innate lymphoid cells are recruited to the lung and involved in the immune response to infection with tuberculosis in humans and mice, as a reduction in group 3 innate lymphoid cells in the lung impaired early immune control of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in mice.

heading: Predator-induced collapse of niche structure and species coexistence
authors: Robert M. PringleTyler R. KartzinelRowan D. H. Barrett
description: Whole-ecosystem manipulations of Caribbean islands occupied by brown anoles, involving the addition of competitors (green anoles) and/or top predators (curly-tailed lizards), demonstrate that predator introductions can alter the ecological niches and destabilize the coexistence of competing prey species.

heading: Palaeo-Eskimo genetic ancestry and the peopling of Chukotka and North America
description: DNA analysis of ancient individuals and modern populations suggests that the population history of North America can be explained by the admixture of two ancestral lineages—Palaeo-Eskimos and First Peoples.

heading: Cryo-EM structure of oxysterol-bound human Smoothened coupled to a heterotrimeric Gi
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structure of the human Smoothened protein bound to 24(S),25-epoxycholesterol and a heterotrimeric Gi protein provides insights into the activation of a Frizzled-class G-protein-coupled receptor and Hedgehog signal transduction.

heading: Freestanding crystalline oxide perovskites down to the monolayer limit
description: Ultrathin freestanding crystalline films of transition-metal oxide perovskites are fabricated and transferred to various substrates, proving their potential for exploring emergent 2D correlated phases.

heading: De novo protein design by citizen scientists
description: Proteins designed de novo by players of the online protein-folding game Foldit can be expressed in Escherichia coli and adopt the designed structure in solution.

heading: The population history of northeastern Siberia since the Pleistocene
description: Analyses of 34 ancient genomes from northeastern Siberia, dating to between 31,000 and 600 years ago, reveal at least three major migration events in the late Pleistocene population history of the region.

heading: Surface erosion events controlled the evolution of plate tectonics on Earth
description: The rise of continents and the accumulation of sediments in trenches since about three billion years ago has had a crucial role in the emergence and evolution of plate tectonics on Earth.

heading: Selective triplet exciton formation in a single molecule
description: Recombination of excitons to produce molecular light emission is made more efficient by controlling electron spin within the molecule to produce spin-triplet excitons only, without the usual accompanying spin-singlet excitons.

heading: Individual brain organoids reproducibly form cell diversity of the human cerebral cortex
description: Single-cell RNA-sequencing analysis demonstrates that individual human brain organoids generate the cellular diversity of the cerebral cortex with organoid-to-organoid variability that is comparable to that of individual endogenous brains.

heading: Heterochromatin drives compartmentalization of inverted and conventional nuclei
description: Attractions between heterochromatic regions are essential for phase separation of the active and inactive genome in inverted and conventional nuclei, whereas chromatin–lamina interactions are necessary to build the conventional genomic architecture from these segregated phases.

heading: Mapping human microbiome drug metabolism by gut bacteria and their genes
description: High-throughput genetic analyses combined with mass spectrometry reveal that the gene products of diverse human gut bacteria affect a wide range of oral drugs, as well as drug metabolism in mice.

heading: To catch and reverse a quantum jump mid-flight
