description: Clonal genetic tracing is used to demonstrate that, in mice, longitudinal bone growth during fetal and neonatal periods relies on the gradual consumption of chondroprogenitors, whereas in adults, a stem cell niche is formed allowing renewing of chondroprogenitors and leading to formation of large, stable monoclonal columns of chondrocytes.

heading: Structural basis for KCTD-mediated rapid desensitization of GABAB signalling
description: X-ray crystallography, electron microscopy and functional experiments reveal the details of how KCTD proteins interact with GABAB receptors and desensitize G-protein-coupled inwardly rectifying potassium channels.

heading: Social parasitism as an alternative reproductive tactic in a cooperatively breeding cuckoo
description: Mixed-effects logistic regression modelling of a dataset of individual reproductive behaviours shows fitness pay-offs of cooperative versus mixed cooperative and parasitic reproductive strategies are approximately equal in female greater anis (Crotophaga major).

heading: Proteomics identifies new therapeutic targets of early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma
description: A subtype of early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by disrupted cholesterol homeostasis and associated with a poor prognosis responds to treatment with the SOAT1 inhibitor avasimibe in a patient-derived xenograft mouse model.

heading: Colouration by total internal reflection and interference at microscale concave interfaces
authors: Amy E. GoodlingSara NagelbergLauren D. Zarzar
description: A mechanism for creating patterns of iridescent structural colour by total internal reflection of light beams along a concave optical interface leading to interference is described, for complex microscopic systems and for systems as simple as condensed water drops.

heading: Observation of moiré excitons in WSe2/WS2 heterostructure superlattices
description: Moiré superlattice exciton states are observed in WSe2/WS2 heterostructures with closely aligned layers.

heading: Evidence for moiré excitons in van der Waals heterostructures
description: Multiple interlayer exciton resonances in a MoSe2/WSe2 heterobilayer with a small twist angle are attributed to excitonic ground and excited states confined within the moiré potential.

heading: Signatures of moiré-trapped valley excitons in MoSe2/WSe2 heterobilayers
description: The trapping of interlayer valley excitons in a moiré potential formed by a molybdenum diselenide/tungsten diselenide heterobilayer with twist angle control is reported.

heading: Bacterial cGAS-like enzymes synthesize diverse nucleotide signals
authors: Aaron T. WhiteleyJames B. EagleshamPhilip J. Kranzusch
description: A bacterial family of cGAS/DncV-like nucleotidyltransferases synthesizes a diverse range of cyclic dinucleotide and trinucleotide compounds that are likely to modulate the interaction of both pathogens and commensal microbiota with their animal and plant hosts.

heading: Modified structure of protons and neutrons in correlated pairs
description: Simultaneous high-precision measurements of the EMC effect and short-range correlated abundances for several nuclei reveal a universal modification of the structure of nucleons in short-range correlated neutron–proton pairs.

heading: Neuromodulatory control of localized dendritic spiking in critical period cortex
authors: Courtney E. YaegerDario L. RingachJoshua T. Trachtenberg
description: A transient circuit that links cholinergic neuromodulation and inhibition is responsible for the dendritic compartmentalization of evoked responses in the mouse visual cortex during the critical period of robust plasticity.

heading: The seventh inner moon of Neptune
authors: M. R. ShowalterI. de PaterR. S. French
description: Hubble Space Telescope observations of the seventh inner moon of Neptune, Hippocamp, show that it is smaller than the other six, orbits near Proteus and probably originates from a fragment of Proteus.

heading: β-Synuclein-reactive T cells induce autoimmune CNS grey matter degeneration
description: In a rat model of multiple sclerosis, β-synuclein-specific T cells induce inflammation and pathological changes in the grey matter of the central nervous system; these cells were also found in higher numbers in patients with multiple sclerosis, particularly those with a chronic progressive course.

heading: A single-cell molecular map of mouse gastrulation and early organogenesis
description: Single-cell profiling is used to create a molecular-level atlas of cell differentiation trajectories during gastrulation and early organogenesis in the mouse.

heading: The single-cell transcriptional landscape of mammalian organogenesis
description: Data from single-cell combinatorial-indexing RNA-sequencing analysis of 2 million cells from mouse embryos between embryonic days 9.5 and 13.5 are compiled in a cell atlas of mouse organogenesis, which provides a global view of developmental processes occurring during this critical period.

heading: Female-biased embryonic death from inflammation induced by genomic instability
authors: Adrian J. McNairnChen-Hua ChuangJohn C. Schimenti
description: Genomic instability, caused by MCM mutations, results in embryonic lethality that disproportionally affects female mouse embryos and is rescued by testosterone or ibuprofen treatment, both of which ameliorate inflammatory effects.

heading: MHC class II proteins mediate cross-species entry of bat influenza viruses
description: The DR isotype of the human leukocyte antigen of the MHC class II—or its homologues in bats, pigs, mice and chickens—is an essential cell entry determinant for bat influenza A viruses.

heading: The centrosome protein AKNA regulates neurogenesis via microtubule organization
description: The interphase centrosome protein AKNA is necessary and sufficient for the organization of centrosomal microtubules, mediates delamination in the formation of the subventricular zone and regulates exit from this zone.

heading: Multiplex chromatin interactions with single-molecule precision
description: A strategy using droplet-based and barcode-linked sequencing captures multiplex chromatin interactions at single-molecule precision, and here provides topological insight into chromatin structures and transcription in Drosophila.

heading: Photonic topological insulator in synthetic dimensions
description: A spatially oscillating two-dimensional waveguide array is used to realize a photonic topological insulator in synthetic dimensions with modal-space edge states, unidirectionality and robust topological protection.

heading: Mapping orbital changes upon electron transfer with tunnelling microscopy on insulators
description: Driving single-electron tunnelling in synchronization with the oscillations of the conductive tip of an atomic force microscope allows mapping of the electronic structure of individual molecules in different charge states.

heading: High frequency of shared clonotypes in human B cell receptor repertoires
authors: Cinque SotoRobin G. BombardiJames E. Crowe Jr
description: Many clonotypes in human B cell repertoires are shared, including between adult and umbilical cord blood repertoires, which indicates that this similarity is not driven only by exposure to common antigens.

heading: Large teams develop and small teams disrupt science and technology
description: Analyses of the output produced by large versus small teams of researchers and innovators demonstrate that their work differs systematically in the extent to which it disrupts or develops existing science and technology.

heading: Rolling of the jaw is essential for mammalian chewing and tribosphenic molar function
authors: Bhart-Anjan S. BhullarArmita R. ManafzadehAlfred W. Crompton
description: The ancestral tribosphenic therian chewing stroke is conserved in Monodelphis domestica, and couples tooth-row eversion and inversion in jaw opening and closing, respectively, with a rotational grinding stroke.

heading: Near-field photonic cooling through control of the chemical potential of photons
description: The ‘negative luminescence’ of a reverse-biased photodiode is harnessed to draw thermal energy from a nearby solid object, thereby realizing photonic cooling without the use of coherent laser radiation.

heading: Spatial and temporal heterogeneity of mouse and human microglia at single-cell resolution
description: Analyses at single-cell resolution show that diverse subtypes of microglia exist during development and homeostasis of the central nervous system, and identify specific subsets of microglia associated with demyelination and neurodegenerative disease in mice and humans.

heading: Neural circuits underlying a psychotherapeutic regimen for fear disorders
description: Bilateral sensory stimulation, which is used to treat post-traumatic stress disorder in humans, alleviates fear memory in mice through a circuit involving the superior colliculus and the medial thalamus.

heading: Singlet molecular oxygen regulates vascular tone and blood pressure in inflammation
authors: Christopher P. StanleyGhassan J. MaghzalRoland Stocker
description: Singlet molecular oxygen, produced by indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase 1 activity, gives rise to a signalling molecule that regulates arterial relaxation under inflammatory conditions.

heading: Diabetes relief in mice by glucose-sensing insulin-secreting human α-cells
description: Islet non-β-cells from non-diabetic and diabetic human donors are modified via the transcription factors PDX1 and MAFA to produce and secrete insulin in response to glucose.

heading: Squalene accumulation in cholesterol auxotrophic lymphomas prevents oxidative cell death
description: The authors find that loss of squalene monooxygenase expression alters the lipid metabolism of cancer cells, which confers protection from ferroptotic cell death and thus promotes tumour growth.

heading: Thermodynamic signatures of quantum criticality in cuprate superconductors
description: Measurements of the specific heat of two cuprate materials at low temperature in magnetic fields large enough to suppress superconductivity and over a wide doping range reveal that the pseudogap phase of cuprates ends at a quantum critical point.

heading: Convergent estimates of marine nitrogen fixation
authors: Wei-Lei WangJ. Keith MooreFrançois W. Primeau
description: Convergent estimates of nitrogen fixation from an inverse biogeochemical and a prognostic ocean model show that biological carbon export in the ocean is higher than expected and that stabilizing nitrogen-cycle feedbacks are weaker than we thought.

heading: Sleep modulates haematopoiesis and protects against atherosclerosis
authors: Cameron S. McAlpineMáté G. KissFilip K. Swirski
description: The fragmentation of sleep in Apoe−/− mice induces monocytosis and accelerated atherosclerosis due to a reduction in hypocretin that otherwise restricts bone marrow CSF1 availability.

heading: Electrical resistivity across a nematic quantum critical point
description: The pattern of electrical resistivity in an unconventional superconductor at high magnetic fields and low temperatures across the nematic quantum critical point reveals two classic signatures of quantum criticality.

heading: Recalibration of path integration in hippocampal place cells
authors: Ravikrishnan P. JayakumarManu S. MadhavJames J. Knierim
description: Evidence from hippocampal place cells shows that path-integration gain, previously thought to be a constant factor in the computation of location, is flexible and can be rapidly fine-tuned.

heading: Structure of the complex I-like molecule NDH of oxygenic photosynthesis
authors: Thomas G. LaughlinAndrew N. BayneKaren M. Davies
description: The structure of NDH, a photosynthetic membrane-protein complex that is related to respiratory complex I, is obtained by single-particle cryo-electron microscopy.

heading: A weak topological insulator state in quasi-one-dimensional bismuth iodide
description: Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy is used to characterize the surface states of bismuth iodide, providing experimental evidence of a weak topological insulator state that had previously been only theoretically predicted.

heading: A new genomic blueprint of the human gut microbiota
authors: Alexandre AlmeidaAlex L. MitchellRobert D. Finn
description: The known species repertoire of the collective human gut microbiota is substantially expanded with the discovery of 1,952 uncultured bacterial species that greatly improve classification of understudied African and South American samples.

heading: Directionality of dynein is controlled by the angle and length of its stalk
description: The motility of dynein towards the minus end of the microtubule is controlled by the length and angle of the coiled-coil stalk that connects the motor to the microtubule.

heading: Global environmental consequences of twenty-first-century ice-sheet melt
authors: Nicholas R. GolledgeElizabeth D. KellerTamsin L. Edwards
description: Increased meltwater from the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets will slow the Atlantic overturning circulation and warm the subsurface ocean around Antarctica, further increasing Antarctic ice loss.

heading: Viral and metazoan poxins are cGAMP-specific nucleases that restrict cGAS–STING signalling
authors: James B. EagleshamYoudong PanPhilip J. Kranzusch
description: Poxvirus immune nucleases (poxins) degrade 2′,3′-cyclic GMP–AMP that is produced by cyclic GMP–AMP synthase (cGAS) to evade the innate immune system of the host.

heading: Neutrophils escort circulating tumour cells to enable cell cycle progression
description: The authors show that circulating tumour cells can be found in association with neutrophils, an interaction which supports their proliferation and their ability to seed metastasis.

heading: Interacting multi-channel topological boundary modes in a quantum Hall valley system
description: Scanning tunnelling microscopy shows that 1D channels between quantum Hall states with different valley polarization are metallic or insulating depending on constraints imposed on electron–electron interaction by valley flavour.

heading: Discrete attractor dynamics underlies persistent activity in the frontal cortex
description: Neuronal networks involving the frontal cortex follow discrete attractor dynamics to maintain short-term memories over times of seconds, much longer than the time-constant of individual neurons.

heading: Revisiting Antarctic ice loss due to marine ice-cliff instability
authors: Tamsin L. EdwardsMark A. BrandonAndreas Wernecke
description: By better quantifying uncertainties for marine ice-cliff instability, future Antarctic ice loss is predicted to be much lower than previously estimated.

heading: The CH25H–CYP7B1–RORα axis of cholesterol metabolism regulates osteoarthritis
description: In experimentally induced osteoarthritis, chondrocytes show increased uptake and metabolism of cholesterol, implicating the CH25H–CYP7B1–RORα axis in the pathogenesis of osteoarthritis.

heading: L1 drives IFN in senescent cells and promotes age-associated inflammation
authors: Marco De CeccoTakahiro ItoJohn M. Sedivy
description: During cellular senescence in human and mouse cells, L1 transposons become transcriptionally derepressed and trigger a type-1 interferon response, which contributes to age-associated inflammation and age-related phenotypes.

heading: Evidence for an alternative fatty acid desaturation pathway increasing cancer plasticity
description: In several human and mouse cancer cell lines and carcinomas, a sapienate biosynthesis pathway underpins metabolic plasticity by allowing these cells to bypass stearoyl-CoA desaturase-dependent fatty acid desaturation.

heading: A dissipatively stabilized Mott insulator of photons
description: Engineered dissipation is used to stabilize a Mott-insulator phase of photons trapped in a superconducting circuit, providing insights into thermalization processes in strongly correlated quantum matter.

heading: Ultra-large library docking for discovering new chemotypes
description: Using a make-on-demand library that contains hundreds-of-millions of molecules, structure-based docking was used to identify compounds that, after synthesis and testing, are shown to interact with AmpC β-lactamase and the D4 dopamine receptor with high affinity.

heading: Anti-tumour immunity controlled through mRNA m6A methylation and YTHDF1 in dendritic cells
description: The m6A reader protein YTHDF1 suppresses the clearance of tumour cells by enhancing the translation of lysosomal proteases in dendritic cells and thereby suppressing tumour antigen presentation.

heading: An N-nitrosating metalloenzyme constructs the pharmacophore of streptozotocin
authors: Tai L. NgRoman RohacEmily P. Balskus
description: The metalloenzyme SznF catalyses the formation of an N–N bond in the biosynthesis of streptozotocin, providing insights into the enzymatic assembly of an N-nitroso group.

heading: CasX enzymes comprise a distinct family of RNA-guided genome editors
description: CRISPR–CasX represents a distinct RNA-guided platform that is functionally separate from Cas9 and Cas12a and is active for bacterial and human genome modification.

heading: Waveguide-coupled single collective excitation of atomic arrays
description: Waveguide quantum electrodynamics is used to couple a single collective excitation of an atomic array to a nanoscale waveguide; the excitation is stored and later read out, generating guided single photons on demand.

heading: Atomically dispersed iron hydroxide anchored on Pt for preferential oxidation of CO in H2
description: Atomically dispersed iron hydroxide deposited on silica-supported platinum nanoparticles enables complete and selective carbon monoxide removal through preferential oxidation in hydrogen in the temperature range from 198 to 380 kelvin.

heading: Deacylative transformations of ketones via aromatization-promoted C–C bond activation
description: Aromatization-driven C–C bond activation through iridium/phosphine catalysis enables deacylative transformations in various ketone substrates.

heading: Gut intraepithelial T cells calibrate metabolism and accelerate cardiovascular disease
description: Integrin β7-dependent Glp1rhigh natural gut intraepithelial T lymphocytes that reside in the small intestine modulate dietary metabolism in mice by restricting the bioavailability of GLP-1.

heading: A quantitative approach for measuring the reservoir of latent HIV-1 proviruses
authors: Katherine M. BrunerZheng WangRobert F. Siliciano
description: An assay to measure the latent HIV-1 reservoir that separately quantifies intact and defective proviruses will facilitate evaluation of HIV-1 cure strategies by measuring the provirues that pose a barrier to cure.

heading: FOXK1 and FOXK2 regulate aerobic glycolysis
description: The Forkhead transcription factors FOXK1 and FOXK2, which are induced by starvation, reprogram cellular metabolism to induce aerobic glycolysis.

heading: Onset of differentiation is post-transcriptionally controlled in adult neural stem cells
description: Sequencing of total and ribosome-associated mRNAs enables identification of specific mRNAs that are differentially translationally regulated along the neuronal stem cell lineage, independently of their availability.

heading: Complex networks reveal global pattern of extreme-rainfall teleconnections
description: Complex networks are used to analyse global-scale teleconnections between extreme-rainfall events, revealing a peak in the distance distribution of statistically significant connections at around 10,000 kilometres.

heading: PKG1-modified TSC2 regulates mTORC1 activity to counter adverse cardiac stress
authors: Mark J. RanekKristen M. Kokkonen-SimonDavid A. Kass
description: Phosphorylation of one of two adjacent serine residues in TSC2 is both required and sufficient for PKG1-mediated cardiac protection against pressure overload in mice; these serine residues provide a genetic tool for the bidirectional regulation of stress-stimulated mTORC1 activity.

heading: Interleukin-22 protects intestinal stem cells against genotoxic stress
description: Sporadic inactivation of the interleukin-22 receptor in the intestinal epithelium of the mouse shows that IL-22 is required for effective activation of the DNA damage response following DNA damage.

heading: Tripled yield in direct-drive laser fusion through statistical modelling
description: A statistical approach to designing and predicting the fusion yield of cryogenic deuterium–tritium implosions leads to tripled yield in direct-drive laser fusion of deuterium–tritium layered targets.

heading: Age estimates for hominin fossils and the onset of the Upper Palaeolithic at Denisova Cave
description: Bayesian modelling of chronometric, stratigraphic and genetic data from Denisova Cave provides a chronological framework for understanding Neanderthal and Denisovan presence at the site, as well as interactions between these groups.

heading: Tissue curvature and apicobasal mechanical tension imbalance instruct cancer morphogenesis
description: Three-dimensional imaging of mouse pancreatic ducts before and after oncogenic transformation reveals that epithelial tumorigenesis is determined by the relationship between tissue curvature and apical–basal mechanical tension.

heading: PU.1 controls fibroblast polarization and tissue fibrosis
description: The transcription factor PU.1 is an essential regulator of the pro-fibrotic gene expression program in fibroblasts; PU.1 expression is upregulated in various fibrotic diseases, whereas inactivation of PU.1 induces regression of fibrosis in a number of organs.

heading: Heterozygous mutations cause genetic instability in a yeast model of cancer evolution
authors: Miguel C. CoelhoRicardo M. PintoAndrew W. Murray
description: Repeated selection for adaptive mutations in a diploid yeast model results in increased genetic instability and sheds light on mechanisms of genetic instability that might contribute to tumorigenesis.

heading: Timing of archaic hominin occupation of Denisova Cave in southern Siberia
description: Optical dating of sediments from Denisova Cave establishes a chronology for its Pleistocene deposits and the associated artefacts, hominin remains and environmental records, which date to between about 300,000 and 20,000 years ago.

heading: Secondary organic aerosol reduced by mixture of atmospheric vapours
description: Adding reactive gases such as isoprene to mixtures lowers the production of secondary organic aerosol in the atmosphere, thus reducing the atmospheric particulate burden, with implications for human health and climate.

heading: Two-dimensional MoS2-enabled flexible rectenna for Wi-Fi-band wireless energy harvesting
description: Integration of an ultrafast flexible rectifier made from a two-dimensional material with a flexible antenna achieves wireless energy harvesting of Wi-Fi radiation, which could power future flexible electronic systems.

heading: Large influence of soil moisture on long-term terrestrial carbon uptake
authors: Julia K. GreenSonia I. SeneviratnePierre Gentine
description: Earth system models suggest that soil-moisture variability and trends will induce large carbon releases throughout the twenty-first century.

heading: Computational periscopy with an ordinary digital camera
description: A faint penumbra in a photograph of a diffuse surface enables recovery of the position of the object creating the penumbra and an image of the scene behind it.

heading: Formation of massive black holes in rapidly growing pre-galactic gas clouds
authors: John H. WiseJohn A. ReganHao Xu
description: Simulations of early galaxy formation suggest that the dynamics of structure formation, rather than the Lyman–Werner flux, drives the formation of massive black holes in the early Universe.

heading: A defined commensal consortium elicits CD8 T cells and anti-cancer immunity
description: A consortium of 11 bacterial strains from the healthy human gut microbiota can strongly induce interferon-γ-producing CD8 T cells in the intestine, and enhance both resistance to bacterial infection and the therapeutic efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

heading: Rubisco condensate formation by CcmM in β-carboxysome biogenesis
description: The structure of a Rubisco–CcmM complex sheds light on the formation of carboxysomes in cyanobacteria.

heading: Southward propagation of Nazca subduction along the Andes
description: The current phase of subduction of the Nazca slab was established in the Peruvian Andes after a plate reorganization around 80 million years ago and then propagated progressively southwards.

heading: Altered human oligodendrocyte heterogeneity in multiple sclerosis
description: Single-nucleus RNA sequencing analysis identifies different subclusters of oligodendroglia in white matter from individuals with multiple sclerosis compared with controls, and these differences may be important for understanding disease progression.

heading: Structural insights into the activation of metabotropic glutamate receptors
description: The activation mechanism of metabotropic glutamate receptor subtype 5, a member of the family C G-protein-coupled receptors, is characterized by a combination of cryo-electron microscopy, crystallography and signalling studies.

heading: Contrasting processes drive ophiuroid phylodiversity across shallow and deep seafloors
authors: Timothy D. O’HaraAndrew F. HugallNicholas J. Bax
description: Our knowledge of the distribution and evolution of deep-sea life is limited, impeding our ability to identify priority areas for conservation.

heading: Dynamics of oligodendrocyte generation in multiple sclerosis
authors: Maggie S. Y. YeungMehdi DjelloulJonas Frisén
description: There are no new oligodendrocytes in potentially remyelinated multiple sclerosis shadow plaques, although oligodendrocyte generation is increased in the normal appearing white matter of patients with aggressive disease, informing the development of new therapies.

heading: GPR31-dependent dendrite protrusion of intestinal CX3CR1+ cells by bacterial metabolites
description: In the mouse intestine, pyruvate and lactate produced from bacterial metabolites enhance immune responses through inducing dendrite protrusion, mediated by GPR31, of small intestinal mononuclear cells that express CX3CR1.

heading: Super-Mendelian inheritance mediated by CRISPR–Cas9 in the female mouse germline
authors: Hannah A. GrunwaldValentino M. GantzKimberly L. Cooper
description: In the early embryo, Cas9 expressed in the female germline induces double-stranded breaks that are corrected by homology-directed repair, biasing inheritance of a desired allele in mice.

heading: Tracking tumour evolution in glioma through liquid biopsies of cerebrospinal fluid
authors: Alexandra M. MillerRonak H. ShahIngo K. Mellinghoff
description: Identification and sequencing of circulating tumour DNA in the cerebrospinal fluid of patients with glioma.

heading: Autophagic cell death restricts chromosomal instability during replicative crisis
description: Cell death during replicative crisis involves autophagy induced by telomere dysfunction.

heading: Real-time vibrations of a carbon nanotube
authors: Arthur W. BarnardMian ZhangPaul L. McEuen
description: The thermal vibrations of a carbon nanotube are directly measured in real time with high displacement sensitivity and fine time resolution, revealing dynamics undetected by previous time-averaged measurements.

heading: Commonality despite exceptional diversity in the baseline human antibody repertoire
description: A genetic study of the baseline human antibody repertoire, based on the circulating B cell populations of ten subjects, reveals universally shared antibody clonotypes within repertoires that are largely unique to the individual.

heading: Photoredox catalysis using infrared light via triplet fusion upconversion
authors: Benjamin D. RavetzAndrew B. PunLuis M. Campos
description: Photoredox transformations are achieved with infrared light by using triplet fusion upconversion that converts infrared into visible light, enabling the use of photoredox chemistry on larger scales and through barriers that are impenetrable by visible light.

heading: Damage-tolerant architected materials inspired by crystal microstructure
description: Inspired by the enhanced mechanical strength of microstructured metals, damage-tolerant architected materials are developed in which the internal structure is granular, with different regions having different lattice orientations.

heading: Magnetic and magnetic inverse spin Hall effects in a non-collinear antiferromagnet
description: A magnetic contribution to the spin Hall effect is observed in the non-collinear antiferromagnet Mn3Sn, which is attributed to momentum-dependent spin splitting produced by non-collinear magnetic order.

heading: Introns are mediators of cell response to starvation
description: Transcriptomic and genetic analyses of a deletion set of all known introns in genes of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae indicate that introns promote resistance to starvation.

heading: Interacting neural ensembles in orbitofrontal cortex for social and feeding behaviour
authors: Joshua H. JenningsChristina K. KimKarl Deisseroth
description: Distinct but partially overlapping subsets of neurons in the orbitofrontal cortex of mice respond to feeding and/or social stimuli and, when optogenetically stimulated at single-cell resolution, specifically regulate reward-seeking behaviours.

heading: Reverse-engineering the locomotion of a stem amniote
authors: John A. NyakaturaKamilo MeloAuke J. Ijspeert
description: Quantitative explorations using biomechanics and robotics of the gait of Orobates, a stem amniote, indicate that the development of relatively erect, power-saving and balanced locomotion preceded the diversification of crown amniotes

heading: HIF-1α metabolically controls collagen synthesis and modification in chondrocytes
description: Increased glutamine metabolism caused by unregulated HIF-1α signalling in mouse chondrocytes results in increased post-translational modification of collagen and skeletal dysplasia, demonstrating that strict regulation of HIF-1α signalling in chondrocytes is essential for normal bone growth.

heading: A kiwellin disarms the metabolic activity of a secreted fungal virulence factor
description: A kiwellin protein in maize is found to inhibit the activity of the secreted enzyme chorismate mutase from a maize-infecting pathogenic fungus, suggesting a role for kiwellins in plant immunity.

heading: Excised linear introns regulate growth in yeast
authors: Jeffrey T. MorganGerald R. FinkDavid P. Bartel
description: A set of 34 excised introns in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, characterized by having a short distance between the lariat branch point and the 3′ splice site, have a biological function within the TOR growth-signalling network.

heading: Signatures of a jet cocoon in early spectra of a supernova associated with a γ-ray burst
authors: L. IzzoA. de Ugarte PostigoK. Wiersema
description: Multi-epoch observations of a supernova associated with a γ-ray burst reveal spectral features at extremely high expansion velocities within the first day after the burst, indicative of a choked jet.

heading: Human blood vessel organoids as a model of diabetic vasculopathy
authors: Reiner A. WimmerAlexandra LeopoldiJosef M. Penninger
description: Organoids derived from human stem cells recapitulate the structure and functions of human blood vessels, and can be used to model and identify regulators of diabetic vasculopathy.

heading: Molecular control of macroscopic forces drives formation of the vertebrate hindgut
authors: Nandan L. NerurkarChangHee LeeClifford J. Tabin
description: Cell-labelling experiments are used to demonstrate that the hindgut in the chick embryo is formed by cells moving through the stationary caudal intestinal portal as a result of a contractile force gradient directed by fibroblast growth factor signalling.

heading: Spatially resolved steady-state negative capacitance
authors: Ajay K. YadavKayla X. NguyenSayeef Salahuddin
description: Imaging steady-state negative capacitance in SrTiO3/PbTiO3 superlattices with atomic resolution provides solid microscale support for this phenomenon.

heading: Unveiling the double-well energy landscape in a ferroelectric layer
authors: Michael HoffmannFranz P. G. FenglerThomas Mikolajick
description: A ferroelectric thin film that behaves as a single domain is found to exhibit both negative capacitance and the predicted double-well polarization–energy relationship.

heading: Core crystallization and pile-up in the cooling sequence of evolving white dwarfs
description: Photometry and parallax data from the Gaia satellite provide direct observational evidence of a theoretically predicted pile-up in the cooling sequence of white dwarfs, which is associated with core crystallization.

heading: Mobile PEAR transcription factors integrate positional cues to prime cambial growth
description: Radial growth in the roots of Arabidopsis, which is mediated by gene expression activated by the mobile PEAR1 and PEAR2 transcription factors, is initiated around protophloem-sieve-element cell files of procambial tissue.

heading: FTSJ3 is an RNA 2′-O-methyltransferase recruited by HIV to avoid innate immune sensing
description: HIV-1 uses the host protein FTSJ3 to methylate its own genome, thereby evading detection by the innate immune system.

heading: Mitochondrial complex III is essential for suppressive function of regulatory T cells
authors: Samuel E. WeinbergBenjamin D. SingerNavdeep S. Chandel
description: Specific ablation of mitochondrial complex III subunits in Treg cells in mice results in inflammatory disease, altered Treg gene expression and defective Treg function, indicating a key functional role for mitochondrial complex III in Treg cells.

heading: High levels of auxin signalling define the stem-cell organizer of the vascular cambium
description: In the roots of Arabidopsis thaliana, cells with xylem identity and high levels of auxin signalling function as organizer cells that direct neighbouring vascular cambial cells to act as stem cells.

heading: A recurrent nova super-remnant in the Andromeda galaxy
authors: M. J. DarnleyR. HounsellS. C. Williams
description: A frequently recurring nova is surrounded by an enormous cavity in space, produced as the nova’s ejecta ‘sweeps up’ the interstellar medium around the star after each eruption.

heading: Chemical control of structure and guest uptake by a conformationally mobile porous material
authors: Alexandros P. KatsoulidisDmytro AntypovMatthew J. Rosseinsky
description: A new metal–organic framework has several conformational degrees of freedom that can be modified by the external chemical environment to change the structure and trigger the uptake of a guest molecule.

heading: Sound velocity of CaSiO3 perovskite suggests the presence of basaltic crust in the Earth’s lower mantle
description: In situ high-pressure and high-temperature measurements of the sound velocity of CaSiO3 perovskite suggest accumulation of basaltic crust in the Earth’s uppermost lower mantle.

heading: The corona contracts in a black-hole transient
authors: E. KaraJ. F. SteinerA. L. Stevens
description: X-ray observations of the evolution of a black-hole transient suggest a shrinkage of its corona, rather than a change in the inner edge of the accretion disk.

heading: Subcellular transcriptomes and proteomes of developing axon projections in the cerebral cortex
authors: Alexandros PoulopoulosAlexander J. MurphyJeffrey D. Macklis
description: A subcellular sorting approach enables quantitative analysis of subtypes of growth cones in the brain, and reveals subcellular relationships between local mRNA and local proteomes in developing projection neurons.

heading: De novo design of potent and selective mimics of IL-2 and IL-15
description: A hyper-stable de novo protein mimic of interleukin-2 computationally designed to not interact with a regulatory T-cell specific receptor subunit has improved therapeutic activity in mouse models of melanoma and colon cancer.

heading: Observations of fast radio bursts at frequencies down to 400 megahertz
description: Thirteen fast radio bursts—astrophysical events that last on the order of a millisecond—have been discovered at frequencies as low as 400 megahertz, including only the second known repeating burst.

heading: LHX2- and LDB1-mediated trans interactions regulate olfactory receptor choice
description: Specific interchromosomal contacts in olfactory sensory neurons form a super-enhancer that controls the expression of a single olfactory receptor in each neuron.

heading: Calicivirus VP2 forms a portal-like assembly following receptor engagement
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of feline calicivirus and its cellular receptor show that twelve copies of the minor capsid protein VP2 form a portal-like assembly arranged about a pore in the capsid shell.

heading: Realization of a three-dimensional photonic topological insulator
description: A three-dimensional photonic topological insulator is presented, made of split-ring resonators with strong magneto-electric coupling, which has an extremely wide topological bandgap, forbidding light propagation.

heading: Structures of an RNA polymerase promoter melting intermediate elucidate DNA unwinding
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of bacterial RNAP–promoter DNA complexes, including structures of partially melted intermediates, suggest a universally conserved common mechanism for promoter DNA opening prior to gene expression.

heading: Electromagnetic and gravitational responses of photonic Landau levels
description: Probing the local response of an integer quantum Hall system enables three different measures of its topology to be explored.

heading: A second source of repeating fast radio bursts
description: A second repeating fast radio burst is detected, showing behaviour similar to that of the first, and demonstrating that repeaters are unlikely to be rare.

heading: Disruption of the Orion molecular core 1 by wind from the massive star θ1 Orionis C
authors: C. PabstR. HigginsA. G. G. M. Tielens
description: Wind from the most massive star in the Trapezium cluster in Orion has carved out a large and expanding cavity around the cluster, bounded by a thin, 2,600-solar-mass shell.

heading: The surprisingly large neutron capture cross-section of 88Zr
authors: Jennifer A. ShustermanNicholas D. ScielzoAnton P. Tonchev
description: The thermal neutron capture cross-section of 88Zr is measured to be 861,000 ± 69,000 barns, the second-largest neutron capture cross-section ever measured.

heading: Age-related remodelling of oesophageal epithelia by mutated cancer drivers
description: In physiologically normal epithelia, age-related expansion of clones that carry mutations in NOTCH1 and other driver genes is accelerated by risk factors for developing oesophageal squamous cell carcinoma, such as alcohol consumption or smoking.

heading: The ultrafast Einstein–de Haas effect
description: Femtosecond time-resolved X-ray diffraction reveals that in the ultrafast demagnitization of ferromagnetic iron, about 80% of the angular momentum lost from the spins is transferred to the lattice on a sub-picosecond timescale.

heading: Genomic insights into the 2016–2017 cholera epidemic in Yemen
description: Isolates of the Vibrio cholerae O1 serotype Ogawa from Yemen are from a single sublineage of the seventh pandemic El Tor (7PET) lineage and are susceptible to several commonly used antibiotics as well as to polymyxins.

heading: Greenland melt drives continuous export of methane from the ice-sheet bed
description: Subglacially produced methane of microbial origin is flushed to the ice margin of the Greenland ice sheet by meltwater, contributing to a previously unaccounted for methane flux to the atmosphere.

heading: GABAA receptor signalling mechanisms revealed by structural pharmacology
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures are reported in which the full-length human α1β3γ2L GABAA receptor in lipid nanodiscs is bound to the channel-blocker picrotoxin, the competitive antagonist bicuculline, the agonist GABA, and the benzodiazepines alprazolam and diazepam.

heading: An ultrafast symmetry switch in a Weyl semimetal
authors: Edbert J. SieClara M. NybyAaron M. Lindenberg
description: Terahertz light pulses induce transitions between a topological and a trivial phase in the Weyl semimetal WTe2 through an interlayer shear strain.

heading: A wireless closed-loop system for optogenetic peripheral neuromodulation
authors: Aaron D. MickleSang Min WonJohn A. Rogers
description: A closed-loop implantable bioelectronic device that can modulate peripheral neuronal activity is used to improve bladder function in a rat model of cystitis.

heading: Cryo-EM structure of the human α1β3γ2 GABAA receptor in a lipid bilayer
description: A high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure is reported for the full-length human α1β3γ2L GABAA receptor, functionally reconstituted in lipid nanodiscs.

heading: Genomic encoding of transcriptional burst kinetics
authors: Anton J. M. LarssonPer JohnssonRickard Sandberg
description: Allele-specific single-cell RNA sequencing provides insights into transcription kinetics, with data indicating that core promoter sequences affect burst size, whereas enhancers mainly affect burst frequency.

heading: Brain regulatory T cells suppress astrogliosis and potentiate neurological recovery
description: In a mouse model of ischaemic stroke, regulatory T cells infiltrate the injured brain in response to the chemokines CCL1 and CCL20 and suppress excessive astrogliosis via the production of amphiregulin.

heading: Tissue-resident memory CD8+ T cells promote melanoma–immune equilibrium in skin
description: A transplantable mouse model of persistent cutaneous melanoma shows that immune-mediated tumour suppression can result in a state of melanoma–immune equilibrium, and that tissue-resident memory T cells are essential drivers of this equilibrium state.

heading: Structural basis of Notch recognition by human γ-secretase
description: The cryo-electron microscopy structure of human γ-secretase in complex with its substrate Notch reveals pronounced structural rearrangements compared to the apo enzyme, including formation of a β-sheet involving residues from both enzyme and substrate.

heading: Structure of the post-translational protein translocation machinery of the ER membrane
description: The cryo-EM structure of the post-translational protein translocation machinery of the endoplasmic reticulum membrane shows that Sec63 opens the channel, enabling insertion of low-hydrophobicity signal sequences into the lipid phase.

heading: A warped disk around an infant protostar
description: Observations at millimetre wavelengths reveal a young protostar surrounded by a disk with two differently tilted regions.

heading: Enzymatic assembly of carbon–carbon bonds via iron-catalysed sp3 C–H functionalization
authors: Ruijie K. ZhangKai ChenFrances H. Arnold
description: Evolved iron-containing enzymes based on cytochrome P450 achieve selective intermolecular alkylation of sp3 C–H bonds through a carbene C–H insertion strategy.

heading: Kurnosov et al. reply
Concerns about modelling of the EDGES data
Desymmetrization of cyclohexanes by site- and stereoselective C–H functionalization
authors: Jiantao FuZhi RenHuw M. L. Davies
description: Unactivated cyclohexane derivatives can be desymmetrized by site- and stereoselective C–H functionalization using carbene-insertion chemistry.

heading: Elasticity of lower-mantle bridgmanite
Reply to Hills et al.
authors: Judd D. BowmanAlan E. E. RogersNivedita Mahesh

heading: Extreme 13C,15N and 17O isotopic enrichment in the young planetary nebula K4-47
authors: D. R. SchmidtN. J. WoolfL. M. Ziurys
description: Millimetre-wavelength observations of the bipolar planetary nebula K4-47 show very high abundances of the rare isotopes 13C, 15N and 17O, providing clues about the possible origin of the nebula.

heading: Programmable design of orthogonal protein heterodimers
description: Computational design incorporating modular buried hydrogen networks produces highly orthogonal protein heterodimers.

heading: Impact of pear-shaped fission fragments on mass-asymmetric fission in actinides
description: Quantum many-body calculations of superfluid fission dynamics reveal that heavy fragments from asymmetric fission of actinides are associated with considerable octupole (pear-shaped) deformation acquired on the way to fission.

heading: Metabolic heterogeneity underlies reciprocal fates of TH17 cell stemness and plasticity
authors: Peer W. F. KarmausXiang ChenHongbo Chi
description: Phenotypically, transcriptionally and metabolically diverse subsets of TH17 cells develop in a chronic autoimmune disease: one subset has inferred stemness features and low anabolic metabolism, while a reciprocal subset has higher metabolic activity that supports transdifferentiation into TH1 cells.

heading: Stochastic synaptic plasticity underlying compulsion in a model of addiction
description: In mice, synaptic potentiation of transmission from the orbitofrontal cortex to the dorsal striatum drives compulsive reinforcement, a defining symptom of addiction.

heading: Measurement of the Casimir torque
authors: David A. T. SomersJoseph L. GarrettJeremy N. Munday
description: The theoretically predicted Casimir torque, which causes charge-neutral, birefringent materials to rotate towards a preferred alignment, is measured.

heading: Actively personalized vaccination trial for newly diagnosed glioblastoma
description: In a phase I trial, highly individualized peptide vaccines against unmutated tumour antigens and neoepitopes elicited sustained responses in CD8+ and CD4+ T cells, respectively, in patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma.

heading: Origin of spatial variation in US East Coast sea-level trends during 1900–2017
authors: Christopher G. PiecuchPeter HuybersMartin P. Tingley
description: Vertical motions of Earth’s crust had the greatest effect on regional spatial differences in relative sea-level trends along the eastern coast of the USA during 1900–2017, explaining most of the large-scale spatial variance in regional rates of sea-level rise.

heading: Thermal stress induces glycolytic beige fat formation via a myogenic state
description: The mouse develops a developmentally and functionally distinct, non-canonical beige fat cell type as an adaptation to cold ambient temperature.

heading: The global distribution and trajectory of tidal flats
authors: Nicholas J. MurrayStuart R. PhinnRichard A. Fuller
description: Analyses of over 700,000 satellite images to map the global extent of tidal flats over the past thirty years, and enable assessments of the status and likely future trajectories of these coastal ecosystems.

heading: Neoantigen vaccine generates intratumoral T cell responses in phase Ib glioblastoma trial
authors: Derin B. KeskinAnnabelle J. AnandappaDavid A. Reardon
description: Neoantigen-targeting vaccines are a feasible therapy for tumours with a low mutation burden and immunologically ‘cold’ tumour microenvironment, as neoantigen-specific T cells from the peripheral blood migrate into intracranial glioblastoma, thereby altering the immune milieu of the glioblastoma.

heading: Quantum Hall effect based on Weyl orbits in Cd3As2
description: Quantized conductivity is observed along a Weyl orbit in wedge-shaped samples of the topological semimetal Cd3As2, providing evidence of the quantum Hall effect in three dimensions.

heading: Loss of ADAR1 in tumours overcomes resistance to immune checkpoint blockade
authors: Jeffrey J. IshizukaRobert T. MangusoW. Nicholas Haining
description: Deletion of the A-to-I double-stranded RNA-editing enzyme ADAR1 sensitizes tumour cells to immunotherapy.

heading: Observation of the nonlinear Hall effect under time-reversal-symmetric conditions
description: The nonlinear Hall effect is observed in bilayer WTe2 in the absence of a magnetic field, providing a direct measure of the dipole moment of the Berry curvature.

heading: Transmission of amyloid-β protein pathology from cadaveric pituitary growth hormone
authors: Silvia A. PurroMark A. FarrowJohn Collinge
description: Archived vials of cadaveric human growth hormone contain substantial levels of amyloid-β (Aβ) peptides and can seed Aβ plaques in susceptible mice, suggesting that this material could have transmitted Aβ pathology to humans.

heading: Catalytic deracemization of chiral allenes by sensitized excitation with visible light
description: Photochemical deracemization through irradiation with visible light in the presence of a chiral sensitizer enables the direct formation of single enantiomers from a racemic mixture of the same compound.

heading: Increased variability of eastern Pacific El Niño under greenhouse warming
description: Despite inter-model differences in predicting the details of the eastern Pacific El Niño, a robust increase in the corresponding sea surface temperature variability under greenhouse warming is found across models.

heading: Structure of Plasmodium falciparum Rh5–CyRPA–Ripr invasion complex
description: A subnanometre-resolution cryo-electron microscopy structure of the Rh5–CyRPA–Ripr complex of Plasmodium falciparum provides insights into how this ligand interacts with the receptor basigin in erythrocyte hosts.

heading: An entanglement-based wavelength-multiplexed quantum communication network
description: A fully connected quantum network is demonstrated in which one source of entangled photons distributes quantum states to four users, with the potential for many more users to be added.

heading: Structure of native lens connexin 46/50 intercellular channels by cryo-EM
authors: Janette B. MyersBassam G. HaddadSteve L. Reichow
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of connexin channels composed of connexin 46 and connexin 50 in an open-state reveal features that govern permselectivity and the location of mutated residues linked to herediatry cataracts.

heading: Experimental realization of on-chip topological nanoelectromechanical metamaterials
description: Topological nanoelectromechanical metamaterials are realized at the micrometre scale, using silicon nitride nanomembranes, opening the way for on-chip integrated acoustic components in high-frequency signal-processing applications.

heading: Assessing the efficiency of changes in land use for mitigating climate change
description: Evaluation of the efficiency of land-use changes and their effect on global carbon storage shows that several land-use and consumption choices relevant to climate policy have greater implications than previously thought.

heading: Structural basis of coreceptor recognition by HIV-1 envelope spike
description: The cryo-electron microscopy structure of the gp120 component of the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein, in complex with the primary receptor CD4 and coreceptor CCR5, provides insight into the cell-entry mechanism of HIV-1.

heading: Disruption of a self-amplifying catecholamine loop reduces cytokine release syndrome
description: Atrial natriuretic peptide, an anti-inflammatory protein, can protect against cytokine release syndrome induced by therapeutic agents such as tumour-targeting bacteria and CAR-T cells by blocking catecholamine synthesis by macrophages.

heading: The translation of non-canonical open reading frames controls mucosal immunity
description: In mouse macrophages, a range of short and non-ATG-initiated open reading frames that can generate proteins are identified, one of which is shown to be essential for host immunity to enteric mucosal infection and inflammation.

heading: Trapping biosynthetic acyl-enzyme intermediates with encoded 2,3-diaminopropionic acid
authors: Nicolas Huguenin-DezotDiego A. AlonzoJason W. Chin
description: A method for encoding the non-canonical amino acid 2,3-diaminopropionate into proteins allows key acyl intermediates in the biosynthesis of valinomycin to be trapped, providing insight into the oligomerization and cyclization reactions involved.

heading: Direct observation of incommensurate magnetism in Hubbard chains
description: Direct observation of incommensurate spin correlations in doped and spin-imbalanced Hubbard chains confirms two fundamental predictions for Luttinger liquids and shows that such correlations are suppressed by interchain coupling.

heading: A male-expressed rice embryogenic trigger redirected for asexual propagation through seeds
description: Misexpression of the sperm-cell-expressed transcription factor BABY BOOM1 in the rice egg cell induces embryo development without fertilization, establishing the feasibility of asexual reproduction in crops and potentially enabling the clonal propagation of hybrids through seeds.

heading: Electric-field-tuned topological phase transition in ultrathin Na3Bi
authors: James L. CollinsAnton TadichMark T. Edmonds
description: An electrically controlled phase transition from topological insulator to conventional insulator in ultrathin films of the topological Dirac semimetal, Na3Bi.

heading: Identifying the pathways required for coping behaviours associated with sustained pain
description: In mice, the ablation of spinal neurons that co-express TAC1 and LBX1 leads to the loss of coping responses to sustained pain without affecting reflexive defensive reactions to external threats.

heading: SETD3 is an actin histidine methyltransferase that prevents primary dystocia
description: SETD3 methylates mammalian actin at His73, and SETD3 deficiency impairs stimulus-induced contraction in primary human uterine smooth muscle cells and leads to maternal dystocia in mice.

heading: Stiff competition
Berger et al. reply
authors: J. B. BergerH. N. G. WadleyR. M. McMeeking

heading: Dna2 nuclease deficiency results in large and complex DNA insertions at chromosomal breaks
description: A deficiency of Dna2 causes duplication of DNA fragments and their insertion into the genome at double-stranded breaks in yeast.

heading: Industrial and agricultural ammonia point sources exposed
description: Satellite observations reveal over 200 ammonia hotspots associated with agricultural and industrial point sources, which emit much larger quantities of ammonia to the atmosphere than previously thought.

heading: Soft-tissue evidence for homeothermy and crypsis in a Jurassic ichthyosaur
description: The presence of blubber and distribution of melanophores in a countershading pattern in an Early Jurassic ichthyosaur demonstrate that the evolutionary convergence of these reptiles with extant marine amniotes extends to the cellular and molecular levels.

heading: Inner ear development in cyclostomes and evolution of the vertebrate semicircular canals
description: The differentiation of the inner ear in the lamprey Lethenteron camtschaticum and hagfish Eptatretus burgeri sheds light on the evolution of the semicircular canals of jawed vertebrates.

heading: Transformation between meron and skyrmion topological spin textures in a chiral magnet
description: A magnetically induced two-dimensional square lattice of merons and antimerons is observed in real space, along with its transformation into a hexagonal lattice of skyrmions at room temperature.

heading: Controlling orthogonal ribosome subunit interactions enables evolution of new function
authors: Wolfgang H. SchmiedZakir TnimovJason W. Chin
description: Orthogonal ribosomes are engineered in which the two subunits are stapled together in a way that limits association with endogenous subunits in cells, enabling the evolution of new functionality in the orthogonal ribosome.

heading: Nonlinear rise in Greenland runoff in response to post-industrial Arctic warming
authors: Luke D. TruselSarah B. DasMichiel R. van den Broeke
description: Ice-core-derived melt records reveal that atmospheric warming has recently intensified Greenland ice-sheet surface melt and runoff to levels that are exceptional over at least the last 350 years.

heading: Capture of nebular gases during Earth’s accretion is preserved in deep-mantle neon
description: The distinctive 20Ne/22Ne ratio in material thought to come from deep mantle plumes provides evidence for nebular gas as a source of volatiles in Earth’s interior.

heading: Complex mammalian-like haematopoietic system found in a colonial chordate
description: The identification of a complex haematopoietic system in a colonial tunicate sheds light on the evolution of the mammalian blood system.

heading: An experiment to search for dark-matter interactions using sodium iodide detectors
description: Early results from the COSINE-100 experiment—designed to test a much-debated claim of the detection of a dark-matter signal—show no indications of dark matter, providing evidence against the previous claim.

heading: A chemical defence against phage infection
description: Streptomyces secondary metabolites provide a chemical defence against phage predation.

heading: A circuit from hippocampal CA2 to lateral septum disinhibits social aggression
description: Pyramidal neurons in the hippocampal CA2 region in mice promote social aggression via a disinhibitory circuit involving the lateral septum and ventromedial hypothalamus.

heading: Consistent success in life-supporting porcine cardiac xenotransplantation
description: α1,3-galactosyltransferase-knockout pig hearts that express human CD46 and human thrombomodulin require non-ischaemic preservation with continuous perfusion and post-transplantation growth control to ensure long-term orthotopic function of the xenograft in baboons.

heading: Single-cell mapping of lineage and identity in direct reprogramming
authors: Brent A. BiddyWenjun KongSamantha A. Morris
description: Combinatorial tagging of single cells using expressed DNA barcodes, delivered by a lentiviral vector, is used to track individual cells and reconstruct their lineages and trajectories during cell fate reprogramming.

heading: Scalable energy-efficient magnetoelectric spin–orbit logic
authors: Sasikanth ManipatruniDmitri E. NikonovIan A. Young
description: A scalable spintronic device operating via spin–orbit transduction and magnetoelectric switching and using advanced quantum materials shows non-volatility and improved performance and energy efficiency compared with CMOS devices.

heading: Chemical differentiation, cold storage and remobilization of magma in the Earth’s crust
authors: M. D. JacksonJ. BlundyR. S. J. Sparks
description: Magma storage and differentiation in the Earth’s crust mainly occurs by reactive melt flow in long-lived mush reservoirs, rather than by fractional crystallization in magma chambers, as previously thought.

heading: A structural transition in physical networks
description: A modelling framework is presented to determine the optimal layout and physical properties of networks in which the nodes and links have physical sizes and intersections between components is prohibited.

heading: Extreme-ultraviolet refractive optics
description: A refractive lens and a refractive prism for extreme-ultraviolet radiation have been developed that use the deflection of the radiation in an inhomogeneous jet of atoms.

heading: Metabolic reprogramming by the S-nitroso-CoA reductase system protects against kidney injury
description: AKR1A1-regulated protein S-nitrosylation protects against kidney injury through PKM2-mediated metabolic reprogramming.

heading: Stella safeguards the oocyte methylome by preventing de novo methylation mediated by DNMT1
description: Stella, a factor essential for female fertility, protects the oocyte methylome in mice by suppressing de novo DNA methylation mediated by the DNA methyltransferase DNMT1.

heading: PtdIns4P on dispersed trans-Golgi network mediates NLRP3 inflammasome activation
description: Recruitment of NLRP3 to the dispersed trans-Golgi network via binding to PtdIns4P is required for activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome by diverse stimuli.

heading: Atomic clock performance enabling geodesy below the centimetre level
authors: W. F. McGrewX. ZhangA. D. Ludlow
description: Improved techniques allow the measurement of a frequency difference with an uncertainty of the order of 10–19 between two independent atomic optical lattice clocks, suggesting that they may be able to improve state-of-the-art geodetic techniques.

heading: Mechanosignalling via integrins directs fate decisions of pancreatic progenitors
description: Single-cell analysis reveals that interactions with the extracellular matrix via integrin α5 and mechanotransducer YAP1 determine whether pancreatic progenitors develop along the duct or endocrine lineages.

heading: Spatially resolved rotation of the broad-line region of a quasar at sub-parsec scale
description: High-angular-resolution observations of the quasar 3C 273 reveal that it has a relatively small but thick disk, viewed nearly face-on, in which material is orbiting the central supermassive black hole.

heading: NP220 mediates silencing of unintegrated retroviral DNA
authors: Yiping ZhuGary Z. WangStephen P. Goff
description: In mammalian cells, NP220 is a key protein that recruits the HUSH complex, SETDB1 and the histone deacetylases HDAC1 and HDAC4 to silence unintegrated retroviral DNA.

heading: Abrupt ice-age shifts in southern westerly winds and Antarctic climate forced from the north
description: The position of the Southern Hemisphere westerly winds responds immediately to abrupt North Atlantic climate events of the last ice age, with a spatially heterogeneous impact on Antarctic climate.

heading: Trophoblast organoids as a model for maternal–fetal interactions during human placentation
description: An in vitro system that generates three-dimensional cultures of extraembryonic fetal trophoblast cells that differentiate into the two main types of trophoblast can be used to study human placental development.

heading: CDK12 regulates DNA repair genes by suppressing intronic polyadenylation
authors: Sara J. DubburyPaul L. BoutzPhillip A. Sharp
description: The kinase CDK12 suppresses usage of intronic polyadenylation sites and thereby promotes the expression of genes involved in homologous recombination DNA repair.

heading: FBXO38 mediates PD-1 ubiquitination and regulates anti-tumour immunity of T cells
description: PD-1 undergoes internalization, FBXO38-mediated ubiquitination and proteasome degradation in activated T cells, and inhibition of this pathway dampens anti-tumour immunity of T cells.

heading: Reversible superdense ordering of lithium between two graphene sheets
description: Using a double-aberration-corrected transmission electron microscope, intercalation of lithium between two graphene sheets is found to produce a dense, multilayer lithium phase, rather than the expected single layer.

heading: Reward behaviour is regulated by the strength of hippocampus–nucleus accumbens synapses
authors: Tara A. LeGatesMark D. KvartaScott M. Thompson
description: Dopamine-independent induction of long-term potentiation at hippocampal synapses onto the nucleus accumbens modulates reward-related behaviour.

heading: Quantum control of surface acoustic-wave phonons
authors: K. J. SatzingerY. P. ZhongA. N. Cleland
description: A non-classical superposition of zero- and one-phonon mechanical Fock states is generated and measured by strongly coupling a surface acoustic-wave resonator to a superconducting qubit.

heading: Flight of an aeroplane with solid-state propulsion
authors: Haofeng XuYiou HeSteven R. H. Barrett
description: A solid-state propulsion system can sustain powered flight, as demonstrated by an electroaerodynamically propelled heavier-than-air aeroplane.

heading: U–Pb-dated flowstones restrict South African early hominin record to dry climate phases
authors: Robyn PickeringAndy I. R. HerriesPhillip J. Hancox
description: Climate-driven periodicity of flowstone accretion between 3.2 and 1.3 million years ago in Cradle of Humankind caves reveals that the presence of hominin fossils reflects accumulation in open caves during intermittent, substantially drier phases.

heading: Creation and control of multi-phonon Fock states in a bulk acoustic-wave resonator
description: Circuit quantum acoustodynamics is used to achieve controlled generation of multi-phonon Fock states in a bulk acoustic-wave resonator, which are demonstrated to have a quantum nature.

heading: Efficient radical-based light-emitting diodes with doublet emission
description: Organic light-emitting devices containing radical emitters can achieve an efficiency of 27 per cent at deep-red and infrared wavelengths based on the excitation of spin doublets, rather than singlet or triplet states.

heading: Distinct activity-gated pathways mediate attraction and aversion to CO2 in Drosophila
authors: Floris van BreugelAinul HudaMichael H. Dickinson
description: Drosophila melanogaster are attracted to CO2 when in an active, foraging state but experience aversion to CO2 at low-activity levels, whereas they are attracted to ethanol in all behavioural states.

heading: Helios is a key transcriptional regulator of outer hair cell maturation
description: Ikzf2, which encodes the transcription factor Helios, is identified as a crucial regulator of gene expression in maturing cochlear outer hair cells, and overexpression of Ikzf2 in inner hair cells induces prestin expression and electromotility.

heading: Efferocytosis induces a novel SLC program to promote glucose uptake and lactate release
authors: Sho MoriokaJustin S. A. PerryKodi S. Ravichandran
description: Distinct transcriptional programs are activated during different stages of apoptotic cell engulfment, including a unique program of genes coding for solute carrier proteins and enzymes in the glycolytic pathway.

heading: Twentieth-century contribution to sea-level rise from uncharted glaciers
description: From 1901 to 2015, missing and disappeared glaciers produced a rise in sea level that may enable the historical budget for global-mean sea-level rise to be closed without recourse to an undiscovered physical process.

heading: TIC236 links the outer and inner membrane translocons of the chloroplast
description: TIC236 is an inner-membrane protein that binds to the outer-membrane channel TOC75 to create a long, stable bridge that enables the transport of proteins into chloroplasts.

heading: Mannose impairs tumour growth and enhances chemotherapy
authors: Pablo Sierra GonzalezJames O’PreyKevin M. Ryan
description: Mannose reduces the growth of tumour cells by impairing the metabolism of glucose, and enhances cell death when used in combination with conventional chemotherapy.

heading: Structural plasticity of D3–D14 ubiquitin ligase in strigolactone signalling
description: The plant F-box protein D3 has a C-terminal α-helix that switches between two conformational states, allowing the α/β hydrolase D14 to recruit the transcription repressor D53 for strigolactone-dependent degradation.

heading: Protocadherin-1 is essential for cell entry by New World hantaviruses
authors: Rohit K. JangraAndrew S. HerbertKartik Chandran
description: New World hantaviruses—which cause a severe human respiratory disease—use surface glycoproteins to bind to the human protocadherin-1 protein and enter endothelial cells in vitro; depleting protocadherin-1 in Syrian golden hamsters largely protects against disease.

heading: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus alters cell wall glycosylation to evade immunity
description: Strains of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus use a prophage-encoded glycosyltransferase to alter the glycosylation of their wall teichoic acid and thereby evade antibody-mediated immune responses.

heading: Amphioxus functional genomics and the origins of vertebrate gene regulation
description: Genomic, epigenomic and transcriptomic data derived from the Mediterranean amphioxus (Branchiostoma lanceolatum) provide insights into the evolution of the genomic regulatory landscape of chordates.

heading: Somatic APP gene recombination in Alzheimer’s disease and normal neurons
description: The gene for the amyloid precursor protein (APP) shows somatic gene recombination in neurons, and the abundance and diversity of APP variants is increased in neurons from individuals with Alzheimer’s disease.

heading: Change in future climate due to Antarctic meltwater
description: Accounting for meltwater from the Antarctic Ice Sheet in simulations of global climate leads to substantial changes in future climate projections and identifies a potential feedback mechanism that exacerbates melting.

heading: VCAM-1+ macrophages guide the homing of HSPCs to a vascular niche
description: In zebrafish embryogenesis, nascent haematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs), homing to a vascular niche for retention, are ushered by patrolling and guiding macrophages through integrin-mediated cell-cell recognition.

heading: Late Middle Pleistocene Levallois stone-tool technology in southwest China
description: Levallois stone-tool technology found at the Guanyindong Cave site in southwest China was dated to approximately 170,000–80,000 years ago, which is much earlier than previously thought.

heading: Cryptic connections illuminate pathogen transmission within community networks
authors: Joseph R. HoytKate E. LangwigA. Marm Kilpatrick
description: Cryptic connections facilitate the community-wide spread of disease both within and among species.

heading: Urbanization exacerbated the rainfall and flooding caused by hurricane Harvey in Houston
description: Modelling the contribution of urbanization to the impacts associated with hurricane Harvey in August 2017 shows that urbanization worsens rainfall and flooding.

heading: Sensitive tumour detection and classification using plasma cell-free DNA methylomes
authors: Shu Yi ShenRajat SinghaniaDaniel D. De Carvalho
description: An immunoprecipitation-based protocol is developed to analyse DNA methylation in small quantities of circulating cell-free DNA, and can detect and classify cancers in plasma samples from several tumour types.

heading: Similar cranial trauma prevalence among Neanderthals and Upper Palaeolithic modern humans
description: Neanderthals and Upper Palaeolithic modern humans exhibit similar overall incidences of cranial trauma that are higher for males of both taxa; however, there are species-specific, age-related variations in trauma prevalence.

heading: The hippocampus is crucial for forming non-hippocampal long-term memory during sleep
description: Hippocampal activity during a period of sleep after memory encoding is crucial for forming long-term memories in rats, even for types of memory considered not to be hippocampus-dependent.

heading: Water input into the Mariana subduction zone estimated from ocean-bottom seismic data
description: Seismic images of Earth’s crust and uppermost mantle around the Mariana trench show widespread serpentinization, suggesting that much more water is subducted than previously thought.

heading: Linking a cell-division gene and a suicide gene to define and improve cell therapy safety
description: Introduction of a suicide gene together with a linked cell-division gene to generate a safe-cell system enables the selective elimination of proliferating cells after cell transplantation in mouse models of cell therapy.

heading: A candidate super-Earth planet orbiting near the snow line of Barnard’s star
description: Analysis of 20 years of observations of Barnard’s star from seven facilities reveals a signal with a period of 233 days that is indicative of a companion planet.

heading: Autophagy maintains tumour growth through circulating arginine
description: Mice with whole-body or liver-specific deletion of Atg7 release circulating arginase I and have reduced levels of serum arginine, which impairs the growth of allografted arginine-auxotrophic tumours.

heading: Hemimastigophora is a novel supra-kingdom-level lineage of eukaryotes
authors: Gordon LaxYana EglitAlastair G. B. Simpson
description: Phylogenetic analyses based on single-cell transcriptomic data from two hemimastigotes, a Spironema species and the newly described Hemimastix kukwesjijk, indicate that Hemimastigophora is a supra-kingdom-level lineage of eukaryotes.

heading: Widespread but heterogeneous responses of Andean forests to climate change
description: With global warming, Andean forests are changing to include more trees of low-elevation, heat-loving species but rates of compositional change are not uniform across elevations and are insufficient to keep species in equilibrium with climate.

heading: POLAR-guided signalling complex assembly and localization drive asymmetric cell division
description: POLAR, identified in a survey of the protein interactome of BRASSINOSTEROID INSENSITIVE 2 in Arabidopsis thaliana, has a key role in coordinating cell polarity and enabling asymmetric cell division.

heading: Anthropogenic influences on major tropical cyclone events
description: Climate model simulations reveal that recent destructive tropical cyclones would have been equally intense in terms of wind speed but would have produced less rainfall if these events had occurred in pre-industrial climates, and in future climates they would have greater wind speeds and rainfall.

heading: Single-cell reconstruction of the early maternal–fetal interface in humans
description: Transcriptomes of about 70,000 single cells from first-trimester deciduas and placentas reveal subsets of perivascular, stromal and natural killer cells in the decidua, with distinct immunomodulatory profiles that regulate the environment necessary for successful placentation.

heading: Enhanced strength and ductility in a high-entropy alloy via ordered oxygen complexes
description: Ordered oxygen complexes in high-entropy alloys enhance both strength and ductility in these compositionally complex solid solutions.

heading: Improved reference genome of Aedes aegypti informs arbovirus vector control
authors: Benjamin J. MatthewsOlga DudchenkoLeslie B. Vosshall
description: An improved, fully re-annotated Aedes aegypti genome assembly (AaegL5) provides insights into the sex-determining M locus, chemosensory systems that help mosquitoes to hunt humans and loci involved in insecticide resistance and will help to generate intervention strategies to fight this deadly disease vector.

heading: The entropic force generated by intrinsically disordered segments tunes protein function
authors: Nicholas D. KeulKrishnadev OrugantyZachary A. Wood
description: The carboxy terminus of human UDP-α-d-glucose-6-dehydrogenase is structurally disordered, but has sequence-independent effects on the conformation of the enzyme and binding of an allosteric inhibitor, suggesting a reason for the persistence of intrinsically disordered peptide segments in the proteome.

heading: Cryo-EM structures and dynamics of substrate-engaged human 26S proteasome
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures and dynamics of a substrate-engaged human 26S proteasome reveal in atomic detail three principal modes of coordinated ATP hydrolysis that regulate different steps in the degradation of a ubiquitylated protein.

heading: Universal prethermal dynamics of Bose gases quenched to unitarity
authors: Christoph EigenJake A. P. GliddenZoran Hadzibabic
description: Degenerate and thermal Bose gases, quenched so that the interparticle interactions are as strong as allowed by quantum mechanics, exhibit dynamics that can be expressed in terms of universal functions.

heading: Observation of universal dynamics in a spinor Bose gas far from equilibrium
description: The emergence of universal dynamics far from equilibrium is observed by evaluating spatially resolved spin correlations in a quasi-one-dimensional spinor Bose–Einstein condensate.

heading: Superfluorescence from lead halide perovskite quantum dot superlattices
description: Cooperative quantum effects in superlattices of quantum dots made of caesium lead halide perovskite give rise to superfluorescence, with the individual emitters interacting coherently to give intense bursts of light.

heading: A population of luminous accreting black holes with hidden mergers
authors: Michael J. KossLaura BlechaDavid B. Sanders
description: High-resolution infrared observations of hard-X-ray-selected black holes show an excess of late-stage mergers in obscured luminous black holes compared with inactive galaxies of similar stellar masses and star formation rates.

heading: Universal dynamics in an isolated one-dimensional Bose gas far from equilibrium
description: The momentum distribution of atoms in a one-dimensional Bose gas far from equilibrium exhibits universal scaling in space and time, independent of the initial conditions of the system.

heading: Structures of the intermediates of Kok’s photosynthetic water oxidation clock
description: Crystallography and spectroscopy are used to solve high-resolution structures of the intermediates of Kok’s S-state clock in photosystem II.

heading: The metabolite BH4 controls T cell proliferation in autoimmunity and cancer
authors: Shane J. F. CroninCorey SeehusJosef M. Penninger
description: Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is an enzyme co-factor that is involved in the nervous system; it is shown here to also function in T cell activation and proliferation, with roles in autoimmunity, allergic inflammation and cancer.

heading: Predictable and precise template-free CRISPR editing of pathogenic variants
authors: Max W. ShenMandana ArbabRichard I. Sherwood
description: The authors use a machine-learning algorithm to predict the spectrum of CRISPR–Cas9-nuclease-mediated DNA repair outcomes at human genomic target sites.

heading: Type 9 secretion system structures reveal a new protein transport mechanism
authors: Frédéric LauberJustin C. DemeBen C. Berks
description: Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the protein-conducting translocon of the type 9 secretion system reveal its architecture and mechanism of translocation.

heading: Efficient and stable emission of warm-white light from lead-free halide double perovskites
description: After alloying with metal cations, a lead-free halide double perovskite shows stable performance and remarkably efficient white-light emission, with possible applications in lighting and display technologies.

heading: Abiotic synthesis of amino acids in the recesses of the oceanic lithosphere
description: High-resolution imaging techniques show that aromatic amino acids such as tryptophan formed abiotically and were subsequently preserved at depth beneath the Atlantis Massif of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, supporting the hydrothermal theory for the origin of life.

heading: Dopamine enhances signal-to-noise ratio in cortical-brainstem encoding of aversive stimuli
authors: Caitlin M. Vander WeeleCody A. SicilianoKay M. Tye
description: Dopamine in the medial prefrontal cortex modulates behavioural responses to aversive stimuli by increasing the signal-to-noise ratio of neurons projecting to the dorsal periaqueductal grey.

heading: Palaeolithic cave art in Borneo
authors: M. AubertP. SetiawanH. E. A. Brand
