heading: Comparative glycoproteomics of stem cells identifies new players in ricin toxicity
description: A novel quantitative approach to identify intact glycopeptides from comparative proteomic data sets, allowing inference of complex glycan structures and direct mapping of them to sites within the associated proteins at the proteome scale.

heading: Enhanced proofreading governs CRISPR–Cas9 targeting accuracy
authors: Janice S. ChenYavuz S. DagdasJennifer A. Doudna
description: A new engineered version of SpCas9, called HypaCas9, displays enhanced accuracy of editing without significant loss of efficiency at the desired target.

heading: Genome editing reveals a role for OCT4 in human embryogenesis
authors: Norah M. E. FogartyAfshan McCarthyKathy K. Niakan
description: Genome editing in human zygotes shows that OCT4 is required for normal development at an earlier stage in humans than in mice.

heading: Targeting neuronal activity-regulated neuroligin-3 dependency in high-grade glioma
authors: Humsa S. VenkateshLydia T. TamMichelle Monje
description: The growth of adult and paediatric brain tumours depends on a microenvironmental signalling pathway involving the activity-regulated secretion of neuroligin-3 (NLGN3) from normal neurons and oligodendrocyte precursor cells, highlighting the potential of NLGN3 as a therapeutic target.

heading: ApoE4 markedly exacerbates tau-mediated neurodegeneration in a mouse model of tauopathy
description: ApoE4 exacerbates tau pathogenesis, neuroinflammation and tau-mediated neurodegeneration independently of brain amyloid-β pathology, and exerts a ‘toxic’ gain of function whereas its absence is protective.

heading: Patchy particles made by colloidal fusion
description: By exploiting geometric constraints and interfacial forces instead of chemistry, colloidal clusters can be controllably coalesced into particles with uniformly distributed surface patches.

heading: Hardware-efficient variational quantum eigensolver for small molecules and quantum magnets
description: The ground-state energy of small molecules is determined efficiently using six qubits of a superconducting quantum processor.

heading: Detection of titanium oxide in the atmosphere of a hot Jupiter
authors: Elyar SedaghatiHenri M. J. BoffinHeike Rauer
description: Titanium oxide, water, sodium and a strongly scattering haze have been detected in the atmosphere of the hot Jupiter exoplanet WASP-19b.

heading: Superparamagnetic enhancement of thermoelectric performance
description: By embedding superparamagnetic nanoparticles in a thermoelectric matrix, phonon and electron transport within the material can be controlled simultaneously at nanometre and mesoscopic length scales, thereby improving the thermoelectric performance of the material.

heading: Real-space imaging of non-collinear antiferromagnetic order with a single-spin magnetometer
description: A non-invasive scanning magnetometer, based on a single nitrogen–vacancy defect in diamond, visualizes antiferromagnetic order at the nanometre scale in thin films of bismuth ferrite at room temperature.

heading: Impact of a global temperature rise of 1.5 degrees Celsius on Asia’s glaciers
authors: P. D. A. KraaijenbrinkM. F. P. BierkensW. W. Immerzeel
description: Models show that even if global temperature rise can be limited to 1.5 degrees Celsius, only about 65 per cent of glacier mass will remain in the high mountains of Asia by the end of this century, and if temperatures rise by more than this the effects will be much more extreme.

heading: The cryo-electron microscopy structure of human transcription factor IIH
authors: Basil J. GreberThi Hoang Duong NguyenEva Nogales
description: The cryo-electron microscopy structure of the ten-subunit human transcription factor IIH, revealing the molecular architecture of the TFIIH core complex, the detailed structures of its constituent XPB and XPD ATPases, and how the core and kinase subcomplexes of TFIIH are connected.

heading: Reversing behavioural abnormalities in mice exposed to maternal inflammation
authors: Yeong Shin YimAshley ParkGloria B. Choi
description: The authors define a specific cortical subregion of the somatosensory cortex as a critical region of dysfunction that is causal to the emergence of abnormal social and repetitive behaviours in mice exposed to maternal inflammation.

heading: The Apostasia genome and the evolution of orchids
description: WebComparing the whole genome sequence of Apostasia shenzhenica with transcriptome and genome data from five orchid subfamilies permits the reconstruction of an ancestral gene toolkit, providing insight into orchid origins, evolution and diversification.

heading: Alternative evolutionary histories in the sequence space of an ancient protein
authors: Tyler N. StarrLora K. PictonJoseph W. Thornton
description: Combining ancestral protein reconstruction with deep mutational scanning to characterize alternative histories in the sequence space around an ancient transcription factor reveals hundreds of alternative protein sequences that use diverse biochemical mechanisms to perform the derived function at least as well as the historical outcome.

heading: The neuropeptide NMU amplifies ILC2-driven allergic lung inflammation
authors: Antonia WallrappSamantha J. RiesenfeldVijay K. Kuchroo
description: Neuromedin receptor NMUR1 is specifically expressed by a subpopulation of type 2 innate lymphoid cells and promotes the inflammatory response of these cells in response to allergens, indicating the importance of neuro-immune crosstalk in allergic responses.

heading: Maternal gut bacteria promote neurodevelopmental abnormalities in mouse offspring
description: Maternal immune activation (MIA)-mediated abnormal behavioural phenotypes require defined gut commensal bacteria for the induction of IL-17-producing T helper 17 cells.

heading: Hippocampal LTP and contextual learning require surface diffusion of AMPA receptors
authors: A. C. PennC. L. ZhangD. Choquet
description: Surface diffusion of AMPA receptors, from extra-synaptic to synaptic sites at the plasma membrane, is essential for full long-term potentiation in hippocampal neurons and for fear conditioning in living mice.

heading: SAM-dependent enzyme-catalysed pericyclic reactions in natural product biosynthesis
description: The enzyme LepI is found to be capable of catalysing several natural-product pericyclic transformations, including a hetero-Diels–Alder reaction and a retro-Claisen rearrangement.

heading: cGAS senses long and HMGB/TFAM-bound U-turn DNA by forming protein–DNA ladders
description: A molecular mechanism for the sensitive detection of long and U-turn DNA by cyclic GMP–AMP synthase (cGAS) both in vitro and in human cells.

heading: Rabies screen reveals GPe control of cocaine-triggered plasticity
authors: Kevin T. BeierChristina K. KimRobert C. Malenka
description: A rabies virus-based monosynaptic tracing method is used to show that the external globus pallidus plays a critical role in cocaine-induced behavioural plasticity.

heading: A spin transition mechanism for cooperative adsorption in metal–organic frameworks
authors: Douglas A. ReedBenjamin K. KeitzJeffrey R. Long
description: Metal–organic frameworks that undergo a cooperative spin transition at neighbouring metal centres upon coordination to CO exhibit large CO separation capacities with only small changes in temperature.

heading: Discrete and broadband electron acceleration in Jupiter’s powerful aurora
authors: B. H. MaukD. K. HaggertyP. Valek
description: The process that generates Earth’s most intense aurora is found to occur at Jupiter, but is of only secondary importance in generating Jupiter’s much more powerful aurora.

heading: Direct instrumental identification of catalytically active surface sites
authors: Jonas H. K. PfistererYunchang LiangAliaksandr S. Bandarenka
description: Scanning tunnelling microscopy is used to distinguish between different active sites of a catalyst—such as boundaries between different materials—during a reaction, allowing the contributions of these sites to be evaluated.

heading: A right-handed signalling pathway drives heart looping in vertebrates
authors: Oscar H. OcañaHakan CoskunM. Angela Nieto
description: Two parallel signalling pathways, driven by Nodal and BMP, respectively integrate left- and right-handed information that drives heart looping and morphogenesis, and are conserved between zebrafish, chicken and mouse.

heading: A solvent- and vacuum-free route to large-area perovskite films for efficient solar modules
description: A new deposition method for solar-panel polycrystalline perovskite thin films enables the production of large-area uniform films and avoids the need for common solvents or vacuum.

heading: Biodiversity effects in the wild are common and as strong as key drivers of productivity
authors: J. Emmett DuffyCasey M. GodwinBradley J. Cardinale
description: A synthesis of 67 biodiversity studies shows that, after controlling for environmental covariates, the effects of biodiversity on biomass are stronger in nature than in experiments and are comparable to the effects of other drivers of productivity.

heading: Structural basis of MsbA-mediated lipopolysaccharide transport
description: Cryo-electron microscopy snapshots of the E. coli flippase MsbA at discrete functional states reveal a ‘trap and flip’ mechanism for lipopolysaccharide flipping and the conformational transitions of MsbA during its substrate transport cycle.

heading: Polycomb-like proteins link the PRC2 complex to CpG islands
description: Crystal structures of the Polycomb-like proteins PHF1 and MTF2 with bound DNA and histone peptides show that extended homologous regions of the two proteins form a winged-helix structure that has an unexpected mechanism of binding to unmethylated CpG-containing DNA motifs.

heading: m6A modulates haematopoietic stem and progenitor cell specification
description: N6-methyladenosine modification of mRNA determines cell fate decisions during the specification of the first haematopoietic stem cells in zebrafish.

heading: Palmitoylation-dependent activation of MC1R prevents melanomagenesis
description: The protein modification palmitoylation increases the ability of variant forms of the melanocortin-1 receptor (MC1R) to induce pigmentation, and this is linked to reduced development of melanomas.

heading: Neuronal regulation of type 2 innate lymphoid cells via neuromedin U
description: Group 2 innate lymphoid cells express the neuromedin U receptor 1 (NMUR1) and respond to neuromedin U (NMU) released by adjacent enteric neurons, and this interaction results in an enhanced immediate early response to the nematode Nippostrongylus brasiliensis.

heading: Competing memories of mitogen and p53 signalling control cell-cycle entry
description: Mother cells transmit mitogen-induced CCND1 mRNA and DNA damage-induced p53 protein to newly born daughter cells, where synthesized cyclin D1 and the p53-regulated CDK inhibitor p21 directly compete to decide between proliferation and quiescence.

heading: The neuropeptide neuromedin U stimulates innate lymphoid cells and type 2 inflammation
authors: Christoph S. N. KloseTanel MahlakõivDavid Artis
description: Intestinal type 2 innate lymphoid cells express the neuropeptide receptor NMUR1, which makes them responsive to neuronal neuromedin U, thereby promoting a type 2 cytokine response and accelerated expulsion of the gastro-intestinal nematode Nippostrongylus brasiliensis.

heading: Mimicking biological stress–strain behaviour with synthetic elastomers
authors: Mohammad Vatankhah-VarnosfaderaniWilliam F. M. DanielSergei S. Sheiko
description: A polymer code based on a triplet of parameters—network strand length, side-chain length and grafting density—enables materials to be designed with specific combinations of mechanical properties to mimic biological materials.

heading: How type II CRISPR–Cas establish immunity through Cas1–Cas2-mediated spacer integration
description: Several structures of the Enteroccocus faecalis Cas1–Cas2 proteins are solved, and help to define the spacer integration mechanisms of type II CRISPR systems.

heading: Fast automated analysis of strong gravitational lenses with convolutional neural networks
authors: Yashar D. HezavehLaurence Perreault LevasseurPhilip J. Marshall
description: Estimates of parameters of strong gravitational lenses are obtained in an automated way using convolutional neural networks, with similar accuracy and greatly improved speed compared to previous methods.

heading: Molecular machines open cell membranes
description: Rotary molecular machines, activated by ultraviolet light, are able to perturb and drill into cell membranes in a controllable manner, and more efficiently than those exhibiting flip-flopping or random motion.

heading: Proper-motion age dating of the progeny of Nova Scorpii AD 1437
description: The re-discovery of the binary star system that created the Nova Scorpii AD 1437 stellar outburst shows that it is now a dwarf nova, suggesting that nova systems spend some time as dwarf novae in between larger outbursts.

heading: Very large release of mostly volcanic carbon during the Palaeocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum
description: Boron and carbon isotope data, used in an Earth system model, show that the Palaeocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum was associated with a much greater release of carbon than thought, most probably triggered by volcanism in the North Atlantic.

heading: Human iPS cell-derived dopaminergic neurons function in a primate Parkinson’s disease model
description: In a preclinical study, dopaminergic neurons derived from human induced pluripotent stem cells were implanted into a primate model of Parkinson’s disease, where they were found to exhibit long-term survival, function as mid-brain dopaminergic neurons, and increase spontaneous movements.

heading: Island biogeography of marine organisms
authors: Hudson T. PinheiroGiacomo BernardiLuiz A. Rocha
description: On marine islands, most species are good dispersers and most niches are filled by immigration with little adaptive radiation; speciation increases over time, associated with the arrival of weak dispersers that randomly establish isolated populations.

heading: Orthotopic patient-derived xenografts of paediatric solid tumours
authors: Elizabeth StewartSara M. FedericoMichael A. Dyer
description: A protocol producing orthotopic patient-derived xenografts at diagnosis, recurrence, and autopsy demonstrates proof of principle for using these tumours for basic and translational research on paediatric solid tumours.

heading: Discovery of stimulation-responsive immune enhancers with CRISPR activation
authors: Dimitre R. SimeonovBenjamin G. GowenAlexander Marson
description: The authors use tiled CRISPR activation for functional enhancer discovery across two autoimmunity risk loci, CD69 and IL2RA, and identify elements with features of stimulus-responsive enhancers, including an IL2RA enhancer that harbours a fine-mapped autoimmunity risk variant.

heading: Early members of ‘living fossil’ lineage imply later origin of modern ray-finned fishes
description: High-resolution scans of fossilized fish skulls suggest that modern ray-finned fishes originated later than previously thought and necessitate reconsideration of the evolution of this major vertebrate group.

heading: Commensal bacteria make GPCR ligands that mimic human signalling molecules
authors: Louis J. CohenDaria EsterhazySean F. Brady
description: Commensal bacteria have N-acyl amide synthase genes that encode signalling molecules (N-acyl amides) that can interact with G-protein-coupled receptors and elicit host cellular responses similar to eukaryotic N-acyl amides.

heading: Fate mapping of human glioblastoma reveals an invariant stem cell hierarchy
authors: Xiaoyang LanDavid J. JörgPeter B. Dirks
description: Using unique barcodes for tumour cells, the authors explore the dynamics of human glioblastoma subpopulations, and suggest that clonal heterogeneity emerges through stochastic fate decisions of a neutral proliferative hierarchy.

heading: Metallic molybdenum disulfide nanosheet-based electrochemical actuators
description: Electrochemical actuators based on exfoliated and restacked metallic MoS2 nanosheet electrodes can generate mechanical force in electrolyte solution on intercalation and deintercalation of ions.

heading: A somatic mutation in erythro-myeloid progenitors causes neurodegenerative disease
description: Braf V600E expression in resident macrophage progenitors leads to clonal expansion of ERK-activated microglia, which causes synaptic and neuronal loss in the brain and results in lethal neurodegenerative disease in adult mice.

heading: A series of energetic metal pentazolate hydrates
description: Metal complexes of the pentazole anion exhibit multiple coordination modes, through ionic, covalent and hydrogen-bonding interactions, and good thermal stability with onset decomposition temperatures greater than 100 °C.

heading: Molecular magnetic hysteresis at 60 kelvin in dysprosocenium
authors: Conrad A. P. GoodwinFabrizio OrtuDavid P. Mills
description: Magnetic hysteresis is observed in a dysprosocenium complex at temperatures of up to 60 kelvin, the origin of which is the localized metal–ligand vibrational modes unique to dysprosocenium.

heading: Minimal geological methane emissions during the Younger Dryas–Preboreal abrupt warming event
authors: Vasilii V. PetrenkoAndrew M. SmithJeffrey P. Severinghaus
description: Measurements from Antarctic ice suggest that geological methane emissions are much lower than previously thought, and that methane emissions from hydrates and permafrost in response to climate warming are minimal.

heading: RETRACTED ARTICLE: Epitaxy of advanced nanowire quantum devices
authors: Sasa GazibegovicDiana CarErik P. A. M. Bakkers
description: A finely tuned growth strategy to generate nanowire networks that fulfil all the prerequisites for braiding may lead to a demonstration of Majorana braiding.

heading: Distinguishing spin-aligned and isotropic black hole populations with gravitational waves
description: The spins of the black holes involved in each of the four mergers that have been detected in gravitational waves so far were either small or not aligned with the binary orbit.

heading: Magnetic antiskyrmions above room temperature in tetragonal Heusler materials
authors: Ajaya K. NayakVivek KumarStuart S. P. Parkin
description: Antiskyrmions, in which the magnetization rotates both as a transverse helix and as a cycloid, are found in acentric tetragonal Heusler compounds over a wide range of temperatures.

heading: A heterochromatin-dependent transcription machinery drives piRNA expression
description: Transcription of Drosophila PIWI-interacting RNA (piRNA) clusters is enforced through RNA polymerase II pre-initiation complex formation within repressive heterochromatin, accomplished through the transcription factor IIA subunit paralogue Moonshiner.

heading: Lhx6-positive GABA-releasing neurons of the zona incerta promote sleep
description: GABAergic Lhx6+ neurons in the ventral zona incerta promote both rapid eye movement and non-rapid eye movement sleep and inhibit the activity of wake-promoting GABAergic and Hcrt+ neurons of the lateral hypothalamus.

heading: Homeostatic control of metabolic and functional fitness of Treg cells by LKB1 signalling
description: The tumour suppressor liver kinase B1 (LKB1) regulates the metabolic and functional fitness of regulatory T cells in the control of immune tolerance and homeostasis.

heading: Kinetic analysis of a complete nitrifier reveals an oligotrophic lifestyle
authors: K. Dimitri KitsChristopher J. SedlacekMichael Wagner
description: A pure culture of the complete nitrifier Nitrospira inopinata shows a high affinity for ammonia, low maximum rate of ammonia oxidation, high growth yield compared to canonical nitrifiers and genomic potential for alternative metabolisms, probably reflecting an important role in nitrification in oligotrophic environments.

heading: Public antibodies to malaria antigens generated by two LAIR1 insertion modalities
description: Up to 10% of individuals in malaria-endemic regions produce antibodies that react to malaria antigens through an additional LAIR1 domain that is inserted by two different insertion modalities.

heading: Feedback regulation of steady-state epithelial turnover and organ size
description: Steady-state turnover of the Drosophila midgut arises through an intercellular, E-cadherin–EGFR relay that couples the death of individual enterocytes to the divisions of nearby stem cells.

heading: Ascorbate regulates haematopoietic stem cell function and leukaemogenesis
authors: Michalis AgathocleousCorbin E. MeachamSean J. Morrison
description: Ascorbate depletion in mice increased haematopoietic stem-cell frequency and promoted leukaemogenesis, partly by reducing the function of the Tet2 tumour suppressor enzyme.

heading: Vigorous atmospheric motion in the red supergiant star Antares
description: Mapping the velocity of the gas at the surface and in the atmosphere of the nearby red supergiant star Antares reveals vigorous motion of several huge gas clumps in an extended atmosphere, which cannot be fully explained by convection.

heading: Ram-pressure feeding of supermassive black holes
authors: Bianca M. PoggiantiYara L. JafféAlessandro Omizzolo
description: The majority of ‘jellyfish’ galaxies, characterized by long ‘tentacles’ of gas, also have active nuclei, indicating that gas is being fed to the central supermassive black hole by ram pressure.

heading: Polylox barcoding reveals haematopoietic stem cell fates realized in vivo
description: An artificial recombination locus, Polylox, that can generate hundreds of thousands of individual barcodes is used to trace the fates of haematopoietic stem cells in mice.

heading: A randomized synbiotic trial to prevent sepsis among infants in rural India
description: A synbiotic preparation of Lactobacillus plantarum and fructooligosaccharide was found to significantly reduce sepsis and infections of the lower respiratory tract in a trial involving rural Indian newborns.

heading: The primed SNARE–complexin–synaptotagmin complex for neuronal exocytosis
description: An atomic model of the primed pre-fusion SNARE–complexin–synaptotagmin-1 complex in neuronal exocytosis accounting for vesicle priming and cooperation in synchronizing and activating evoked release on the sub-millisecond timescale.

heading: Identification of CMTM6 and CMTM4 as PD-L1 protein regulators
authors: Riccardo MezzadraChong SunTon N. M. Schumacher
description: CMTM6 and CMTM4 bind to and stabilize the inhibitory receptor PD-L1 and regulate PD-L1 levels at the surface of human tumour and immune cells.

heading: The rise of algae in Cryogenian oceans and the emergence of animals
authors: Jochen J. BrocksAmber J. M. JarrettTharika Liyanage
description: Steroid biomarkers provide evidence for a rapid rise of marine planktonic algae between 659 and 645 million years ago, establishing more efficient energy transfers and driving ecosystems towards larger and increasingly complex organisms.

heading: Stromal R-spondin orchestrates gastric epithelial stem cells and gland homeostasis
authors: Michael SigalCatriona Y. LoganThomas F. Meyer
description: Myofibroblast-derived R-spondin 3 orchestrates regeneration of antral stomach epithelium via Wnt signalling in Axin2+ stem cells.

heading: CDK4/6 inhibition triggers anti-tumour immunity
authors: Shom GoelMolly J. DeCristoJean J. Zhao
description: Mouse models of breast carcinoma and other solid tumours show that selective cyclin-dependent kinase 4 and 6 (CDK4/6) inhibitors not only induce tumour cell cycle arrest but also promote anti-tumour immunity.

heading: Mechanism of intracellular allosteric β2AR antagonist revealed by X-ray crystal structure
description: The authors report the crystal structure of the β2 adrenergic receptor in complex with compound 15, an allosteric modulator that binds to an alternative binding pocket.

heading: Mammals divert endogenous genotoxic formaldehyde into one-carbon metabolism
description: The mechanism by which formaldehyde, a potent DNA and protein crosslinking agent, is generated from folate is described, with implications for the treatment of certain cancers.

heading: Vaccine-driven pharmacodynamic dissection and mitigation of fenethylline psychoactivity
authors: Cody J. WenthurBin ZhouKim D. Janda
description: A vaccine-driven approach shows that the prominent stimulant features of the psychoactive profile of fenethylline can be attributed to amphetamine, with synergistic support from theophylline, and no direct contributions from the parent drug molecule.

heading: CMTM6 maintains the expression of PD-L1 and regulates anti-tumour immunity
authors: Marian L. BurrChristina E. SparbierMark A. Dawson
description: CMTM6 maintains PD-L1 at the plasma membrane by inhibiting its lysosome-mediated degradation and promoting its recycling.

heading: Large turbulent reservoirs of cold molecular gas around high-redshift starburst galaxies
description: Large haloes of diffuse molecular gas discovered around high-redshift starburst galaxies show that galactic feedback, coupled to turbulence and gravity, extends the starburst phase instead of quenching it.

heading: Genome-scale activation screen identifies a lncRNA locus regulating a gene neighbourhood
description: Long noncoding RNAs are investigated using a CRISPR–Cas9 activation screen and shown to confer BRAF inhibitor resistance on melanoma cells through various local mechanisms.

heading: Role of stem-cell divisions in cancer risk
Wu et al. reply
Global patterns of drought recovery
authors: Christopher R. SchwalmWilliam R. L. AndereggHanqin Tian
description: A global analysis of gross primary productivity reveals that drought recovery is driven by climate and carbon cycling, with recovery longest in the tropics and high northern latitudes, and with impacts increasing over the twentieth century.

heading: The complete connectome of a learning and memory centre in an insect brain
description: The complete, synapse-resolution connectome of the Drosophila larval mushroom body.

heading: Enhanced sensitivity at higher-order exceptional points
description: The response of a ternary, parity–time-symmetric system that exhibits a third-order exceptional point increases as a function of the cube-root of induced perturbations.

heading:
New infant cranium from the African Miocene sheds light on
ape evolution
description:
Description of the most complete fossil skull of an infant ape
recovered from the Miocene epoch of Kenya, assigned to a new species in the genusNyanzapithecus.

heading: Exceptional points enhance sensing in an optical microcavity
description: Tuning optical microcavities to exceptional points enhances their ability to sense nanoscale objects, owing to the topological features of exceptional points.

heading: Chaotic dynamics in nanoscale NbO2 Mott memristors for analogue computing
authors: Suhas KumarJohn Paul StrachanR. Stanley Williams
description: A relaxation oscillator incorporating nanoscale niobium dioxide memristors that exhibit both a current- and a temperature-controlled negative differential resistance produces chaotic dynamics that aid biomimetic computing.

heading: New gliding mammaliaforms from the Jurassic
description: Maiopatagium, a haramiyid from the Jurassic Tiaojishan Formation (around 160 million years ago) of China was specialised for gliding with a patagium (wing membrane) and a fused wishbone, reminiscent of that of birds.

heading: Satellite-to-ground quantum key distribution
description: Decoy-state quantum key distribution from a satellite to a ground station is achieved with much greater efficiency than is possible over the same distance using optical fibres.

heading: Rewiring the taste system
authors: Hojoon LeeLindsey J. MacphersonNicholas J. P. Ryba
description: Taste-receptor cells use distinct semaphorins to guide wiring of the peripheral taste system; targeted ectopic expression of SEMA3A or SEMA7A leads to bitter neurons responding to sweet tastes or sweet neurons responding to bitter tastes.

heading: Ground-to-satellite quantum teleportation
description: Quantum teleportation of single-photon qubits from a ground observatory to a satellite in low-Earth orbit via an uplink channel is achieved with a fidelity that is well above the classical limit.

heading: mRNA 3′ uridylation and poly(A) tail length sculpt the mammalian maternal transcriptome
description: TUT4 and TUT7 mediate 3′ uridylation of mRNA transcripts, preferentially those with short poly(A) tails; in the absence of TUT4 and TUT7, oocytes cannot mature and female mice are infertile.

heading: Mutation predicts 40 million years of fly wing evolution
authors: David HouleGeir H. BolstadThomas F. Hansen
description: A detailed analysis of fly wing phenotypes reveals a strong positive relationship between variation produced by mutation, standing genetic variation, and evolutionary rate over the past 40 million years.

heading: New evidence for mammaliaform ear evolution and feeding adaptation in a Jurassic ecosystem
description: The fossil of a gliding mammal from the Tiaojishan Formation of China displays many unique features of its ears, teeth and tooth-replacement pattern, illustrating the great diversity of stem mammals living in the Jurassic period.

heading: m6A mRNA methylation controls T cell homeostasis by targeting the IL-7/STAT5/SOCS pathways
description: The authors assess the role of N6-methyladenosine in T cell development and function, and show that RNA methylation controls T cell homeostasis by regulating IL-7-mediated STAT5 activation.

heading: Structural insights into ligand recognition by the lysophosphatidic acid receptor LPA6
description: Determination of the crystal structure of the zebrafish LPA6 receptor shows that the lipid ligand binds to an unusual ligand-binding pocket in the receptor that is laterally accessible through the membrane.

heading: An early modern human presence in Sumatra 73,000–63,000 years ago
description: Morphological analysis of teeth found at Lida Ajer shows that these belong to Homo sapiens, indicating that modern humans were in Sumatra between 73,000 and 63,000 years ago.

heading: Identification of essential genes for cancer immunotherapy
authors: Shashank J. PatelNeville E. SanjanaNicholas P. Restifo
description: The authors describe a two-cell-type CRISPR screen to identify tumour-intrinsic genes that regulate the sensitivity of cancer cells to effector T cell function.

heading: Electronic in-plane symmetry breaking at field-tuned quantum criticality in CeRhIn5
authors: F. RonningT. HelmP. J. W. Moll
description: Electronic nematicity is observed in a heavy-fermion superconductor, CeRhIn5, suggesting a close link between unconventional superconductivity and the appearance of nematicity.

heading: Elsässer et al. reply
authors: Simon J. ElsässerKyung-Min NohLaura A. Banaszynski

heading: Observation of the hyperfine spectrum of antihydrogen
authors: M. AhmadiB. X. R. AlvesJ. S. Wurtele
description: The hyperfine splitting of antihydrogen has been measured and is consistent with expectations for atomic hydrogen.

heading: On the role of H3.3 in retroviral silencing
An ultrahot gas-giant exoplanet with a stratosphere
authors: Thomas M. EvansDavid K. SingRoxana Lupu
description: Observations of the gas-giant exoplanet WASP-121b reveal near-infrared emission lines of water, suggesting that the planet has a stratosphere—a layer in the upper atmosphere where temperature increases with altitude.

heading: Global Λ hyperon polarization in nuclear collisions
description: The measurement of an alignment between the angular momentum of a non-central collision between heavy ions and the spin of emitted particles reveals that the fluid produced in the collision is extremely vortical.

heading: Quantum simulation of a Fermi–Hubbard model using a semiconductor quantum dot array
authors: T. HensgensT. FujitaL. M. K. Vandersypen
description: A quantum simulation platform based on quantum dots is reported that can operate at relatively low temperatures, and its utility is shown by simulating a Fermi–Hubbard model.

heading: Persistent anthrax as a major driver of wildlife mortality in a tropical rainforest
description: An anthrax-causing agent, Bacillus cereus biovar anthracis, is a persistent and widespread cause of death for a broad range of mammalian hosts in a tropical rainforest, with important implications for the conservation of mammals such as chimpanzees.

heading: Tumours with class 3 BRAF mutants are sensitive to the inhibition of activated RAS
description: Hypoactive BRAF mutants bind more tightly than wild type to the upstream regulator RAS, thus amplifying to amplify ERK signalling; tumours expressing these mutants require coexistent mechanisms for RAS activation to grow and are sensitive to their inhibition.

heading: A Braf kinase-inactive mutant induces lung adenocarcinoma
description: Kinase-inactive Braf mutants can initiate the development of lung adenocarcinoma in mice; co-expression of activated Kras enhances tumour initiation and progression, and wild-type Braf is required to sustain tumorigenesis.

heading: Correction of aberrant growth preserves tissue homeostasis
description: Intravital imaging reveals unanticipated plasticity of adult skin epithelium in mice when faced with mutational or non-mutational insults, and elucidates the dynamic cellular behaviours used for its return to a homeostatic state.

heading: Integrative clinical genomics of metastatic cancer
authors: Dan R. RobinsonYi-Mi WuArul M. Chinnaiyan
description: Clinical exome and transcriptome sequencing of 500 adult patients with metastatic solid tumours of diverse lineage and biopsy site, as part of the Michigan Oncology Sequencing (MI-ONCOSEQ) Program.

heading: Genetic origins of the Minoans and Mycenaeans
description: New genome-wide data for ancient, Bronze Age individuals, including Minoans, Mycenaeans, and southwestern Anatolians, show that Minoans and Mycenaeans were genetically very similar yet distinct, supporting the idea of continuity but not isolation in the history of populations of the Aegean.

heading: ISWI chromatin remodellers sense nucleosome modifications to determine substrate preference
authors: Geoffrey P. DannGlen P. LiszczakTom W. Muir
description: A high-throughput approach using a DNA-barcoded nucleosome library shows that ISWI chromatin remodellers can distinguish between differently modified nucleosomes.

heading: Proteins evolve on the edge of supramolecular self-assembly
description: Introducing a single ‘sticky’ (hydrophobic) amino acid by point mutation into symmetric protein complexes frequently triggers their association into higher-order assemblies, without affecting their native fold and structure.

heading: Artificial light at night as a new threat to pollination
description: The pollination service provided by nocturnal flower visitors is disrupted near streetlamps, which leads to a reduced reproductive output of the plant that cannot be compensated for by day-time pollinators; in addition, the structure of combined nocturnal and diurnal pollination networks facilitates the spread of the consequences of disrupted night-time pollination to daytime pollinators.

heading: Metabolic control of TH17 and induced Treg cell balance by an epigenetic mechanism
description: Metabolic changes in T cells can affect the genomic methylation status of key transcription factors and regulate the fate decision between induced regulatory T cells and T helper 17 cells.

heading: Correction of a pathogenic gene mutation in human embryos
description: CRISPR–Cas9 genome editing is used to induce a DNA repair response and correct a disease-causing heterozygous mutation in human embryos with reduced mosaicism and preferential repair using the wild-type copy of the gene.

heading: Mitotic progression following DNA damage enables pattern recognition within micronuclei
authors: Shane M. HardingJoseph L. BenciRoger A. Greenberg
description: The authors report a link between mitosis, the formation of micronuclei and DNA-damage-induced cGAS-dependent inflammation.

heading: High-temperature crystallization of nanocrystals into three-dimensional superlattices
authors: Liheng WuJoshua J. WillisChristopher J. Tassone
description: A bottom-up process to achieve rapid growth of micrometre-sized three-dimensional nanocrystal superlattices during colloidal synthesis at high temperatures is revealed by in situ small-angle X-ray scattering; the process is applicable to several colloidal materials.

heading: Wilhelm et al. reply
Can we predict protein from mRNA levels?
authors: Nikolaus FortelnyChristopher M. OverallGabriela V. Cohen Freue

heading: Synergy of synthesis, computation and NMR reveals correct baulamycin structures
description: Experimental and computed nuclear magnetic resonance data and an iterative synthetic strategy have revealed the correct structures of the baulamycins, potentially important antimicrobial compounds, allowing them to be chemically synthesized.

heading: Significant and variable linear polarization during the prompt optical flash of GRB 160625B
description: The prompt optical flash produced by the γ-ray burst GRB 160625B is highly linearly polarized, suggesting that it is produced by fast-cooling synchrotron radiation in a large-scale magnetic field.

heading: Neuromorphic computing with nanoscale spintronic oscillators
description: Spoken-digit recognition using a nanoscale spintronic oscillator that mimics the behaviour of neurons demonstrates the potential of such oscillators for realizing large-scale neural networks in future hardware.

heading: Spontaneous breaking of rotational symmetry in copper oxide superconductors
description: The electronic nematic phase in copper oxide superconductors is found over a broad range of temperature and doping but is not aligned with the crystal axes.

heading: Higher-order interactions stabilize dynamics in competitive network models
description: Communities that are very rich in species could persist thanks to the stabilizing role of higher-order interactions, in which the presence of a species influences the interaction between other species.

heading: Sequencing and de novo assembly of 150 genomes from Denmark as a population reference
authors: Lasse MarettyJacob Malte JensenMikkel Heide Schierup
description: A report of high-depth, short-read sequencing and de novo assemblies for 150 individuals from 50 parent–offspring trios as part of establishing a population reference genome for the GenomeDenmark project.

heading: Prolonged Mek1/2 suppression impairs the developmental potential of embryonic stem cells
description: Long-term culture of male embryonic stem cells in naive conditions containing Mek1/2 and Gsk3a/b inhibitors leads to irreversible changes in epigenetic and genomic stability that compromise their in vivo developmental potential.

heading: Hypothalamic stem cells control ageing speed partly through exosomal miRNAs
description: Ablation of hypothalamic stem/progenitor cells in mice leads to ageing-related decreases in physiological parameters and lifespan, and the speed of ageing is partially controlled by these cells through the release of exosomal miRNAs.

heading: Derivation of ground-state female ES cells maintaining gamete-derived DNA methylation
description: Derivation of female mouse embryonic stem cells under certain conditions induces a loss of DNA methylation and erasure of genomic imprints, which are not recovered and that may contribute to observed impaired development.

heading: Complex cellular logic computation using ribocomputing devices
description: De-novo-designed RNA molecules are used to construct cellular computing devices that can implement complex logic functions.

heading: Stimulation of functional neuronal regeneration from Müller glia in adult mice
authors: Nikolas L. JorstadMatthew S. WilkenThomas A. Reh
description: Inhibition of histone deacetylation allows the transcription factor Ascl1 to bind to key gene loci in Müller glia and drive the functional generation of retinal neurons in adult mice.

heading: In vivo FRET–FLIM reveals cell-type-specific protein interactions in Arabidopsis roots
description: Imaging in living Arabidopsis roots reveals that protein complexes can change their conformation in a cell-type-dependent manner to regulate specific gene expression programs leading to precise specification and maintenance of particular cell fates within the root meristem.

heading: GLUTAMATE RECEPTOR-LIKE channels are essential for chemotaxis and reproduction in mosses
description: Mutations in genes that encode GLUTAMTATE RECEPTOR-LIKE (GLR) channels in the moss Physcomitrella patens result in failure of motile sperm to target the female reproductive organs and of zygotes to develop properly.

heading: cGAS surveillance of micronuclei links genome instability to innate immunity
authors: Karen J. MackenziePaula CarrollAndrew P. Jackson
description: The cytoplasmic DNA sensor cGAS detects DNA in ruptured micronuclei and activates an innate immune response.

heading: No large population of unbound or wide-orbit Jupiter-mass planets
description: In an analysis of a large sample of microlensing events, a few suggest the existence of Earth-mass free-floating planets, but only the expected number of Jupiter-mass free-floating objects were detected.

heading: Elements of Eoarchean life trapped in mineral inclusions
authors: T. HassenkamM. P. AnderssonM. T. Rosing
description: In situ infrared spectroscopy maps the occurrences of chemical bonds within tiny inclusions in 3,700-million-year-old metasedimentary rocks from West Greenland, finding greater evidence for organic life at this early date.

heading: Channel opening and gating mechanism in AMPA-subtype glutamate receptors
authors: Edward C. TwomeyMaria V. YelshanskayaAlexander I. Sobolevsky
description: The structures of AMPA receptors in complex with auxiliary proteins are resolved by cryo-electron microscopy, and reveal conformational and permeation pathway changes that are associated with activation and desensitization of ionotropic glutamate receptors.

heading: Experimental signatures of the mixed axial–gravitational anomaly in the Weyl semimetal NbP
description: A positive magneto-thermoelectric conductance is observed in the Weyl semimetal niobium phosphide, suggesting the presence of the elusive mixed axial–gravitational anomaly.

heading: Human occupation of northern Australia by 65,000 years ago
description: Optical dating of sediments containing stone artefacts newly excavated at Madjedbebe, Australia, indicate that human occupation began around 65,000 years ago, thereby setting a new minimum age for the arrival of people in Australia.

heading: Three-dimensional magnetization structures revealed with X-ray vector nanotomography
description: Techniques exist for imaging the magnetization patterns of magnetic thin films and at the surfaces of magnets, but here hard-X-ray tomography is used to image the three-dimensional magnetic structure within a micrometre-sized magnet in the vicinity of Bloch points.

heading: Rapid elicitation of broadly neutralizing antibodies to HIV by immunization in cows
authors: Devin SokKhoa M. LeDennis R. Burton
description: Immunization of cows with a recombinant HIV envelope protein leads to the rapid development of potent, broadly neutralizing antibodies against HIV.

heading: Ribosomes are optimized for autocatalytic production
description: The large number of small, similarly sized proteins and the small number of heavy RNA molecules that make up a ribosome reduce the time required for reproduction.

heading: The whole-genome landscape of medulloblastoma subtypes
description: Genomic analysis of 491 medulloblastoma samples, including methylation profiling of 1,256 cases, effectively assigns candidate drivers to most tumours across all molecular subgroups.

heading: Nitrogen reduction and functionalization by a multimetallic uranium nitride complex
description: A complex containing two uranium ions and three potassium ions, held together by a nitride group and a flexible molecular framework, can reduce and functionalize N2 under mild conditions.

heading: Maternal H3K27me3 controls DNA methylation-independent imprinting
description: Analysis of parental allele-specific chromatin accessibility genome-wide in mouse zygotes and morula embryos, and investigation of the epigenetic mechanisms underlying these allelic sites, identifying maternal H3K27me3 as a DNA methylation-independent mechanism for genomic imprinting.

heading: In vivo CRISPR screening identifies Ptpn2 as a cancer immunotherapy target
authors: Robert T. MangusoHans W. PopeW. Nicholas Haining
description: In vivo CRISPR screening reveals that loss of Ptpn2 increases the response of tumour cells to immunotherapy and increases IFNγ signalling, suggesting that PTPN2 inhibition may potentiate the effect of immunotherapies that invoke an IFNγ response.

heading: Topological quantum chemistry
description: A complete electronic band theory is presented that describes the global properties of all possible band structures and materials, and can be used to predict new topological insulators and semimetals.

heading: Cysteine protease cathepsin B mediates radiation-induced bystander effects
description: The cysteine protease CPR-4, a cathepsin B homologue, is identified as a radiation-induced bystander effect (RIBE) factor in nematodes in response to ultraviolet or ionizing radiation, and causes inhibition of cell death and increased embryonic lethality.

heading: Type III CRISPR–Cas systems produce cyclic oligoadenylate second messengers
description: CRISPR-associated protein Csm6 is activated by a cyclic oligoadenylate second messenger generated by Cas10 activity in the CRISPR type III interference complex, representing a novel mechanism of CRISPR interference.

heading: Distinct timescales of population coding across cortex
authors: Caroline A. RunyanEugenio PiasiniChristopher D. Harvey
description: Calcium imaging data from mice performing a virtual reality auditory decision-making task are used to analyse the population codes in primary auditory and posterior parietal cortex that support choice behaviour.

heading: The lysosomal potassium channel TMEM175 adopts a novel tetrameric architecture
description: The lysosomal potassium channel TMEM175 has a tetrameric structure unlike that of the canonical potassium channels, with an hourglass-shaped pore in which isoleucine residues have a key role in channel selectivity.

heading: Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and aldolase mediate glucose sensing by AMPK
description: Glucose starvation activates AMPK via an AMP/ADP-independent mechanism that involves fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and aldolase.

heading: Global forest loss disproportionately erodes biodiversity in intact landscapes
description: Deforestation increases the odds of a species being threatened by extinction, and this effect is disproportionately strong in relatively intact landscapes, suggesting that efforts are needed to protect intact forest landscapes and prevent a new wave of extinctions.

heading: Visible-light-driven methane formation from CO2 with a molecular iron catalyst
description: An iron tetraphenylporphyrin complex is shown to catalyse the reduction of carbon dioxide to methane upon visible light irradiation at ambient temperature and pressure.

heading: Tayi et al. reply
authors: Alok S. TayiAlexander K. ShveydSamuel I. Stupp

heading: Snyder replies
Overestimate of committed warming
authors: Gavin A. SchmidtJeff SeveringhausThomas F. Stocker

heading: Conflicting evidence for ferroelectricity
Tundra uptake of atmospheric elemental mercury drives Arctic mercury pollution
description: A two-year study of mercury deposition in the Arctic finds that the main source of mercury is gaseous elemental mercury, which is deposited throughout the year and leads to very high soil mercury levels.

heading: Quantum back-action-evading measurement of motion in a negative mass reference frame
authors: Christoffer B. MøllerRodrigo A. ThomasEugene S. Polzik
description: By coupling a mechanical object to an ensemble of atomic spins with negative effective mass, the object’s position can be measured without the usual quantum back-action perturbation of its momentum.

heading: Allelic reprogramming of 3D chromatin architecture during early mammalian development
description: A low-input Hi-C method is used to show that chromatin organization is markedly relaxed in pre-implantation mouse embryos after fertilization and that the subsequent maturation of 3D chromatin architecture is surprisingly slow.

heading: TFH-derived dopamine accelerates productive synapses in germinal centres
description: Human follicular helper T cells engaging in synaptic interactions with germinal centre B cells release dopamine stored in chromogranin B+ granules, causing rapid externalization of ICOS ligand, which in turn enhances CD40L delivery to the synaptic cleft and synaptic contact, and results in an accelerated response.

heading: Cholangiocytes act as facultative liver stem cells during impaired hepatocyte regeneration
description: Two independent systems impairing hepatocyte proliferation during liver injury cause physiologically significant levels of functional hepatocyte regeneration from biliary cells.

heading: Infant viewing of social scenes is under genetic control and is atypical in autism
description: Monozygotic twins show high concordance in eye- and mouth-looking, and this behaviour is markedly reduced in toddlers with autism spectrum disorder.

heading: CRISPR–Cas encoding of a digital movie into the genomes of a population of living bacteria
authors: Seth L. ShipmanJeff NivalaGeorge M. Church
description: The authors encode pixel values of a short motion picture into the DNA of a population of Escherichia coli.

heading: Synaptic organization of visual space in primary visual cortex
authors: M. Florencia IacarusoIoana T. GaslerSonja B. Hofer
description: Mapping the organization of excitatory inputs onto the dendritic spines of individual mouse visual cortex neurons reveals how inputs representing features from the extended visual scene are organized and establishes a computational unit suited to amplify contours and elongated edges.

heading: Open and closed structures reveal allostery and pliability in the HIV-1 envelope spike
description: New high-resolution cryo-electron microscopy structures of the HIV-1 envelope protein provide a detailed description and understanding of how the HIV-1 fusion machinery functions and how it changes its structure over time to convert from the pre-fusion to the fusion-intermediate conformation.

heading: A novel mechanism for mechanosensory-based rheotaxis in larval zebrafish
description: In the absence of visual information, larval zebrafish (Danio rerio) use their mechanosensory lateral line to perform rheotaxis by using flow velocity gradients as navigational cues.

heading: K2P2.1 (TREK-1)–activator complexes reveal a cryptic selectivity filter binding site
authors: Marco LolicatoCristina ArrigoniDaniel L. Minor Jr
description: Crystal structures of an activated two-pore potassium channel reveal a cryptic binding pocket that binds small-molecule activators that restrict the mobility of the selectivity filter and surrounding structure, stabilizing an active ‘leak-mode’ conformation.

heading: Large-scale physical activity data reveal worldwide activity inequality
description: A huge smartphone dataset of physical activity yields global insights, revealing that activity inequality predicts obesity better than does volume of activity and that much of the inequality is a result of reduced activity in females.

heading: Fischer et al. reply
authors: Kari R. FischerNasser K. AltorkiDingcheng Gao

heading: Upholding a role for EMT in pancreatic cancer metastasis
authors: Nicole M. AielloThomas BrabletzBen Z. Stanger

heading: Upholding a role for EMT in breast cancer metastasis
Cell-cycle dynamics of chromosomal organization at single-cell resolution
description: Single-cell Hi-C analysis in thousands of mouse embryonic stem cells shows that chromosomal compartments, topological-associated domains and long-range loops all have distinct cell-cycle dynamics.

heading: West Antarctic Ice Sheet retreat driven by Holocene warm water incursions
description: During the early Holocene epoch—and since the 1940s—variations in Southern Hemisphere westerly winds controlled the upwelling of Circumpolar Deep Water and seemingly ice-sheet retreat in West Antarctica.

heading: Episodic kinematics in continental rifts modulated by changes in mantle melt fraction
authors: Simon LambJames D. P. MooreTim Stern
description: GPS measurements are used to investigate the continental rift system of North Island, New Zealand, and to develop a model for short-term deformation involving flexing of an elastic upper crust caused by episodic changes in mantle viscosity and melt fraction.

heading: Cryo-EM structure of the protein-conducting ERAD channel Hrd1 in complex with Hrd3
description: The structure of yeast Hrd1 in complex with Hrd3 shows that Hrd1 forms an aqueous cavity with a lateral seal within the endoplasmic reticulum membrane, shedding light on how misfolded proteins are transported out of the endoplasmic reticulum.

heading: Three-dimensional integration of nanotechnologies for computing and data storage on a single chip
description: Multiple nanotechnologies are integrated on a single chip to realize a three-dimensional integrated circuit architecture that combines computing and data storage—a potentially transformative advance in computing.

heading: Personalized RNA mutanome vaccines mobilize poly-specific therapeutic immunity against cancer
description: The authors report the first-in-human application of personalized neo-antigen RNA vaccines in patients with melanoma.

heading: An immunogenic personal neoantigen vaccine for patients with melanoma
authors: Patrick A. OttZhuting HuCatherine J. Wu
description: The results of a phase I trial assessing a personal neoantigen multi-peptide vaccine in patients with melanoma, showing feasibility, safety, and immunogenicity.

heading: Dependency of a therapy-resistant state of cancer cells on a lipid peroxidase pathway
authors: Vasanthi S. ViswanathanMatthew J. RyanStuart L. Schreiber
description: Therapy-resistant cancer cell states identified across diverse contexts are selectively vulnerable to ferroptotic cell death induced by inhibition of lipid peroxidase pathways converging on GPX4.

heading: Nutrient sensing modulates malaria parasite virulence
description: Malaria parasites use a sensing mechanism to moderate their growth in response to the nutrient content of their host.

heading: Crystal structures of agonist-bound human cannabinoid receptor CB1
description: Crystal structures of the human cannabinoid receptor 1 (CB1) bound to the agonists AM11542 and AM841 reveal notable structural rearrangements upon receptor activation, and this flexibility may be a common feature among other G-protein-coupled receptors.

heading: Transcription elongation factors represent in vivo cancer dependencies in glioblastoma
authors: Tyler E. MillerBrian B. LiauJeremy N. Rich
description: An in vivo RNA interference screening strategy in glioblastoma enabled the identification of a host of epigenetic targets required for glioblastoma cell survival that were not identified by parallel standard screening in cell culture, including the transcription pause–release factor JMJD6, and could be a powerful tool to uncover new therapeutic targets in cancer.

heading: Cryo-EM structures of tau filaments from Alzheimer’s disease
authors: Anthony W. P. FitzpatrickBenjamin FalconSjors H. W. Scheres
description: High-resolution structures of tau filaments shed light on the ultrastructure of neurofibrillary lesions in Alzheimer’s disease.

heading: Pre-oral gut contributes to facial structures in non-teleost fishes
description: In contrast to the prevailing belief that the gut begins with the mouth and continues backwards from there, this work shows that substantial areas of the faces of ray-finned fishes originate from the pre-oral gut or endoderm.

heading: The pyrite-type high-pressure form of FeOOH
description: The pyrite-type high-pressure form of FeOOH is predicted from first principles, and found experimentally to be stable under the conditions at the base of the mantle, with implications for transport of water within Earth’s deep interior.

heading: Dong et al. reply
Dong et al. reply
Dong et al. reply
Dong et al. reply
Dong et al. reply
Contesting the evidence for limited human lifespan
authors: Nicholas J. L. BrownCasper J. AlbersStuart J. Ritchie

heading: Many possible maximum lifespan trajectories
Questionable evidence for a limit to human lifespan
Is there evidence for a limit to human lifespan?
authors: Maarten P. RozingThomas B. L. KirkwoodRudi G. J. Westendorp

heading: Maximum human lifespan may increase to 125 years
Making waves in a photoactive polymer film
authors: Anne Helene GelebartDirk Jan MulderDirk J. Broer
description: Illumination of thin liquid-crystal polymer films that contain azobenzene derivatives with short thermal relaxation times induces a continuous wave motion throughout the films, owing to a feedback loop driven by material self-shadowing.

heading: On-chip generation of high-dimensional entangled quantum states and their coherent control
description: The on-chip generation of high-dimensional frequency-entangled states and their spectral-domain manipulation are demonstrated, introducing a powerful and practical platform for quantum information processing.

heading: Tracing the origins of relapse in acute myeloid leukaemia to stem cells
authors: Liran I. ShlushAmanda MitchellJohn E. Dick
description: Identification of the cell types from which relapse arises in acute myeloid leukaemia, by following leukaemia propagation from patient-derived leukaemia samples.

heading: mTORC1-dependent AMD1 regulation sustains polyamine metabolism in prostate cancer
description: mTOR complex 1 signalling regulates polyamine metabolism and thereby promotes tumorigenesis, through regulation of the stability of a key enzyme, AMD1.

heading: RNase III nucleases from diverse kingdoms serve as antiviral effectors
authors: Lauren C. AguadoSonja SchmidBenjamin R. tenOever
description: RNase III from all three domains of life elicits RNA-targeting antiviral activity that is independent of, and possibly predates, other known eukaryotic antiviral systems.

heading: Recurrent and functional regulatory mutations in breast cancer
description: High-depth sequencing of targeted regions in primary breast cancer identifies mutated promoter elements with recurrent mutations at specific and/or nearby bases, suggesting selection of certain non-coding events.

heading: Climate change drives expansion of Antarctic ice-free habitat
description: Permanently ice-free areas, home to almost all of Antarctica’s biodiversity, are projected, in the worst case, to expand by over 17,000 km2 as a result of climate change by the end of this century, with potentially deleterious consequences for the continent’s biodiversity.

heading: Fine-mapping inflammatory bowel disease loci to single-variant resolution
description: Results of fine-mapping 94 inflammatory bowel disease loci using high-density genotyping in 67,852 individuals and several new fine-mapping methods.

heading: Whole-body imaging of lymphovascular niches identifies pre-metastatic roles of midkine
description: Genetically engineered ‘lymphoreporter’ mouse strains are used to track melanoma dissemination in vivo, identifying midkine as a tumour-secreted factor that acts at a distance, preparing pre-metastatic niches and serving as an indicator of poor prognosis in patients.

heading: Electron cryo-microscopy structure of the mechanotransduction channel NOMPC
description: Single-particle electron cryo-microscopy analysis of the mechanotransduction channel NOMPC reveals that it contains a bundle of four helical spring-shaped ankyrin repeat domains that undergo motion, potentially allowing mechanical movement of the cytoskeleton to be coupled to the opening of the channel.

heading: Zanos et al. reply
A massive, dead disk galaxy in the early Universe
description: When the Universe was just 3 billion years old, half of the most massive galaxies had already ceased star formation, and such a galaxy has now been observed using gravitational lensing, unexpectedly turning out to be a compact, fast-spinning disk galaxy rather than a proto-bulge galaxy.

heading: Strong constraints on aerosol–cloud interactions from volcanic eruptions
authors: Florent F. MalavelleJim M. HaywoodThorvaldur Thordarson
description: Investigations of an Icelandic volcanic eruption confirm that sulfate aerosols caused a discernible yet transient brightening effect, as predicted, but their effect on the liquid water path was unexpectedly negligible.

heading: Unique roles for histone H3K9me states in RNAi and heritable silencing of transcription
description: Heterochromatin formation involves histone H3 methylation, with H3K9me2 defining a distinct heterochromatin state that is transcriptionally permissive and can couple with RNAi, and the transition to non-permissive H3K9me3 required for the epigenetic heritability of heterochromatin.

heading: Effects of a ketamine metabolite on synaptic NMDAR function
Catalytic allylic oxidation of internal alkenes to a multifunctional chiral building block
authors: Liela BayehPhong Q. LeUttam K. Tambar
description: Non-symmetric internal alkenes are selectively converted into allylic functionalized products with high stereoselectivity and regioselectivity.

heading: Microscopy of the interacting Harper–Hofstadter model in the two-body limit
description: The combination of interparticle interactions and a synthetic gauge field leads to chirality in the propagation dynamics of particles in a ladder-like lattice.

heading: Selective sp3 C–H alkylation via polarity-match-based cross-coupling
authors: Chip LeYufan LiangDavid W. C. MacMillan
description: Using a triple catalytic approach, a selective sp3 C–H alkylation is demonstrated that is applicable in late-stage functionalization of pharmaceutical compounds.

heading: Hidden morphological diversity among early tetrapods
authors: Jason D. PardoMatt SzostakiwskyjJason S. Anderson
description: Detailed micro-computed tomography analysis of the skull of Lethiscus stocki places it much earlier in the tetrapod lineage that was previously thought, showing that early tetrapods were more morphologically diverse than has been believed.

heading: Surface tension prevails over solute effect in organic-influenced cloud droplet activation
description: A phase-separation mechanism is proposed for the dominance of the surface tension effect over the solute effect in the observed activation of ultrafine cloud condensation nuclei.

heading: Phase separation drives heterochromatin domain formation
authors: Amy R. StromAlexander V. EmelyanovGary H. Karpen
description: HP1a can nucleate into foci that display liquid properties during the early stages of heterochromatin domain formation in Drosophila embryos, suggesting that the repressive action of heterochromatin may be mediated in part by emergent properties of phase separation.

heading: T cells from patients with Parkinson’s disease recognize α-synuclein peptides
description: Epitopes derived from two regions of α-synuclein elicit immune responses in patients with Parkinson’s disease, involving IL-5-secreting CD4+ T cells, as well as IFNγ-secreting CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

heading: Crystal structure of the potassium-importing KdpFABC membrane complex
authors: Ching-Shin HuangBjørn Panyella PedersenDavid L. Stokes
description: The crystal structure of the bacterial potassium import complex KdpFABC shows how ATP hydrolysis is coupled to potassium transport to maintain cellular homeostasis under low potassium conditions.

heading: Identifying specificity groups in the T cell receptor repertoire
description: The authors devise an algorithm that can cluster T cell receptor (TCR) sequences sharing the same specificity, predict the HLA restriction of these TCR clusters on the basis of subjects’ genotypes and help to identify specific peptide major histocompatibility complex ligands.

heading: Quantifiable predictive features define epitope-specific T cell receptor repertoires
authors: Pradyot DashAndrew J. Fiore-GartlandPaul G. Thomas
description: The authors characterize epitope-specific T cell repertoires, identify shared and recognizable features of TCRs, and develop tools to classify antigen specificity on the basis of sequence analysis.

heading: Trans-kingdom mimicry underlies ribosome customization by a poxvirus kinase
description: The poxvirus vaccinia virus phosphorylates serine/threonine residues in the human small ribosomal subunit RACK1, converting it to a plant-like state to favour translation of poxvirus mRNAs

heading: Liquid droplet formation by HP1α suggests a role for phase separation in heterochromatin
authors: Adam G. LarsonDaniel ElnatanGeeta J. Narlikar
description: Phosphorylation or DNA binding promotes the physical partitioning of HP1α out of a soluble aqueous phase into droplets, suggesting that the repressive action of heterochromatin may in part be mediated by the phase separation of HP1.

heading: Nlrp9b inflammasome restricts rotavirus infection in intestinal epithelial cells
description: The inflammasome receptor Nlrp9b defends against enteric viruses by interacting with double-stranded viral RNA-bound helicase Dhx9, triggering gasdermin-D-dependent pyroptotic cell death of infected cells and secretion of Il-18.

heading: Host and viral traits predict zoonotic spillover from mammals
authors: Kevin J. OlivalParviez R. HosseiniPeter Daszak
description: Analysis of a comprehensive database of mammalian host–virus relationships reveals that both the total number of viruses that infect a given species and the proportion likely to be zoonotic are predictable and that this enables identification of mammalian species and geographic locations where novel zoonoses are likely to be found.

heading: Observation of three-component fermions in the topological semimetal molybdenum phosphide
description: A new type of fermion, corresponding to a three-fold degeneracy in the electronic band structure of crystalline molybdenum phosphide, is observed, which lies conceptually between Dirac and Weyl fermions.

heading: A wet-tolerant adhesive patch inspired by protuberances in suction cups of octopi
description: The suction cups found in octopus tentacles are the inspiration for a synthetic adhesive that functions well in dry and wet conditions and is resistant to chemical contamination.

heading: Slush-like polar structures in single-crystal relaxors
description: Molecular dynamics simulations of the Pb(Mg1/3,Nb2/3)O3–PbTiO3 relaxor reveal a multi-domain state analogous to the slush state of water that provides an explanation for the unusual properties of relaxors.

heading: Rare cell variability and drug-induced reprogramming as a mode of cancer drug resistance
authors: Sydney M. ShafferMargaret C. DunaginArjun Raj
description: Through drug exposure, a rare, transient transcriptional program characterized by high levels of expression of known resistance drivers can get ‘burned in’, leading to the selection of cells endowed with a transcriptional drug resistance and thus more chemoresistant cancers.

heading: Robust wireless power transfer using a nonlinear parity–time-symmetric circuit
description: A nonlinear parity–time-symmetric circuit is used to enable robust wireless power transfer to a moving device over a distance of one metre without the need for tuning.

heading: Microglia-dependent synapse loss in type I interferon-mediated lupus
authors: Allison R. BialasJessy PresumeyMichael C. Carroll
description: Abnormal behavioural phenotypes and synapse loss in the brain of lupus-prone mice are prevented by blocking type I interferon signalling, which is further shown to stimulate microglial phagocytosis of neuronal material in the brains of these mice.

heading: Histone deacetylase 3 prepares brown adipose tissue for acute thermogenic challenge
authors: Matthew J. EmmettHee-Woong LimMitchell A. Lazar
description: Histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) is required to activate brown adipose tissue enhancers to ensure thermogenic aptitude.

heading: Selective depletion of uropathogenic E. coli from the gut by a FimH antagonist
authors: Caitlin N. SpauldingRoger D. KleinScott J. Hultgren
description: Both F17-like and type 1 pili promote intestinal colonization in mouse colonic crypts, and the high-affinity mannoside M4284 reduces intestinal colonization of uropathogenic Escherichia coli while simultaneously treating urinary tract infections without disrupting the composition of the gut microbiota.

heading: Human fetal dendritic cells promote prenatal T-cell immune suppression through arginase-2
description: Prenatal immune suppression is regulated by fetal arginase-2-expressing dendritic cells which respond normally to toll-like receptor stimulation but, in contrast to adult dendritic cells, induce regulatory T cells and repress TNF-α secretion by effector T cells.

heading: Homeostatic circuits selectively gate food cue responses in insular cortex
authors: Yoav LivnehRohan N. RameshMark L. Andermann
description: A combination of microprism-based cellular imaging to monitor insular cortex visual cue responses in behaving mice across hunger states with circuit mapping and manipulations reveals a neural basis for state-specific biased processing of motivationally relevant cues.

heading: ERF mutations reveal a balance of ETS factors controlling prostate oncogenesis
authors: Rohit BoseWouter R. KarthausCharles L. Sawyers
description: In prostate cancer, the oncogenicity of transcription factor ERG is mediated, in part, by competition with another member of the ETS family, ERF.

heading: PTEN counteracts FBXL2 to promote IP3R3- and Ca2+-mediated apoptosis limiting tumour growth
description: PTEN, a known tumour suppressor, inhibits the FXBL2-dependent degradation of IP3R3, an IP3 receptor, thus augmenting IP3R3-mediated calcium release from the endoplasmic reticulum to mitochondria and inducing apoptosis; inhibiting FXBL2 sensitizes PTEN-deficient tumours to photodynamic therapy.

heading: Multilineage communication regulates human liver bud development from pluripotency
description: Single-cell RNA sequencing analysis of two- and three-dimensional hepatic differentiation reveals that both systems recapitulate certain transcriptomic features of human hepatogenesis.

heading: BAP1 regulates IP3R3-mediated Ca2+ flux to mitochondria suppressing cell transformation
description: BRCA1-associated protein 1 (BAP1) regulates calcium flux in the endoplasmic reticulum to facilitate the execution of apoptosis, unveiling a new facet of the role of BAP1 as an environmental tumour suppressor.

heading: Improved maize reference genome with single-molecule technologies
description: An improved reference genome for maize, using single-molecule sequencing and high-resolution optical mapping, enables characterization of structural variation and repetitive regions, and identifies lineage expansions of transposable elements that are unique to maize.

heading: New fossils from Jebel Irhoud, Morocco and the pan-African origin of Homo sapiens
description: New human fossils from Jebel Irhoud (Morocco) document the earliest evolutionary stage of Homo sapiens and display modern conditions of the face and mandible combined with more primative features of the neurocranium.

heading: Microresonator-based solitons for massively parallel coherent optical communications
description: Frequency combs produced by solitons in silicon-based optical microresonators are used to transmit data streams of more than 50 terabits per second in telecommunication wavelength bands.

heading: Layer-dependent ferromagnetism in a van der Waals crystal down to the monolayer limit
description: Magneto-optical Kerr effect microscopy is used to show that monolayer chromium triiodide is an Ising ferromagnet with out-of-plane spin orientation.

heading: The age of the hominin fossils from Jebel Irhoud, Morocco, and the origins of the Middle Stone Age
description: Thermoluminescence dating of fire-heated flint artefacts, and directly associated newly discovered remains of Homo sapiens, indicate that the Middle Stone Age site of Jebel Irhoud in Morocco is 383–247 thousand years old.

heading: Accelerated discovery of two crystal structure types in a complex inorganic phase field
authors: C. CollinsM. S. DyerM. J. Rosseinsky
description: A computational tool that combines human-like chemical understanding with ab initio methods guides the compositional choice of complex five-component metallic oxides, yielding two new complex crystal structures.

heading: Exosomes facilitate therapeutic targeting of oncogenic KRAS in pancreatic cancer
description: Exosomes improve the delivery of siRNA to mutant KRAS in the pancreatic tumours and bypass immune clearance better than artificial liposomes, probably owing to enhanced macropinocytocis and presence of CD47 on exosomes, respectively.

heading: The metabolic function of cyclin D3–CDK6 kinase in cancer cell survival
description: The cyclin D3–CDK6 kinase complex, which is overactive in some cancers, inhibits two key glycolysis enzymes and thereby enhances the levels of antioxidants in cells, promoting tumour cell survival.

heading: Principles of early human development and germ cell program from conserved model systems
description: The authors trace the emergence of porcine primordial germ cells and develop in vitro models of primordial germ cell development from human and monkey pluripotent stem cells in order to provide insight into early human development.

heading: Single-molecule analysis of ligand efficacy in β2AR–G-protein activation
authors: G. Glenn GregorioMatthieu MasureelScott C. Blanchard
description: Single-molecule FRET imaging provides insights into the allosteric link between the ligand-binding and G-protein nucleotide-binding pockets of the β2 adrenergic receptor (β2AR) and improved understanding of the G-protein activation mechanism.

heading: A retinal code for motion along the gravitational and body axes
authors: Shai SabbahJohn A. GemmerDavid M. Berson
description: Global mapping shows that mouse retinal neurons prefer visual motion produced when the animal moves along two behaviourally relevant axes, allowing the encoding of the animal’s every translation and rotation.

heading: Stability and function of regulatory T cells expressing the transcription factor T-bet
authors: Andrew G. LevineAlejandra MendozaAlexander Y. Rudensky
description: Regulatory T cells expressing the transcription factor T-bet selectively suppress TH1 and CD8 T cells, but not TH2 or TH17 activation and associated autoimmunity.

heading: A giant planet undergoing extreme-ultraviolet irradiation by its hot massive-star host
authors: B. Scott GaudiKeivan G. StassunPatricia Trueblood
description: The giant planet KELT-9b has a dayside temperature of about 4,600 K, which is sufficiently high to dissociate molecules and to evaporate its atmosphere, owing to its hot stellar host.

heading: The extracellular matrix protein agrin promotes heart regeneration in mice
description: The extracellular matrix protein agrin promotes cardiac regeneration in adult mice after myocardial infarction; it modulates cardiac differentiation and proliferation by interacting with the dystrophin–glycoprotein complex, Yap and ERK-mediated signalling.

heading: Dystrophin–glycoprotein complex sequesters Yap to inhibit cardiomyocyte proliferation
description: After injury in the heart, postnatal mouse hearts deficient in the Hippo pathway show efficient repair, and in the hearts of Mdx mice (a model of Duchenne muscular dystrophy) Hippo deficiency protects against overload-induced heart failure.

heading: Genetic wiring maps of single-cell protein states reveal an off-switch for GPCR signalling
authors: Markus BrockmannVincent A. BlomenThijn R. Brummelkamp
description: Random mutagenesis in haploid human cells coupled to quantitative protein measurements with different antibodies is used as a readout for individual cellular phenotypes.

heading: Frequency dependence limits divergent evolution by favouring rare immigrants over residents
description: In a study using stickleback fish, negative frequency-dependent selection favours rare immigrants over common residents, weakening the effect of divergent natural selection.

heading: RNA phase transitions in repeat expansion disorders
description: Nucleotide repeat expansions create templates for multivalent base-pairing, which causes RNA to undergo a sol–gel phase transition and may explain the formation of nuclear RNA foci that are commonly observed in several neurological and neuromuscular diseases.

heading: The B-cell receptor controls fitness of MYC-driven lymphoma cells via GSK3β inhibition
description: Combined studies in MYC-driven mouse lymphomas and human Burkitt lymphoma unravel an essential role for the B-cell antigen receptor in the control of tumour B-cell fitness both in vitro and in vivo, with possible biological and clinical implications.

heading: Deletion of a mycobacterial divisome factor collapses single-cell phenotypic heterogeneity
authors: E. Hesper RegoRebecca E. AudetteEric J. Rubin
description: The mycobacterial protein LamA functions as an inhibitor of cell wall synthesis at the nascent cell pole, contributing to asymmetry in polar growth, and could represent a much-needed target for the development of anti-tuberculosis therapies.

heading: Structure of the Cpf1 endonuclease R-loop complex after target DNA cleavage
description: The structure of Cpf1, a CRISPR–Cas/RNA-guided nuclease, is presented with a three-stranded RNA–DNA loop after cleavage, providing insight into its working mechanism.

heading: Crystal structure of the GLP-1 receptor bound to a peptide agonist
description: The solved crystal structure of the GLP-1 receptor bound to a truncated agonist enables the design of synthetic agonists that exhibit potent activity in vivo.

heading: Acetyl-CoA synthetase regulates histone acetylation and hippocampal memory
description: The metabolic enzyme acetyl coenzyme A synthetase directly regulates gene expression during memory formation by binding to specific genes and providing acetyl coenzyme A for histone acetylation.

heading: Femtosecond response of polyatomic molecules to ultra-intense hard X-rays
description: Upon exposure to ultra-intense, hard X-ray pulses, polyatomic molecules containing one heavy atom reach a much higher degree of ionization than do individual heavy atoms, contrary to previous assumptions.

heading: Dynamic corticostriatal activity biases social bonding in monogamous female prairie voles
authors: Elizabeth A. AmadeiZachary V. JohnsonRobert C. Liu
